YN CHESHAGHT GHAILCKAGH

Manx: S'lesh Brimax Books kied-choipal ny jallooyn

English: [image]
Manx: [jalloo]

English: Alice Pleasance Liddell
Manx: Alice Pleasance Liddell

English: Foreword
Manx: Roie-raa

English: Lewis Carroll was the pen-name of mathematics lecturer Charles Dodgson when he wrote he wrote his nonsense rhymes an books.
Manx: She Lewis Carroll yn ennym screeuee v’ec leaghteyr maddaght Charles Dodgson tra screeu eh ny draneyn as lioaryn meecheeayllagh echey.

English: He was born the twenty-seventh of January in the year 1832 and he received his education at Richmond School, Rugby School and Christ Church College, Oxford, where he taught mathematics for twenty-six years, until 1881.
Manx: V’eh ruggit yn 27oo laa Jerrey Geuree sy vlein 1832 as hooar eh yn edjaghys echey ec Scoill Richmond, Scoill Rugby as Colleish Keeill Chreest, Oxford, raad v’eh gynsaghey maddaght rish 26 bleeaney derrey 1881.

English: The Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland is his most famous book, written by him especially to entertain the daughter of the Dean of Christ Church College.
Manx: She yn lioar smoo ard-ghooagh echey Contoyrtyssyn Ealish ayns Cheer ny Yindyssyn va scruit echey er lheh dy chur taitnys da neen Dean Colleish Keeill Chreest..

English: Her name was Alice Pleasance Liddell.
Manx: She Alice Pleasance Liddell yn ennym v’urree.

English: The book was first published in 1865 and since then it has become one of the most famous and  beloved children’s stories that has ever been written.
Manx: Va’n lioar er ny chur magh hoshiaght ayns 1865 as er dyn traa shen t’eh er jeet dy ve nane jeh ny skeealyn clienney smoo ennymoil as smoo ennoil va rieau scruit.

English: Lewis Caroll was a keean photographer too and he took many photos of the Liddell family.
Manx: Va Lewis Caroll ny chasleyder-sollys jeean neesht as ghow eh ymmodee caslysyn jeh lught-thie Liddell.

English: The picture above of Alice Liddell, it was taken by him in the year 1859.
Manx: Yn caslys heose jeh Alice Liddell, v’eh goit echey sy vlein 1859.

English: In Lewis Carroll’s story, Ealish follows the White Rabbit down the rabbit-hole into an extremely strange wonderland where creatures hold endless tea-parties, dance the quadrille, drive and play the most peculiar game of croquet that there has ever been.
Manx: Ayns skeeal Lewis Carroll, ta Ealish geiyrt er y Chonning Vane sheese y towl-conning stiagh ayns cheer ny yindyssyn whaagh erskyn towse raad ta cretooryn cummal giensyn-tey dyn jerrey, daunsey yn "quadrille,-gimmagh as cloie yn gamman s’quaaghey dy chroquet ta rieau er ve ayn.

English: The stories about Alice’s adventures have been told again and again to generations of children.
Manx: Ta ny skeealyn mychione contoyrtyssyn Ealish er n’goll er insh reesht as reesht da sheelogheyn dy phaitchyn.

English: This time the artist Eric Kincaid has gone back to real picture of Alice and with his particular illustrative style he has created new images for this classic children’s book that seem fresh and lively.
Manx: Yn cheayrt shoh ta’n jallooder Eric Kincaid er n’goll er ash dys caslys yn Ealish firrinagh as lesh yn aght jallooaghey er lheh echey t’eh er chroo jallooyn noa son y lioar clienney classicagh shoh ta jeeaghyn oor as bioyr.

English: Alice’s stories are a sort of Everest for translators because of the abundance of play-words in it, especially the double-entendres (puns).
Manx: She sorch dy 'Everest' da çhyndaaderyn skeealyn Ealish kyndagh rish yn phalchid dy cloie-fockle t’ayn, er lheh ny raaghyn daa foyragh.

English: Nevertheless, the stories are available today in more than fifty tongues (languages) throughout the world, including now Manx, thanks to Brian Stowell.
Manx: Ny yei shoh, ta ny skeealyn ry gheddyn jiu ayns ny smoo na 50 chengaghyn feiy ny cruinney, goaill stiagh nish Y Ghaelg bwooise da Brian Stowell.

English: This Manx translation came out of a challenge that was given to Brian a few years ago, that Manx could not be used to translate such a difficult story.
Manx: Haink y chyndaa Gaelgagh shoh ass doolane va currit da Brian kuse dy vleeantyn er dy henney nagh voddagh Gaelg ve currit er lheid y skeeal cho doillee..

English: That it is was fufilled so well by him is an example to us that Manx can to be used just as creatively and effectively as any other tongue in the hands of a capable Manx speaker.
Manx: Dy row eh cooilleenit cho mie echey ny hampleyr dooin dy vod Yn Ghaelg goll er ymmydey kiart cho crootagh as fondagh as chengey erbee elley ayns laueyn Gaelgeyr aghtal.

English: Thanks to Christ Church College Oxford for Alice’s picture.
Manx: Bwooise da Colleish Keeill Chreest, Oxford son caslys Alice.

English: List of the Chapters
Manx: Rolley ny Cabdyllyn

Manx: Duillag  Cabdyl

Manx: 1 Sheese sy Towl-Conning

Manx: 2 Y Dubbey dy Yeir

Manx: 3 Ratch-kaakys as Skeeal Liauyr

English: 4 The Rabbit sends in a little bill.
Manx: 4 Ta’n Chonning Cur Stiagh Illiam Beg

English: 5 Advice from a Caterpillar
Manx: 5 Coyrle voish Praddag

English: 6 Pig and Pepper
Manx: 6 Muc as Pibbyr

English: 7 A Mad Tea-Party
Manx: 7 Giense-Tey Keoi

English: 8 The Queen’s Croquet-Ground
Manx: 8 Faaie-Croquet y Venrein

English: 9 The Mock-Turtle’s Story
Manx: 9 Skeeal y Far-Ligganagh Marrey

English: 10 The Lobster Quadrille
Manx: 10 Y Quadrille-Gimmagh

English: 11 Who stole the Tarts?
Manx: 11 Quoi Gheid ny Sooanyn

English: 12 Alice’s Evidence
Manx: 12 Feanish Ealish

English: Chapter 1
Manx: CABDYL I

English: Down The Rabbit-Hole
Manx: Sheese sy Towl-Conning

English: Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do.
Manx: Va Ealish cheet dy ve feer skee liorish soie marish e shuyr er y vroogh as veg eck ry-yannoo:

English: Once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, “and what is the use of a book,” thought Alice, “without pictures or conversations?”
Manx: Keayrt ny ghaa v’ee er speeikey sy lioar va’n chuyr eck lhaih, agh cha row jallooyn ny co-loayrtyssyn ayn, “as cre’n feeuid t’ec lioar,” smooinee Ealish, “fegooish jallooyn ny co-loayrtyssyn?”

English: So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.
Manx: Er y hon shen v'ee sursmooinaght, syn aigney eck hene (chammah as v'ee abyl, er y fa dy row y laa cheh cur urree gennaghtyn feer chadlagh as bolvaneagh), beagh y taitnys jeh jannoo geuley-shee feeu y boirey jeh troggal urree as pluggey ny neayninyn, tra, dy doaltattym, roie Conning Vane as sooillyn jiarg-bane echey faggys jee.

English: There was nothing so very remarkable in that, nor did Alice think it so very much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself,
Manx: Cha row shen feer chronnalagh; as cha smooinee Ealish dy row eh feer whaagh dy chlashtyn y Chonning gra rish hene,

English: “Oh dear! Oh
Manx: “Atreih! Atreih! Bee'm ro anmagh!”

English: dear! I shall be too late!”
(when she thought about it afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural)
Manx: (tra smooinee ee er shoh ny s’anmagh, woaill y smooinaght ee dy lhisagh ee er ngoaill yindys jeh shoh, agh ec y traa shen v'eh ooilley sheiltyn dy row eh dooghyssagh dy liooar);

English: but when the Rabbit actually took a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket and looked at it and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and, burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it and was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole, under the hedge.
Manx: agh, tra ghow y Chonning ooreyder magh ass poggaid e vest as yeeagh eh er, as eisht jimmee eh roish dy tappee, lheim Ealish ny shassoo, er y fa dy jagh eh trooid e h-aigney nagh row ee rieau er vakin conning roie as poggaid-vest echey, ny ooreyder dy ghoaill magh ass noadyr, as, eeit seose lesh peeikearys, roie ee tessen y magher ny lurg, as v'ee kiart abyl fakin eh as eh goll roish sheese ayns towl-conning mooar va fo'n chleigh.

English: In another moment, down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.
Manx: Ayns grig elley, hie Ealish sheese ny lurg, gyn smooinaght erbee sy teihll er yn aght veagh ee cosney magh ass reesht.

English: The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down what seemed to be a very deep well.
Manx: Va'n towl-conning jeeragh goll rish thiollane ec y toshiaght, as eisht v'eh goll sheese dy doaltattym, cho doaltattym as nagh row tullagh ec Ealish dy smooinaghtyn er scuirr ee hene roish my row ee tuittym sheese red va goll rish chibbyrt feer dowin.

English: Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time, as she went down, to look about her, and to wonder what was going to happen next.
Manx: Va’n chibbyrt feer dowin, er-nonney v’ee tuittym feer voal, er y fa dy row traa dy liooar eck dy yeeaghyn mygeayrt y mooee myr v'ee goll sheese, as dy smooinaghtyn cre veagh taghyrt lurg shen.

English: First, she tried to make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs.
Manx: Hoshiaght, phrow ee jeeaghyn sheese as fakin cre v'ee cheet huggey, agh v'eh ro ghorraghey dy 'akin red erbee: eisht, yeeagh ee er cheughyn y çhibbyrt as hug ee my ner dy row ad lhieent lesh cubbyrtyn as skellooyn-lioaragh: ayns shoh as ayns shid honnick ee caslyssyn-cheerey as jallooyn va croghit er kibbinyn.

English: She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed. It was labeled “ORANGE MARMALADE,” but, to her great disappointment, it was empty; she did not like to drop the jar, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.
Manx: Ghow ee costrayl veih nane jeh ny skellooyn as ish goll shaghey: va lipaid er, “MARMALAID ORANJE,” agh v’ee mollit dy mooar er y fa dy row eh follym: cha row ee laccal lhiggey da’n chostrayl tuittym, er aggle dy jinnagh eh marroo peiagh ennagh oddagh ve foee, as, kyndagh rish shen, haink eh lhee eh y chur stiagh ayns nane jeh ny cubbyrtyn myr v’ee tuittym shaghey.

English: “Well!” thought Alice to herself, “after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they’ll all think me at home.
Manx: “Dy jarroo!” smooinee Ealish ree hene. "Erreish dou v'er tuittym myr shoh, cha jeanym coontey veg jeh surlley sheese ny greeishyn! Nagh bee ad ooilley coontey mish y ve dunnal ayns y thie!

English: Why, I wouldn’t say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house. (Which was very likely true).
Manx: Cammah, cha nyiarrins veg my e chione, eer dy duittins veih mullagh y thie!" (Va feer liklee y ve firrinagh).

English: Down, down, down. Would the fall never come to an end?
Manx: Sheese, sheese, sheese. Nagh beagh jerrey dy bragh er tuittym?

English: “I wonder how many miles I’ve fallen by this time?” she said aloud.
Manx: “C’woad meeiley ta mee er duittym nish, ta mee smooinaghtyn?” dooyrt ee er ard.

English: “I must be getting somewhere near the centre of the earth.
Manx: “Gyn ourys, ta mee roshtyn boayl ennagh ta faggys da mean y teihill.

English: Let me see: that would be four thousand miles down, I think—”
Manx: Lhig dou smooinaghtyn: veagh shen kiare thousane meeiley sheese, er lhiam —”

English: (for, you see, Alice had learnt several things of this sort in her lessons in the schoolroom, and though this was not a very good opportunity for showing off her knowledge, as there was no one to listen to her, still it was good practice to say it over)
Manx: (er y fa, t’ou toiggal, dy row Ealish er nynsaghey shiartanse dy reddyn myr shoh ayns ny lessoonyn eck sy chamyr-scoill, as ga nagh row shoh ny chaa feer vie dy hoilshaghey y fys eck, er y hon nagh row peiagh ayn dy eaishtagh ree, ny yeih, she cliaghtey mie dy ghra eh reesht)

English: “—yes, that’s about the right distance—but then I wonder what Latitude or Longitude I’ve got to?”
Manx: “— she, shen mysh y foddid kiart — agh cre’n Lheead-Cruinney ny Lhiurid-Cruinney ta mee er roshtyn, ta mee smooinaghtyn?”

English: (Alice had no idea what Latitude was, or Longitude either, but thought they were nice grand words to say.)
Manx: (Cha row fys ec Ealish er y vun jeh Lheead- Cruinney ny jeh Lhiurid-Cruinney noadyr, agh v'ee coontey ad dy ve nyn vocklyn braew jesh dy ghra.)

English: Presently she began again. “I wonder if I shall fall right through the earth!
Manx: Lurg tammylt, ghow ee toshiaght reesht. “Jeanym tuittym kiart trooid y teihll!

English: How funny it’ll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward!
Manx: Nagh bee eh aitt dy heet magh mastey sleih ta shooyl as ny king oc heese!

English: The Antipathies, I think—” (she was rather glad there was no one listening, this time, as it didn’t sound at all the right word)
Manx: Ny Noi-Woailley, er lhiam—” (v’ee beggan bwooiagh nagh row peiagh erbee geaishtagh, y keayrt shoh, er y fa nagh row eh sheeanal goll rish y fockle kiart noadyr)

English: “—but I shall have to ask them what the name of the country is, you know. Please, Ma’am, is this New Zealand or Australia?”
Manx: “—agh shegin dou fenaght jeu cre'n ennym t'er y cheer, ta fys ayd. My sailliu, Venainstyr, nee yn Teelan Noa t'ayn? Ny yn Austrail?”

English: (and she tried to curtsey as she spoke fancy curtseying as you’re falling through the air! Do you think you could manage it?)
Manx: As phrow ee dy yannoo curtshee as ish loayrt -— smooinee er shen, curtshee as oo tuittym trooid yn aer! Vel oo smooinaghtyn dy voddagh oo jannoo eh?)

English: “And what an ignorant little girl she’ll think me for asking!
Manx: “As nagh jean ee smooinaghtyn dy nee inneen veg almoragh mish son briaght!

English: No, it’ll never do to ask: perhaps I shall see it written up somewhere.”
Manx: Cha bee eh cooie dy vriaght: foddee dy vaikym eh screeut seose boayl ennagh.”

English: Down, down, down! There was nothing else to do, so Alice soon began talking to herself.
Manx: Sheese, sheese, sheese. Cha row veg elley ry yannoo, as, er y hon shen, ghow Ealish toshiaght dy loayrt reesht.

English: “Dinah'll miss me very much to-night, I should think!” (Dinah was the cat.)
Manx: “Gowee Dinah foddeeaght er my hon noght, er lhiam!” (She yn kayt va Dinah.)

English: “I hope they'll remember her saucer of milk at tea-time. Dinah, my dear, I wish you were down here with me!”
Manx: “Ta mee treishteil dy bee cooinaghtyn oc er e skaal dy vainney ec traa-tey. Dinah veen! Saillym dy row uss heese ayns shoh marym!”

English: There are no mice in the air, I’m afraid, but you might catch a bat, and that’s very like a mouse, you know.
Manx: Cha nel lughee syn aer, s’doogh lhiam, agh foddee dy voddagh oo tayrtyn craitnag, as ta shen kiart goll rish lugh, ta fys ayd.

English: But do cats eat bats, I wonder?
Manx: Agh vel ny kiyt gee ny craitnagyn, ta mee smooinaghtyn?”

English: And here Alice began to get rather sleepy, and went on saying to herself, in a dreamy sort of way,
Manx: As er-shen haink Ealish dy ve beggan cadlagh, as hie ee er as ish gra ree hene er aght ashlishagh,

English: “Do cats eat bats? Do cats eat bats?” and sometimes, “Do bats eat cats?”
Manx: “Vel ny kiyt gee ny craitnagyn? Vel ny kiyt gee ny craitnagyn?” as ny keayrtyn, “Vel ny craitnagyn gee ny kiyt?”

English: for, you see, as she couldn’t answer either question, it didn’t much matter which way she put it.
Manx: as, er y hon, t’ou toiggal, nagh dod ee cur ansoor da ny feyshtyn, by chummey yn feysht v’ee dy vriaght.

English: She felt that she was dozing off, and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah, and saying to her very earnestly, “Now, Dinah, tell me the truth: did you ever eat a bat?”
Manx: V’ee gennaghtyn myr dy beagh cadley cheet urree, as v'ee er ngoaill toshiaght dy ghreamal dy row ee shooyl laue ry laue marish Dinah, as dy row ee gra ree er aght feer jeean, “Nish, Dinah, insh dou yn ’irriney: dee uss craitnag rieau?”

English: when suddenly, thump! thump! down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall was over.
Manx: tra, dy doaltattym, polt! polt! sheese lhee er carnane dy vaidjyn as duillagyn chirrym, as cha row ee tuittym arragh.

English: Alice was not a bit hurt, and she jumped up in a moment. She looked up, but it was all dark overhead; before her was another long passage and the White Rabbit was still in sight, hurrying down it.
Manx: Cha row Ealish gortit noadyr, as lheim ee seose ny shassoo ayns tullagh: yeeagh ee seose, agh v’eh ooilley dorraghey erskyn eck: sheeyney magh roee va thiollane liauyr elley, as vaʼn Chonning Vane foast ry akin, as eshyn goll sheese dy bieau sy thiollane.

English: There was not a moment to be lost.
Manx: Cha row traa erbee ry yummal:

English: Away went Alice like the wind and was just in time to hear it say, as it turned a corner,
Manx: ersooyl lesh Ealish goll rish y gheay, as v’ee kiart abyl clashtyn eh gra, as eshyn goll mygeayrt corneil,

English: “Oh, my ears and whiskers, how late it's getting!" She was close behind it when she turned the corner, but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen.
Manx: “Ogh, my chleayshyn as robaigyn, s'anmagh t'eh gaase!" V'ee faggys da, ny chooyl, tra hie ee mygeayrt y chorneil, agh cha row y Chonning ry akin arragh:

English: she found herself in a long, low hall, which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof.
Manx: hug ee my ner dy row ee ayns halley injil, liauyr, va jeant gial liorish roa dy lostanyn va soiet ayns y chlea.

English: There were doors all round the hall, but they were all locked; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other, trying every door, she walked sadly down the middle, wondering how she was ever to get out again.
Manx: Va dorryssyn ooilley mygeayrt y halley, agh v'ad ooilley glast: as tra va Ealish er ngoll ooilley yn raad sheese er un cheu as seose yn cheu elley, as ish prowal gagh dorrys, hooill ee dy trimshagh sheese y vean, smooinaghtyn er aght erbee dy chosney magh ass dy bragh.

English: Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table, all made of solid glass; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key, and Alice’s first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall; but, alas! either the locks were too large, or the key was too small, but at any rate it would not open any of them.
Manx: Dy doaltattym, haink ee gys boayrd beg tree-chassagh, ooilley jeant ass gless stooalt: cha row veg er agh ogher vinniagagh airhey, as smooinee Ealish hoshiaght dy row shoh lesh nane jeh ny dorryssyn sy halley; agh, atreih! va ny glish ro vooar, ny va'n ogher ro veg, agh, aghterbee, cha voshlagh ee fer erbee jeu.

English: However, on the second time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!
Manx: Ny yei, er y nah hurrys, haink ee gys curtan injil nagh row ee er chur my ner roie. Cheu-heear jeh va dorrys beg va mysh queig oarlagh jeig er yrjid: phrow ee yn ogher veg airhey sy ghlass, as v'ee jeant feer wooiagh tra hie ee stiagh!

English: Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw.
Manx: Doshil Ealish y dorrys as hooar ee magh dy row raad ayns shen gys thiollane beg nagh row foddey ny smoo na towl-roddan: ghlioon ee sheese as yeeagh ee trooid y thiollane stiagh sy gharey s'aaley honnick oo rieau.

English: How she longed to get out of that dark hall, and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains, but she could not even get her head through the doorway; “and even if my head would go through,” thought poor Alice, “it would be of very little use without my shoulders.
Manx: S'mooar va’n foddeeaght urree dy scapail veih'n halley dorraghey shen as rouail mygeayrt trooid ny h-immraghyn shen dy vlaaghyn daahoil as ny farraneyn feayr shen, agh cha dod ee eer cur e kione trooid y dorrys; “as eer dy ragh my chione ny hrooid,” smooinee Ealish voght, “cha beagh eh feeu fegooish my gheayltyn.

English: Oh, how I wish I could shut up like a telescope! I think I could, if I only knew how to begin.”
Manx: Oh, dy row mee abyl dooney seose goll rish fodreayrtan! Er lhiam dy noddin, dy beagh fys aym er yn aght dy ghoaill toshiaght."

English: For, you see, so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible.
Manx: T’ou toiggal, va whilleen reddyn quaagh er daghyrt er y gherrit dy row Ealish smooinaght dy row reddyn va dy firrinagh neu-yantagh feer ghoan dy jarroo.

English: There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door, so she went back to the table, half hoping she might find another key on it, or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes: this time she found a little bottle on it, (“which certainly was not here before,” said Alice,) and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label, with the words “DRINK ME,” beautifully printed on it in large letters.
Manx: V’eh sheiltyn nagh row eh feeu dy ve fuirraghtyn ec y dorrys beg, as hie ee reesht gys y voayrd, as ish lieh-hreishteil dy voghe ee ogher elley er, foddee, er nonney, er y chooid sloo, lioar dy reillyn ry-hoi dooney sleih seose goll rish fodreayrtan: y keayrt shoh, hooar ee boteil veg er ("nagh row ayns shoh roie, son shickyrys," dooyrt Ealish), as kianlt mygeayrt y mysh mwannal y voteil va lipaid pabyrey as ny focklyn "IU MEE" clouit urree dy h-aalin ayns lettyryn mooarey.

English: It was all very well to say “Drink me,” but the wise little Alice was not going to do that in a hurry.
Manx: V'eh mie dy liooar dy ghra "Iu mee," agh cha row Ealish veg chreeney goll dy yannoo shen dy siyragh.

English: “No, I’ll look first,” she said, “and see whether it’s marked ‘poison’ or not”; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt, and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things, all because they would not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them:
Manx: “Cha jeanym, nee’m jeeaghyn hoshiaght,” dooyrt ee, “as jeeaghyn vel eh cowrit ‘nieu’ ny dyn”; myr v’ee er lhaih shiartanse dy skeealyn beggey jesh mychione paitchyn ren cheet dy ve loshtit, as eeit seose ec beishtyn oaldey, as reddyn neu-haitnyssagh elley, er y fa nagh dod ad freayll cooinaghtyn er ny reillyn neu-ghoillee va ny caarjyn oc er nynsaghey daue:

English: such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that if you cut your finger very deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that, if you drink much from a bottle marked “poison,” it is almost certain to disagree with you, sooner or later.
Manx: myr sampleyr, nee brod-yiarn jiarg-loshtee oo y lostey my t’ou goaill greim er ro foddey; as, my t’ou giarrey dty vair feer dowin lesh skynn, dy cliaghtagh t’ee lhiggey fuill; as cha row ee rieau er nyarrood, my t'ou giu ram veih boteil ta cowrit “nieu”, t’eh bunnys shickyr dy jean eh tuittym magh lhiat sy jerrey.

English: However, this bottle was not marked “poison,” so Alice ventured to taste it, and finding it very nice, (it had, in fact, a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast,) she very soon finished it off.
Manx: Agh cha row y voteil shoh cowrit “nieu”, as myr shen ventyr Ealish dy vlasstyn er, as, er y fa dy row eh feer jesh (dy jarroo, va sorch dy vlass mestit echey, goaill stiagh pie-shillish, custart, annane, kellagh frangagh rostit, taffee, as arran-greddan cheh as eeym er), d'ee ee seose eh feer tappee.

English: “What a curious feeling!” said Alice; “I must be shutting up like a telescope.”
Manx: “Cre’n ennaghtyn quaagh!” dooyrt Ealish. “Gyn ourys ta mee dooney seose goll rish fodreayrtan!”

English: And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden.
Manx: As, dy jarroo, shen myr v'eh: cha row ee agh jeih oarlagh er yrjid nish, as haink boggey er e h-eddin lesh y smooinaght dy row ee yn mooadys kiart dy gholl trooid y dorrys beg stiagh sy gharey aalin shen.

English: First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this; “for it might end, you know,” said Alice to herself, “in my going out altogether, like a candle. I wonder what I should be like then?”
Manx: Agh, hoshiaght, duirree ish shiartanse dy vinnidyn dy 'eddyn magh beagh ee cheet dy ve ny sloo foast: va beggan dy aggle urree roish shoh; “er y fa dy noddagh eh cheet gy kione, ta fys ayd,” dooyrt Ealish ree hene, “as mish goll er mooghey dy bollagh, goll rish cainle. Cre goll rish veigns eisht, ta mee smooinaghtyn?”

English: And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out, for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing.
Manx: As phrow ee dy heiltyn cre goll rish ta lossey y chainle erreish da'n chainle v'er sheidit magh, er yn oyr nagh dod ee cooinaghtyn dy vaik ee y lheid rieau.

English: After a while, finding that nothing more happened, she decided on going into the garden at once; but, alas for poor Alice!
Manx: Lurg tammylt, tra hooar ee magh nagh row veg elley taghyrt, smooinee ish dy ragh ee stiagh sy gharey er y chooyl; agh atreih, Ealish voght!

English: When she got to the door, she found she had forgotten the little golden key, and when she went back to the table for it, she found she could not possibly reach it:
Manx: Tra haink ee gys y dorrys, hooar ee magh dy row ee er nyarrood ogher veg y gharee, as tra haink ee reesht gys y voayrd dy gheddyn ee, cha dod ee geddyn ee noadyr:

English: she could see it quite plainly through the glass, and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table, but it was too slippery; and when she had tired herself out with trying, the poor little thing sat down and cried.
Manx: V’ee abyl fakin ee dy cronnal trooid y ghless, as ren ee e cooid share dy ghrappal seose nane jeh ny lurgaghyn jeh’n voayrd, agh v'eh ro shliawin; as tra v'ee jeant skee lesh yn eab, hoie y red beg sheese as huitt ee er keayney.

English: “Come, there’s no use in crying like that!” said Alice to herself, rather sharply; “I advise you to leave off this minute!”
Manx: “Trog ort, cha neeu eh y ve keayney myr shen!” dooyrt Ealish ree hene gear dy liooar. “Ta mee cur coyrle dhyt dy chur kione er nish!”

English: She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it), and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself, for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people.
Manx: V’ee cliaghtey cur coyrle vie jee hene (ga nagh row ee cur geill jee dy mennick), as ny keayrtyn ren ee troiddey ee hene cho olk as dy row eh cur jeiryn ayns e sooillyn; as keayrt dy row, va cooinaghtyn eck dy phrow ee bassag y chur da ny cleayshyn eck hene er y fa dy chloie ee branglash ayns gamman dy chroquet v'ee cloie ny lomarcan, er y hon dy row y paitchey quaagh shoh feer ghraihagh er lhiggey er dy row daa pheiagh aynjee.

English: “But it’s no use now,” thought poor Alice, “to pretend to be two people! Why, there’s hardly enough of me left to make one respectable person!”
Manx: “Agh cha neeu eh nish,” smooinee Ealish voght, “dy lhiggey er dy vel daa pheiagh aynym! Cammah, cha nod oo gra dy vel dy liooar jeem faagit dy yannoo un pheiagh ta feeu!”

English: Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table: she opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words “EAT ME” were beautifully marked in currants.
Manx: Dy gerrid, yeeagh ee er kishtey beg gless va ny lhie fo'n voayrd: doshil ee eh, as aynsyn hooar ee berreen feer veg as ny focklyn "EE MEE" screeut er dy h-aalin lesh curranyn.

English: “Well, I’ll eat it,” said Alice, “and if it makes me grow larger, I can reach the key; and if it makes me grow smaller, I can creep under the door; so either way I’ll get into the garden, and I don’t care which happens!”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, eeym eh,” dooyrt Ealish, “as my vees eh cur orrym gaase ny smoo, foddym roshtyn yn ogher; as my vees eh cur orrym gaase ny sloo, foddym snaue fo’n voayrd: myr shen, nee'm cosney stiagh sy gharey as s'cummey lhiams cre vees taghyrt!”

English: She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself, “Which way? Which way?”, holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing, and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size:
Manx: Dee ee minniag, as dooyrt ee dy h-imneagh ree hene “Cre’n raad? Cre’n raad?”, as ish cur laue er mullagh e kione dy ’eddyn cre’n raad v’ee gaase; as va yindys dy liooar urree feddyn magh dy hannee ee y mooadys cheddin.

English: to be sure, this generally happens when one eats cake, but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen, that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way.
Manx: Son shickyrys, shoh yn red ta cliaghtey taghyrt tra t’ou gee berreen; agh va Ealish er jeet dy ve cho cliaghtit rish jerkal rish taghyrtyn neu-chadjin as dy row eh sheiltyn dree as bolvaneagh dy liooar my va'n vea goll er er yn aght cadjin.

English: So she set to work, and very soon finished off the cake.
Manx: Myr shen, ghow ee yn obbyr ayns laue, as ayns tammylt beg va'n berreen eeit eck.

English: CHAPTER II.
Manx: CABDYL 2

English: The Pool of Tears
Manx: Y Dubbey dy Yeir

English: “Curiouser and curiouser!” cried Alice (she was so much surprised, thatfor the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English); “now I’m opening out like the largest telescope that ever was! Good-bye, feet!”

English: (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off).
Manx: (tra yeeagh ee sheese er e cassyn, v’ad sheiltyn dy ve ass shilley, bunnys, v’ad cheet dy ve cho foddey ersooyl).

English: “Oh, my poor little feet, I wonder who will put on your shoes and stockings for you now, dears?
Manx: “Ogh, my chassyn beggey boghtey, quoi vees cur miu ny braagyn as oashyryn son euish nish, ta mee smooinaghtyn, veen?

English: I’m sure I shan’t be able! I shall be a great deal too far off to trouble myself about you: you must manage the best way you can; but I must be kind to them,” thought Alice, “or perhaps they won’t walk the way I want to go!
Manx: Ta mee shickyr nagh beem’s abyl shen y yannoo! Bee'm ro foddey ersooyl dy ve boirit my-nyn-gione: shegin diu jannoo chammah as jee, ghow ee toshiaght dy ghra lesh coraa injil, faitagh, “My oddys shiu - agh shegin dou ve kenjal roo,” smooinee Ealish, “er nonney foddee nagh jean ad shooyl yn raad ta mish laccal goll!

English: Let me see: I’ll give them a new pair of boots every Christmas.”
Manx: Lhig dou smooinaghtyn. Verym piyr noa dy vootsyn daue gagh Nollick.”

English: And she went on planning to herself how she would manage it. “They must go by the carrier,” she thought; “and how funny it’ll seem, sending presents to one’s own feet! And how odd the directions will look!
Manx: As ren ee goll er reaghey ree hene yn aght veagh ee jannoo eh. “Shegin da ’n ymmyrkagh cur lesh ad,” smooinee ish; “as nagh bee shen sheiltyn y ve aitt, dy ve cur giootyn da ny cassyn ayd hene! As nagh bee yn enmys jeeaghyn quaagh!

English: Alice’s Right Foot, Esq.,
Manx: Cass Yesh Ealish, Ooasle,

English: Hearthrug,
Manx: Breshag-chiollee,

English: near the Fender,

English: (with Alice’s love).

Manx: Atreih, cre’n boghtynid ta mee taggloo!”

English: Just then her head struck against the roof of the hall: in fact she was now more than nine feet high, and she at once took up the little golden key and hurried off to the garden door.
Manx: Kiart ec y traa shoh, woaill e kione noi clea yn halley: dy jarroo, v'ee beggan ny smoo na nuy trie er yrjid nish, as dy chelleeragh ghow ee yn ogher veg airhey as ersooyl lhee gys dorrys y gharee.

English: Poor Alice! It was as much as she could do, lying down on one side, to look through into the garden with one eye; but to get through was more hopeless than ever: she sat down and began to cry again.
Manx: Ealish voght! V'eh ooilley v'ee abyl jannoo, as ish ny lhie er un lhiattee, dy yeeaghyn stiagh sy gharey lesh un tooill; agh dy chosney trooid, va shen ny smoo fardailagh na v'eh rieau: hoie ee sheese as ghow ee toshiaght dy cheayney reesht.

English: “You ought to be ashamed of yourself,” said Alice, “a great girl like you,” (she might well say this), “to go on crying in this way! Stop this moment, I tell you!”
Manx: “Lhisagh oo goaill nearey jeed hene,” dooyrt Ealish, “inneen vooar goll rhyt hene,” (v’ee kiart dy ghra shen) “as uss goll er keayney myr shoh! Cur stap nishtagh, ta mish dy ghra!”

English: But she went on all the same, shedding gallons of tears, until there was a large pool all round her, about four inches deep and reaching half down the hall.
Manx: Agh, ny yeih, ren ee goll er, ceau galloonyn dy yeir, gys va dubbey mooar mygeayrt y mooee, mysh kiare oarlagh er diunid, as sheeyney lieh-raad sheese y halley.

English: After a time she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming.
Manx: Lurg tammylt, cheayll ee clabberaght veg jeh cassyn sy foddeeaght, as hirmee ee e sooillyn dy siyragh dy ’akin cre va cheet.

English: It was the White Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed, with a pair of white kid gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other: he came trotting along in a great hurry, muttering to himself as he came,
Manx: She y Chonning Vane va cheet reesht, va coamrit dy stoamey, as piyr dy laueanyn-mannan baney ayns un laue as feayragan mooar sy laue elley: v’eh troytal feer tappee, as, myr v’eh cheet, v’eh tallaghey rish hene,

English: “Oh! the Duchess, the Duchess! Oh! won’t she be savage if I’ve kept her waiting!”
Manx: “Oh! Y Vendiuic, y Vendiuic! Nagh bee ish oaldey my ta mee er chur urree fuirraghtyn!”

Manx: Va Ealish gennaghtyn cho debejagh as dy row ee arryltagh shirrey cooney voish peiagh erbee: myr shen, tra haink y Chonning faggys jee, ghow ee toshiaght dy ghra lesh coraa injil, faitagh, “My sailliu, Vainstyr –“

English: The Rabbit started violently, dropped the white kid gloves and the fan, and skurried away into the darkness as hard as he could go.
Manx: Ren y Chonning clistal dy raghtal, lhig eh da ny laueanyn-mannan baney as da'n feayragan tuittym, as ren eh siyraghey ersooyl sy dorraghys cho tappee as v'eh abyl.

English: Alice took up the fan and gloves, and, as the hall was very hot, she kept fanning herself all the time she went on talking: “Dear, dear! How queer everything is to-day! And yesterday things went on just as usual. I wonder if I’ve been changed in the night?
Manx: Ghow Ealish greim er y feayragan as ny laueanyn, as, er y fa dy row eh feer cheh sy halley, v'ee fasney ee hene ooilley'n traa v'ee loayrt. "Graih veen! Nagh vel dy chooilley red quaagh jiu! As jea va reddyn goll er myr dy cliaghtagh. Row mee caghlaait syn oie, ta mee smooinaghtyn?

English: Let me think: was I the same when I got up this morning? I almost think I can remember feeling a little different. But if I’m not the same, the next question is, Who in the world am I? Ah, that’s the great puzzle!”
Manx: Lhig dou smooinaghtyn: row mish y peiagh cheddin tra hrog mee orrym moghrey jiu? Ta mee bunnys credjal dy vel mee cooinaghtyn dy row anchaslys beg aynym. Agh mannagh vel mee y peiagh cheddin, shoh y nah feysht: Quoi sy teihll ta mish?  She, shen y feysht vooar!”

English: And she began thinking over all the children she knew that were of the same age as herself, to see if she could have been changed for any of them.
Manx: As ghow ee toshiaght dy smooinaghtyn er ooilley ny paitchyn as enney eck orroo va yn eash cheddin as ee hene, dy ’eddyn magh noddagh fer erbee jeu ve currit ayns e h-ynnyd.

English: “I’m sure I’m not Ada,” she said, “for her hair goes in such long ringlets, and mine doesn’t go in ringlets at all; and I’m sure I can’t be Mabel, for I know all sorts of things, and she, oh! she knows such a very little!
Manx: “Ta mee shickyr nagh nee Ada mish,” dooyrt ee, “er y fa dy vel kiogyn liauyrey ayns e folt, as cha nel kiogyn erbee sy folt ayms; as ta mee shickyr nagh nee Mabel mish, er y fa dy vel fys ayms er dy chooilley horch dy red, as s’beg ta’n fys ecksh er red erbee!

English: Besides, she’s she, and I’m I, and—oh dear, how puzzling it all is!
Manx: Red elley, she ish ish, as she mish mish, as — atreih, nagh vel y clane chooish cho keishtagh!

English: I’ll try if I know all the things I used to know.

Manx: Lhig dou smooinaghtyn: kiare keayrtyn queig, shen ghaa-yeig, as kiare keayrtyn shey, shen tree-jeig, as kiare keayrtyn shiaght, shen — atreih! Cha jeanym dy bragh roshtyn feed er yn aght shen!

English: However, the Multiplication Table doesn’t signify: let’s try Geography.

English: I’ll try and say ‘How doth the little —’” and she crossed her hands on her lap as if she were saying lessons, and began to repeat it, but her voice sounded hoarse and strange, and the words did not come the same as they used to do:—

English: Her first idea was that she had somehow fallen into the sea, “and in that case I can go back by railway,” she said to herself.
Manx: Hoshiaght, heill ee dy row ee er duittym stiagh sy cheayn er aght ennagh, “as sy chooish shen, foddym goll back er y traen,” dooyrt ee ree hene.

English: (Alice had been to the seaside once in her life, and had come to the general conclusion, that wherever you go to on the English coast you find a number of bathing machines in the sea, some children digging in the sand with wooden spades, then a row of lodging houses, and behind them a railway station.)
Manx: (Va Ealish er chur shilley er oirr ny marrey un cheayrt sy vea eck, as, liorish shen, v’ee shickyr, boayl erbee er oirr ny marrey, dy voghe oo shiartanse dy ghreieyn-faarkee sy cheayn, paart dy phaitchyn veagh reurey sy ghenniagh lesh kiebbaghyn fuyghagh, eisht roa dy hieyn aaght, as cheu-heear jeu shid, stashoon traen.)

English: However, she soon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.
Manx: Aghterbee, hooar ee magh dy gerrid dy row ee sy dubbey dy yeir va jeant eck tra v'ee nuy trie er yrjid.

English: “I wish I hadn’t cried so much!” said Alice, as she swam about, trying to find her way out.
Manx: “Saillym nagh row mee er cheayney cho wheesh as shen!” dooyrt Ealish myr v’ee snaue mygeayrt, as ish prowal feddyn raad magh.

English: “I shall be punished for it now, I suppose, by being drowned in my own tears! That will be a queer thing, to be sure! However, everything is queer to-day.”
Manx: “Bee’m kerrit er e hon nish, ta mee sheiltyn, liorish goll er baih ayns ny jeir aym pene! Bee shen ny red quaagh, gyn ourys! Aghterbee, ta dy chooilley red quaagh jiu.”

English: Just then she heard something splashing about in the pool a little way off, and she swam nearer to make out what it was: at first she thought it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had slipped in like herself.
Manx: Eisht cheayll ee red ennagh va skeolley sy dubbey faggys dy liooar jee, as snaue ee ny sniessey da dy ’eddyn magh c’red v’eh: hoshiaght, smooinee ish dy beagh eh ny choo-marrey ny cabbyl-awin, agh eisht va cooinaghtyn eck dy row eh feer veg, as dy gerrid hoig ee dy nee lugh v'ayn, skyrr stiagh goll ree hene.

English: “Would it be of any use, now,” thought Alice, “to speak to this mouse?
Manx: “Beagh eh feeu nish,” smooinee Ealish, “dy loayrt rish y lugh shoh?

English: Everything is so out-of-the-way down here, that I should think very likely it can talk: at any rate, there’s no harm in trying.”
Manx: Ta gagh red neu-chadjin heese ayns shoh, as er y hon shen, veigns smooinaghtyn dy vel eh feer liklee dy vod ee loayrt: aghterbee, cha jean eh assee dy phrowal."

English: So she began: “O Mouse, do you know the way out of this pool?
Manx: Myr shen, ghow ee toshiaght: “Y Lugh, nhione dhyt y raad ass y dubbey shoh?

English: I am very tired of swimming about here, O Mouse!”
Manx: Ta mee feer skee liorish snaue ayns shoh, Y Lugh!”

English: (Alice thought this must be the right way of speaking to a mouse: she had never done such a thing before, but she remembered having seen in her brother’s Latin Grammar,
Manx: (Heill Ealish dy beagh shoh yn aght kiart dy loayrt rish lugh: cha row ee rieau er nyannoo y lheid roie, agh va cooinaghtyn eck dy vaik ee, ayns Grammeydys Ladjyn e braar,

English: “A mouse — of a mouse — to a mouse — a mouse — O mouse!”) The Mouse looked at her rather inquisitively, and seemed to her to wink with one of its little eyes, but it said nothing.
Manx: “Lugh — jeh lugh — da lugh — lugh Y lugh!”) Yeeagh y lugh urree er aght va beggan scrialtagh, as heill ee dy veek y lugh lesh nane jeh e sooillyn mooarey, agh cha dooyrt ee veg.

English: “Perhaps it doesn’t understand English,” thought Alice; “I daresay it’s a French mouse, come over with William the Conqueror.”
Manx: “Foddee nagh vel ee toiggal Gailck,” smooinee Ealish, “Yiarrins dy nee lugh Frangagh t’ayn, haink harrish marish Illiam ny Barriaght.”

English: (For, with all her knowledge of history, Alice had no very clear notion how long ago anything had happened.)
Manx: (Ga dy row shennaghys dy liooar eck, cha row eie cronnal ec Ealish cre cho foddey er dy henney va red erbee er daghyrt.)

English: So she began again: “Où est ma chatte?”
Manx: Myr shen, ghow ee toshiaght reesht: “Ou est ma chatte?”

English: Which was the first sentence in her French lesson-book.
Manx: Va shoh y chied raa sy lioar Frangish eck.

English: The Mouse gave a sudden leap out of the water, and seemed to quiver all over with fright.
Manx: Dy doaltattym, lheim y Lugh magh ass yn ushtey as v’eh jeeaghyn dy row ee er craa lesh aggle.

English: “Oh, I beg your pardon!” cried Alice hastily, afraid that she had hurt the poor animal’s feelings. “I quite forgot you didn’t like cats.”
Manx: “Oh, gow my leshtal,” dyllee Ealish dy siyragh, as ish goaill aggle dy row ee er chur yn olk er y chretoor boght. “Yarrood mee dy bollagh nagh mie lhiat ny kiyt.”

English: “Not like cats!” cried the Mouse, in a shrill, passionate voice. “Would you like cats if you were me?”
Manx: “Nagh mie lhiams ny kiyt!” dyllee y Lugh lesh coraa ard, fergagh. “Beagh uss graihagh er ny kiyt dy beagh uss mish?”

English: “Well, perhaps not,” said Alice in a soothing tone: “don’t be angry about it. And yet I wish I could show you our cat Dinah:
Manx: “Dy jarroo, foddee nagh beigns,” dooyrt Ealish lesh coraa blandeyragh: “ny bee corree my e chione. As ny yeih, saillym dy noddin jeeaghyn y kayt ain Dinah dhyt.

English: I think you’d take a fancy to cats if you could only see her. She is such a dear quiet thing,” Alice went on, half to herself, as she swam lazily about in the pool, “and she sits purring so nicely by the fire, licking her paws and washing her face—and she is such a nice soft thing to nurse—and she’s such a capital one for catching mice—oh, I beg your pardon!” cried Alice again, for this time the Mouse was bristling all over, and she felt certain it must be really offended.
Manx: Ta mee sheiltyn dy beagh oo graihagh er ny kiyt, dy noddagh oo fakin ee. T'ee ny red ennoil as kiune," hie Ealish er, ree hene, bunnys, as ish snaue dy litcheragh sy dubbey, “as t’ee cliaghtey soie cronnaney cho jesh ec y chiollagh, shliee e maaigyn as nhiee e h-eddin - as t’ee ny red bog jesh dy nuiddragh - as t’ee tayrtyn lughee cho aashagh - oh, gow my leshtal!” dyllee Ealish reesht, er y fa dy daink caulg er y Lugh, as v’ee shickyr dy row frioggan mooar urree.

English: “We won’t talk about her any more if you’d rather not.”
Manx: “Cha jeanmayd loayrt my e kione ny smoo, my share lhiat.”

English: “We indeed!” cried the Mouse, who was trembling down to the end of his tail. “As if I would talk on such a subject!
Manx: “Cha jeanmayd dy jarroo!” dyllee y Lugh, va er craa sheese dys kione e famman. “Myr dy beigns eer taggloo mysh y lheid!

English: Our family always hated cats: nasty, low, vulgar things! Don’t let me hear the name again!”
Manx: Va’n lught-thie ain kinjagh cur feoh da ny kiyt: reddyn eajee, injil, cadjin! Ny lhig dou clashtyn yn ennym reesht!”

English: “I won’t indeed!” said Alice, in a great hurry to change the subject of conversation. “Are you — are you fond of — of dogs?”
Manx: “Cha jeanym dy jarroo!” dooyrt Ealish as driss mooar urree dy chaghlaa cooish y choloayrtys. “Vel oo — vel oo graihagh er ny moddee?”

English: The Mouse did not answer, so Alice went on eagerly:
Manx: Cha dreggyr y Lugh, as myr shen ren Ealish goll er dy jeean:

English: “There is such a nice little dog near our house I should like to show you!
Manx: “Ta moddey beg feer jesh faggys da’n thie ain, by vie lhiam jeeaghyn eh dhyt!

English: A little bright-eyed terrier, you know, with oh, such long curly brown hair!
Manx: Terree beg as sooillyn lonragh echey, ta fys ayd, as oh, fynney dhone cho liauyr as casagagh!

English: And it’ll fetch things when you throw them, and it’ll sit up and beg for its dinner, and all sorts of things — I can’t remember half of them — and it belongs to a farmer, you know, and he says it’s so useful, it’s worth a hundred pounds!
Manx: As nee eh cur lesh reddyn tra t'ou ceau ad, as nee eh soie seose dy hirrey e yinnair, as dy chooilley horch dy red — cha noddym cooinaghtyn er lieh jeu — as t’eh lesh eirinagh, ta fys ayd, as ta eshyn gra dy vel eh cho ymmydoil as dy vel eh feeu keead punt!

English: He says it kills all the rats and—oh dear!” cried Alice in a sorrowful tone,
Manx: T'eh gra dy vel eh marroo ooilley ny roddanyn as - atreih!" dyllee Ealish dy trimshagh,

English: “I’m afraid I’ve offended it again!”
Manx: “S’doogh dy vel mee er chur yn olk urree reesht!”

English: For the Mouse was swimming away from her as hard as it could go, and making quite a commotion in the pool as it went.
Manx: Va’n Lugh snaue ersooyl voee cho lajer as oddagh ee, as jannoo musthaa dy liooar as ish gimmeeaght.

English: So she called softly after it, “Mouse dear! Do come back again, and we won’t talk about cats or dogs either, if you don’t like them!”
Manx: Er y hon shen, dyllee ee dy meeley ny lurg, “Lugh veen! Tar erash reesht, as cha jeanmayd taggloo mychione kiyt ny moddee noadyr, mannagh mie lhiat ad!”

English: When the Mouse heard this, it turned round and swam slowly back to her: its face was quite pale (with passion, Alice thought), and it said in a low trembling voice, “Let us get to the shore, and then I’ll tell you my history, and you’ll understand why it is I hate cats and dogs.”
Manx: Tra cheayll y Lugh shoh, hyndaa ee mygeayrt as snaue ee erash huic dy moal: v'ee bane-eddinagh dy liooar (v’ee jiarg chorree, smooinee Ealish), as dooyrt ee, ayns coraa injil va er craa, “Lhig dooin goll gys y traie, as inshym dhyt my skeeal, as toiggee oo yn oyr dy vel mee cur feoh da kiyt as moddee.”

English: It was high time to go, for the pool was getting quite crowded with the birds and animals that had fallen into it: there were a Duck and a Dodo, a Lory and an Eaglet, and several other curious creatures. Alice led the way, and the whole party swam to the shore.
Manx: Son shickyrys, v'eh traa dy gholl, er y fa dy row y dubbey cheet dy ve lane dy liooar kyndagh rish ny h-ushagyn as beiyn va er duittym stiagh ayn: va Thunnag as Dodo ayns shen, Loree as Eean-urley, as shiartanse dy chretooryn elley. Leeid Ealish, as snaue y clane cheshaght gys y traie.

English: CHAPTER III.
Manx: CABDYL 3

English: A Caucus-Race and a Long Tale
Manx: Ratch-kaakys as Skeeal Liauyr

English: They were indeed a queer-looking party that assembled on the bank—the birds with draggled feathers, the animals with their fur clinging close to them, and all dripping wet, cross, and uncomfortable.
Manx: Dy jarroo, she sheshaght whaagh ren chaglym er y vroogh - ny h-ushagyn as fedjagyn dragagh oc, ny beiyn as y fynney oc lhiantyn feer faggys daue, as gagh nane jeu fliugh baiht, corree as mee-gherjoilagh.

English: The first question of course was, how to get dry again: they had a consultation about this, and after a few minutes it seemed quite natural to Alice to find herself talking familiarly with them, as if she had known them all her life.
Manx: Y chied feysht, dy dooghyssagh, va shen cre'n aght dy heet dy ve çhirrym reesht: va co-choyrle eddyr oc mysh shoh, as lurg minnid ny ghaa, va Ealish coontey eh dooghyssagh dy liooar dy ve loayrt roo er aght caarjoil, myr dy beagh enney er ve eck orroo car e bea.

English: Indeed, she had quite a long argument with the Lory, who at last turned sulky, and would only say, “I am older than you, and must know better;”
Manx: Dy jarroo, huitt ee magh rish traa dy liooar lesh y Loree, ren cheet dy ve pooitchagh as nagh nyiarragh agh “Ta mish ny shinney na uss as shegin fys share ve aym.”

English: and this Alice would not allow without knowing how old it was, and, as the Lory positively refused to tell its age, there was no more to be said.
Manx: As cha lhiggagh Ealish da shoh, gyn fys y ve eck er eash y Loree, as, er y fa dy dob eh dy bollagh dy ghra cre cho shenn as v'eh, cha row veg elley dy ghra.

English: At last the Mouse, who seemed to be a person of authority among them, called out, “Sit down, all of you, and listen to me! I’ll soon make you dry enough!”
Manx: Sy jerrey, ren y Lugh, va jeeaghyn goll rish peiagh as eaghtyrys echey ny mast'oc, yllagh magh “Soie-jee sheese shiuish ooilley, as eaisht-jee rhyms! Verym erriu dy ve chirrym tappee dy liooar!

English: They all sat down at once, in a large ring, with the Mouse in the middle.
Manx: Hoie ad sheese dy çhelleeragh, ayns kiarkyl mooar as y Lugh sy vean.

English: Alice kept her eyes anxiously fixed on it, for she felt sure she would catch a bad cold if she did not get dry very soon.
Manx: Dreill Ealish e sooillyn urree dy h-imneagh, er yn oyr dy row ee shickyr dy darragh mughane agglagh urree mannagh beagh ee cheet dy ve chirrym feer tappee.

English: “Ahem!” said the Mouse with an important air, “are you all ready?
Manx: “Ahem!” dooyrt y Lugh as y cummey jeh scansh vooar urree. “Vel shiu ooilley aarloo?

English: This is the driest thing I know. Silence all round, if you please!
Manx: Shoh y red s’chirmey ta fys aym er. Tostid, ta mee guee erriu!

English: ‘William the Conqueror, whose cause was favoured by the pope, was soon submitted to by the English, who wanted leaders, and had been of late much accustomed to usurpation and conquest. Edwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria—’”
Manx: ‘Illiam ny Barriaght, va’n chooish echey feddyn foayr veih'n phaab, v’eh dy gerrid geddyn biallys veih ny Sostnee, va shirrey fir-toshee as va er jeet dy ve cliaghtit rish cass er bolg er y gherrit. Edwin as Morcar, ny h-eearlaghyn jeh Mercia as Northumbria —"

English: “Ugh!” said the Lory, with a shiver.
Manx: “Ugh!” dooyrt y Loree as eshyn bibbernee.

English: “I beg your pardon!” said the Mouse, frowning, but very politely: “Did you speak?”
Manx: “Gow my leshtal!” dooyrt Y Lugh as eshyn grouigey, agh feer chooyrtoil. “Dooyrt oo veg?”

English: “Not I!” said the Lory hastily.
Manx: "Cha dooyrt!" dooyrt Y Loree dy siyragh.

English: “I thought you did,” said the Mouse. “I proceed.
Manx: “Heill mee dy dooyrt,” dooyrt y Lugh. “Gowym er.

English: ‘Edwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria, declared for him: and even Stigand, the patriotic archbishop of Canterbury, found it advisable’”
Manx: ‘Edwin as Morcar, ny h-eearlaghyn jeh Mercia as Northumbria, hoilshee ad magh dy row ad ayns foayr jeh; as eer Stigand, yn ardaspick cheer- ghraihagh jeh Canterbury, hooar eshyn magh dy row eh creeney’”

English: “Found what?” said the Duck.
Manx: “Hooar eshyn c'red?” dooyrt y Thunnag.

English: “Found it,” the Mouse replied rather crossly: “of course you know what ‘it’ means.”
Manx: “Hooar eshyn eh,” dreggyr y Lugh er aght va corree dy liooar: “son shickyrys, t’ou toiggal eh mie dy liooar.”

English: “I know what ‘it’ means well enough, when _I_ find a thing,” said the Duck: “it’s generally a frog or a worm.
Manx: “Ta mee toiggal ‘eh’ mie dy liooar tra ta mee feddyn red," dooyrt y Thunnag: “dy cliaghtagh, she rannag ny dhiane t’ayn.

English: The question is, what did the archbishop find?”
Manx: Shoh yn feysht: cre hooar yn ardaspick?”

English: The Mouse did not notice this question, but hurriedly went on, “He found it advisable to go with Edgar Atheling to meet William and offer him the crown.
Manx: Cha dug y Lugh geill da’n ’eysht shoh, agh hie eh er dy siyragh, “hooar eshyn magh dy row eh creeney goll marish Edgar Atheling dy veeiteil rish Illiam as dy arral yn attey da.

English: William’s conduct at first was moderate.
Manx: Hoshiaght, va Illiam gaghtey eh hene dy castreycair.

English: But the insolence of his Normans—’ How are you getting on now, my dear?” it continued, turning to Alice as it spoke.
Manx: Agh y sonnaase jeh ny Normanee echey — ‘Cre’n aght t’ou goll er nish, veen?” ghow eh er as eshyn çhyndaa eh hene gys Ealish myr v’ee loayrt.

English: “As wet as ever,” said Alice in a melancholy tone: “it doesn’t seem to dry me at all.”
Manx: “Cho fliugh as rieau,” dooyrt Ealish lesh coraa trimshagh: “cha nel eh jeeaghyn dy vel eh çhirmaghey mee noadyr.”

English: “In that case,” said the Dodo solemnly, rising to its feet, “I move that the meeting adjourn, for the immediate adoption of more energetic remedies—”
Manx: “Kyndagh rish shen,” dooyrt y Dodo dy trome as eshyn girree ny hassoo, “ta mish cur roish dy bee yn çhaglym currit ry lhiattee ry hoi goaill ayns laue dy çhelleeragh feayslaghyn smoo breeoil —"

English: “Speak English!” said the Eaglet.
Manx: “Loayr Gailck!” dooyrt yn Eean-urley.

English: “I don’t know the meaning of half those long words, and, what’s more, I don’t believe you do either!”
Manx: “Cha nel mee toiggal lieh jeh ny focklyn liauyrey shen, as ny smoo na shen, cha nel mee credjal dy vel uss toiggal ad noadyr!”

English: And the Eaglet bent down its head to hide a smile: some of the other birds tittered audibly.
Manx: As chroym yn Eean-urley e chione sheese dy cheiltyn dy row eh mongey: va’n gigleragh jeh shiartanse jeh ny h-ushagyn elley ry chlashtyn.

English: “What I was going to say,” said the Dodo in an offended tone, “was, that the best thing to get us dry would be a Caucus-race.”
Manx: “Ny va foym gra,” dooyrt y Dodo as frioggan er, “dy bare dooin chirmaghey shin hene lesh Ratch-kaakys.”

English: “What is a Caucus-race?” said Alice; not that she wanted much to know, but the Dodo had paused as if it thought that somebody ought to speak, and no one else seemed inclined to say anything.
Manx: “Cre ta Ratch-kaakys?” dooyrt Ealish; dy firrinagh, cha row ee laccal feddyn magh, agh va'n Dodo er scuirr myr dy beagh eh smooinaghtyn dy lhisagh peiagh ennagh gra red ennagh, as cha row beoyn er peiagh ennagh elley gra red erbee.

English: “Why,” said the Dodo, “the best way to explain it is to do it.”
Manx: “Cammah,” dooyrt y Dodo, “yn aght share dy hoilshaghey magh eh, shen dy yannoo eh.”

English: (And, as you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, I will tell you how the Dodo managed it.)
Manx: (As, er y fa dy by vie lhiats prowal y red dhyt hene laa-geuree ennagh, foddee, inshym dhyt cre'n aght v’eh jeant ec y Dodo.)

English: First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, (“the exact shape doesn’t matter,” it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there.
Manx: Hoshiaght, chowree eh magh coorse-ratch, ayns sorch dy chiarkyl, (“ta’n cummey kiart jeh beggan scansh,” dooyrt eh) as eisht va ooilley yn çheshaght currit rish y choorse, ayns shoh as ayns shid.

English: There was no “One, two, three, and away,” but they began running when they liked, and left off when they liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over.
Manx: Cha row “Nane, jees, tree as ersooyl!” ry chlashtyn, agh ghow ad toshiaght dy roie tra by vie lhieu, as dy scuirr tra by vie lhieu.

English: However,when they had been running half an hour or so, and were quite dry again, the Dodo suddenly called out “The race is over!” and they all crowded round it, panting, and asking, “But who has won?”
Manx: Aghterbee, tra v’ad er roie rish lieh oor ny myr shen, as v'ad çhirrym dy liooar reesht, dyllee y Dodo dy doaltattym “Ta’n ratch harrish!”, as ying ad ooilley stiagh er as ad pandoogh, as fenaght “Agh quoi hooar y varriaght?”

English: This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought, and it sat for a long time with one finger pressed upon its forehead (the position in which you usually see Shakespeare, in the pictures of him), while the rest waited in silence.
Manx: Cha dod y Dodo cur freggyrt rish y feysht gyn smooinaghtyn dowin, as v'eh ny hassoo rish traa liauyr as un vair currit dy trome noi e ghlaare-eddin (yn aght t’ou cliaghtey fakin Shakespeare, ayns ny jallooyn jeh), choud’s va ny fir elley fuirraghtyn ayns tostid.

English: At last the Dodo said, “Everybody has won, and all must have prizes.”
Manx: Fy yerrey dooyrt y Dodo “Ta dy chooilley pheiagh er ngeddyn y varriaght, as shegin da dy chooilley pheiagh geddyn aundyr.”

English: “But who is to give the prizes?” quite a chorus of voices asked.
Manx: “Agh quoi vees cur ny aundyryn?” vrie coraaghyn dy liooar ry cheilley.

English: “Why, she, of course,” said the Dodo, pointing to Alice with one finger; and the whole party at once crowded round her, calling out in a confused way, “Prizes! Prizes!”
Manx: “Cammah, ish, son shickyrys,” dooyrt y Dodo as eshyn cowraghey magh Ealish lesh un vair; as dy chelleeragh, ying y clane cheshaght stiagh urree, as adsyn gyllagh magh er aght fud y cheilley, “Aundyryn! Aundyryn!”

English: Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand in her pocket, and pulled out a box of comfits, (luckily the salt water had not got into it), and handed them round as prizes.
Manx: Cha row fys erbee ec Ealish c’red dy yannoo, as dy mee-hreishteilagh hug ee e laue stiagh sy phoggaid eck as hayrn ee magh kishteig veg dy villjanyn (dy aighoil, cha row yn ushtey sailjey er chosney stiagh orroo), as heeyn ee ad mygeayrt myr aundyryn.

English: There was exactly one a-piece, all round.
Manx: Va gagh red kiart: va nane y pheesh.

English: “But she must have a prize herself, you know,” said the Mouse.
Manx: “Agh shegin jee geddyn aundyr jee hene, ta fys ayd,” dooyrt y Lugh.

English: “Of course,” the Dodo replied very gravely. “What else have you got in your pocket?” he went on, turning to Alice.
Manx: “Son shickyrys,” dreggyr y Dodo feer hrome-chooishagh. “C’red elley t’ayd ayns dty phoggaid?” ren eh goll er as eshyn chyndaa gys Ealish.

English: “Only a thimble,” said Alice sadly.
Manx: “Mairane, shen ooilley,” dooyrt Ealish dy trimshagh.

English: “Hand it over here,” said the Dodo.
Manx: “Cur eh dou,” dooyrt y Dodo.

English: Then they all crowded round her once more, while the Dodo solemnly presented the thimble, saying “We beg your acceptance of this elegant thimble;” and, when it had finished this short speech, they all cheered.
Manx: Eisht ying ad ooilley mygeayrt y mooee, choud’s va’n Dodo chebbal y mairane dy trome-chooishagh, as eshyn gra “Ta shin guee dy jean shiu y mairane stoamey shoh y ghoaill”; as, tra va’n loayrtys beg shoh jeant echey, dyllee ad ooilley ouwatta.

English: Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she could.
Manx: Va Ealish coontey y slane red y ve ommidjagh, agh v’ad ooilley jeeaghyn cho jeean as nagh b'loys jee gearey; as, er yn oyr nagh dod ee smooinaghtyn er red erbee dy ghra, cha ren ee agh croymmey sheese, as ghow ee y mairane, jeeaghyn cho trome-chooishagh as oddagh ee.

English: The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back.
Manx: Y nah red, va shen dy ee ny milljanyn: kyndagh rish shoh, va feiyr as corvaal dy liooar currit er y hoshiaght, myr va ny h-ushaghyn mooarey gaccan nagh dod ad blaystey ny fir ocsyn, as va ny fir veggey goll er plooghey as beign bassagyn ve currit daue er ny dreeymyn oc.

English: However, it was over at last, and they sat down again in a ring, and begged the Mouse to tell them something more.
Manx: Aghterbee, v’eh harrish fy yerrey, as hoie ad sheese reesht ayns kiarkyl, as ghuee ad er y Lugh dy insh red ennagh elley daue.

English: “You promised to tell me your history, you know,” said Alice, “and why it is you hate — C and D,” she added in a whisper, half afraid that it would be offended again.
Manx: "Yiall oo dy ninshagh oo dou dty hennaghys, ta fys ayd," dooyrt Ealish, "as cre'n fa t'ou cur feoh da ny — K as M," dooyrt ee ec y jerrey, myr sannish, as ish lieh agglit dy beagh yn olk currit urree reeshtagh.

English: “Mine is a long and a sad tale!” said the Mouse, turning to Alice, and sighing.
Manx: “Cammah, ta’n skeeal aym liauyr as trimshagh!” dooyrt y Lugh, as ish chyndaa gys Ealish as gosnaghey.

English: [The word ‘cammah’ made Ealish think about ‘famman’ (tale).][1]
Manx: Hug y fockle “cammah” er Ealish smooinaghtyn er “famman”.
Notes: [1] This sentence appears in the Manx version to aid the narrative.

English: “It is a long tail, certainly,” said Alice, looking down with wonder at the Mouse’s tail; “but why do you call it sad?”
Manx: “She famman liauyr t’ayn, son shickyrys,” dooyrt Ealish, as ish goaill yindys jeh famman ny Lugh; “agh cre'n fa t’ou gra trimshagh rish?”

English: And she kept on puzzling about it while the Mouse was speaking, so that her idea of the tale was something like this:—
Manx: As v’ee boirey er choud’s va’n Lugh loayrt, as myr shen v’ee coontey yn skeeal y ve myr shoh syn aigney eck: —

English: “Fury said to a mouse, That he met in the house, ‘Let us both go to law: I will prosecute you. Come, I’ll take no denial;
Manx: “Dooyrt Eulys rish lugh, veeit eh rish tra v’eh fliugh, ‘Hooin roin gys y leigh: neeym shual dy creoi — cha neaishtym rish obbal:

English: We must have a trial: For really this morning I’ve nothing to do.’
Manx: Sy chooyrt beemayd chebbal; son jiu ta’n traa lhag.’

English: Said the mouse to the cur, ‘Such a trial, dear sir, With no jury or judge, would be wasting our breath.’
Manx: Dooyrt y lugh rish y choo, ‘Fegooish bing, fegooish briw, beemayd milley shin hene, veigns gra, ghooinney veen.’

English: ‘I’ll be judge, I’ll be jury,’ Said cunning old Fury: ‘I’ll try the whole cause, and condemn you to death.’”
Manx: ‘Bee’m y briw as y ving,’ dooyrt Eulys dy bing, ‘Cha noddym ve faase, bee uss deyrit gy baase.’”

English: “You are not attending!” said the Mouse to Alice severely. “What are you thinking of?”
Manx: “Cha nel oo cur geill!” dooyrt y Lugh rish Ealish dy creoi. “Cre t’ou smooinaghtyn er?”

English: “I beg your pardon,” said Alice very humbly: “you had got to the fifth bend, I think?”
Manx: “Gow my leshtal,” dooyrt Ealish feer imlee: “va shiu er roshtyn y wheigoo loobey, er lhiam?”

English: “I had not!” cried the Mouse, sharply and very angrily.
Manx: “Cha row! Cre'n cront t'ayns dty aigney?” dyllee y Lugh dy sharroo as dy corree.

English: “A knot!” said Alice, always ready to make herself useful, and looking anxiously about her. “Oh, do let me help to undo it!”
Manx: “Cront!” dooyrt Ealish, va kinjagh aarloo dy yannoo red erbee ymmydoil. As ish jeeaghyn dy h-imneagh mygeayrt y mooee, dooyrt ee “Oh, lhig dou cooney lhiu dy ’eaysley eh!”

English: “I shall do nothing of the sort,” said the Mouse, getting up and walking away. “You insult me by talking such nonsense!”
Manx: “Cha jeanym y lheid,” dooyrt y Lugh, ren irree ny shassoo as shooyl ersooyl. “T’ou cur oltooan dou lesh lheid y voghtynid shen!”

English: “I didn’t mean it!” pleaded poor Alice. “But you’re so easily offended, you know!”
Manx: “Cha row eh foym jannoo shen!” ghuee Ealish voght. “Agh t’eh feer aashagh dy chur yn olk erriu, ta fys eu!”.

English: The Mouse only growled in reply.
Manx: Cha ren y Lugh agh scryssey myr freggyrt.

English: “Please come back and finish your story!”
Manx: My sailliu, tar-jee erash as cur-jee kione er y skeeal eu!"

English: Alice called after it; and the others all joined in chorus, “Yes, please do!” but the Mouse only shook its head impatiently, and walked a little quicker.
Manx: dyllee Ealish ny lurg. As dyllee ooilley ny fir elley ry cheilley “Tar-jee, my sailliu!” Agh ren y Lugh agh craa e kione dy mee-hurransagh, as hooill ee beggan ny s’tappee.

English: “What a pity it wouldn’t stay!” sighed the Lory, as soon as it was quite out of sight;
Manx: “S’bastagh nagh jinnagh ee tannaghtyn!” dosnee y Loree, cho leah’s v’ee slane ass shilley.

English: and an old Crab took the opportunity of saying to her daughter “Ah, my dear! Let this be a lesson to you never to lose your temper!”
Manx: As ghow shenn Phartan y caa dy ghra rish e h-inneen “Ogh, veen! Lhig da shoh ve myr lessoon dhyt gyn dty happey y choayl dy bragh!”

English: “Hold your tongue, Ma!” said the young Crab, a little snappishly.
Manx: “Cum dty hengey, Vummig!” dooyrt y Partan aeg, beggan sneggagh.

English: “You’re enough to try the patience of an oyster!”
Manx: “Oddagh uss brishey yn meenid jeh ooastyr!”

English: “I wish I had our Dinah here, I know I do!” said Alice aloud, addressing nobody in particular.
Manx: “Saillym dy row yn Dinah ain ayns shoh ta mish dy ghra!” dooyrt Ealish er ard, nagh row loayrt rish peiagh erbee er lheh.

English: “She’d soon fetch it back!”
Manx: “Yinnagh ish cur ee erash lhee dy bieau!”

English: “And who is Dinah, if I might venture to ask the question?” said the Lory.
Manx: “As quoi Dinah, my ta mee cho dunnal as dy vriaght shen?" dooyrt y Loree.

English: Alice replied eagerly, for she was always ready to talk about her pet: “Dinah’s our cat.
Manx: Dreggyr Ealish dy jeean, er y fa dy row ee kinjagh ullee dy haggloo mychione e biggin: “She y kayt ain Dinah.

English: And she’s such a capital one for catching mice you can’t think!
Manx: As t’ee mie mirrilagh son tayrtyn ny lughee, cha nod oo credjal eh!

English: And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds!
Manx: As ogh, saillym dy noddagh oo fakin ee as ish geiyrt er ny h-ushagyn!

English: Why, she’ll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!”
Manx: Cammah, eeagh ee ushag veg cho leah’s jeeaghyn urree!”

English: This speech caused a remarkable sensation among the party.
Manx: Hug yn oraid shoh yindys ass towse er y çheshaght.

English: Some of the birds hurried off at once: one old Magpie began wrapping itself up very carefully, remarking,
Manx: Ren paart jeh ny h-ushagyn siyraghey ersooyl dy çhelleeragh: ghow un chenn Phieanat toshiaght dy chur eaddagh mysh hene feer chiarailagh, as eshyn gra

English: “I really must be getting home; the night-air doesn’t suit my throat!”
Manx: “Son shickyrys, shegin dou goll dy valley: cha nel aer ny hoie cooie da my scoarnagh!”

English: And a Canary called out in a trembling voice to its children, “Come away, my dears! It’s high time you were all in bed!”
Manx: As dyllee Canaaree magh rish e paitchyn lesh coraa er craa, “Tar-shiu ersooyl, phaitchyn veen! T'eh tayrn dys traa ny lhiabbagh!”

English: On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.
Manx: Va leshtal ennagh jeant ec gagh nane jeu as hie ad ersooyl, as dy gerrid va Ealish faagit ny lomarcan.

English: “I wish I hadn’t mentioned Dinah!” she said to herself in a melancholy tone.
Manx: “Saillym nagh row mee er nimraa Dinah!” dooyrt ee ree hene dy trimshagh.

English: “Nobody seems to like her, down here, and I’m sure she’s the best cat in the world! Oh, my dear Dinah!
Manx: “Cha nel eh jeeaghyn dy vel peiagh erbee graihagh urree heese ayns shoh, as ta mish shickyr dy nee ish y kayt share sy teihll! Ogh, y Dinah veen ayms!

English: I wonder if I shall ever see you any more!”
Manx: Foddee nagh vaikym ee arragh!”

English: And here poor Alice began to cry again, for she felt very lonely and low-spirited.
Manx: As eisht huitt Ealish voght er keayney reesht, er y fa dy row ee gennaghtyn feer fadaneagh as lhag-chreeagh.

English: In a little while, however, she again heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming back to finish his story.
Manx: Agh ayns tammylt beg cheayll ee clabberaght veg jeh maaigyn sy foddeeaght, as yeeagh ee seose dy jeean, lieh-hreishteil dy row y Lugh er chaghlaa yn aigney eck, as v'ee cheet erash dy chur kione er e skeeal.

English: CHAPTER IV.
Manx: CABDYL 4

English: The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill
Manx: Ta'n Chonning Cur Stiagh Illiam Beg

English: It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard it muttering to itself “The Duchess!
Manx: She y Chonning Vane v’ayn, va troytal erash reesht dy moal, as eshyn jeeaghyn mygeayrt y mysh dy h-imneagh myr v'eh goll, myr dy beagh red ennagh caillt echey; as cheayll ee eh loayrt dy h-injil rish hene, “Y Vendiuic!

English: The Duchess! Oh my dear paws! Oh my fur and whiskers! She’ll get me executed, as sure as ferrets are ferrets!
Manx: Y Vendiuic! Ogh my vaaigyn veen! Ogh y fynney as ny robaigyn aym! Bee’m currit gy baase eck, cho shickyr as dy vel ferradyn nyn verradyn!

English: Where can I have dropped them, I wonder?”
Manx: C’raad oddins er lhiggey daue tuittym, ta mee smooinaghtyn?”

English: Alice guessed in a moment that it was looking for the fan and the pair of white kid gloves, and she very good-naturedly began hunting about for them, but they were nowhere to be seen
Manx: Heill Ealish ayns grig dy row eh shirrey y feayragan as y piyr dy laueanyn-mannan baney, as dy doaieagh ghow ee toshiaght dy hirrey ad, agh cha row ad ry akin boayl erbee

English: — everything seemed to have changed since her swim in the pool, and the great hall, with the glass table and the little door, had vanished completely.
Manx: — v’eh jeeaghyn dy row dy chooilley nhee caghlaait neayr’s y traa v’ee snaue sy dubbey; as y halley mooar, lesh y voayrd-gless as y dorrys beg, v’ad er skellal roish dy bollagh.

English: Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice, as she went hunting about, and called out to her in an angry tone, “Why, Mary Ann, what are you doing out here? Run home this moment, and fetch me a pair of gloves and a fan! Quick, now!” And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once in the direction it pointed to, without trying to explain the mistake it had made.
Manx: Feer leah, hug y Chonning Ealish my ner, myr v'ee shirrey noon as noal, as dyllee eh magh ree lesh coraa corree, "Cammah, Voirrey Ann, cre sy teihll t'ou uss jannoo mooie ayns shoh? Roie dy valley dy çhelleeragh as cur lhiat dou piyr dy laueanyn as feayragan!" As va Ealish wheesh agglit as dy roie ee dy chelleeragh syn ard v'eh jeeaghyn jee, gyn prowal dy ’eaysley yn marran va jeant echey.

English: “     He took me for his housemaid,” she said to herself as she ran.
Manx: “Heill eh dy row mish yn inney-veyl echey,” dooyrt ee ree hene as ish roie.

English: “How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am! But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.”
Manx: “Nagh bee yindys er tra vees eh feddyn magh quoi mish hene! Agh bare dou cur lhiam huggey y feayragan as ny laueanyn echey - ta shen dy ghra, my ’oddym feddyn ad.”

English: As she said this, she came upon a neat little house, on the door of which was a bright brass plate with the name “W. RABBIT,” engraved upon it.
Manx: Myr dooyrt ee shoh, haink ee gys thie beg skeoigh, as er dorrys y thie va plait prashey gial as yn ennym “I. CONNING” grainnit er.

English: She went in without knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves.
Manx: Hie ee stiagh fegooish crankal, as hiyree ee seose ny greeishyn, er aggle dy jinnagh ee meeiteil rish y Voirrey Ann firrinagh as dy beagh ee ceaut magh ass y thie roish my dooar ee y feayragan as ny laueanyn.

English: “How queer it seems,” Alice said to herself, “to be going messages for a rabbit!
Manx: “Nagh quaagh t’eh sheiltyn,” dooyrt Ealish ree hene, “dy ve jannoo chaghteraghtyn da conning!

English: I suppose Dinah’ll be sending me on messages next!”
Manx: Ta mee sheiltyn dy bee Dinah cur orrym jannoo chaghteraghtyn jeeish lurg shoh!”

English: And she began fancying the sort of thing that would happen:
Manx: Ghow Ealish toshiaght dy smooinaghtyn er y torch dy red haghyragh:

English: “‘Miss Alice! Come here directly, and get ready for your walk!’
Manx: “Inneen Ealish! Tar dys shoh nish, as jean uss hene aarloo son dty hooyl!’

English: ‘Coming in a minute, nurse! But I’ve got to see that the mouse doesn’t get out.’
Manx: ‘Ta mee cheet ayns minnid, voandyr! Agh shegin dou freayll rick er y towl-lugh shoh gys hig Dinah erash, as jeeaghyn dou hene nagh jean y lugh cosney magh ass.’

English: Only I don’t think,” Alice went on, “that they’d let Dinah stop in the house if it began ordering people about like that!”
Manx: Agh cha nel mee sheiltyn,” hie Ealish er, “dy lhiggagh ad da Dinah tannaghtyn sy thie dy jinnagh ee goaill toshiaght dy chur oardaghyn da sleih myrshen!”

English: By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves:
Manx: Ec y traa shoh, v’ee er ngeddyn y raad stiagh ayns shamyr veg skeoigh as boayrd syn uinnag, as er y voayrd (myr v'ee treishteil), va feayragan as ghaa ny tree piyryn dy laueanyn-mannan baney minniagagh:

English: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass.
Manx: ghow ee greim er y feayragan as piyr dy laueanyn, as v'ee er chee faagail y shamyr tra hug ee my ner boteil veg va ny shassoo faggys da'n ghless-huarystal.

English: There was no label this time with the words “DRINK ME,” but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it to her lips.
Manx: Y keayrt shoh, cha row lipaid ayn as ny fockleyn "IU MEE” urree, agh ny yeih shen, ghow ee yn eairkey ass as hug ish ee da ny meillyn eck.

English: “I know something interesting is sure to happen,” she said to herself, “whenever I eat or drink anything; so I’ll just see what this bottle does.
Manx: “Ta fys aym dy vel eh shickyr dy jean red ennagh taghyrt,” dooyrt ee ree hene, “traa erbee ta mee gee ny giu red erbee: myr shen, yiowym magh cre vees jeant ec y voteil shoh.

English: I do hope it’ll make me grow large again, for really I’m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!”
Manx: Ta treisht aym dy der eh orrym gaase mooar reesht er y fa dy vel mee slane skee as mish my red beg minniagagh!”

English: It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken.
Manx: Ren eh shen dy jarroo, as foddey ny s'leaie na v'ee jerkal: roish my row ee er niu lieh voteil, hooar ee dy row e kione traastey noi'n far-woalley, as beign j’ee croymmey sheese dy haghney mwannal brisht.

English: She hastily put down the bottle, saying to herself “That’s quite enough — I hope I shan’t grow any more — As it is, I can’t get out at the door — I do wish I hadn’t drunk quite so much!”
Manx: Hug ee sheese y voteil dy tappee as ish gra ree hene “S’liooar shen — ta mee treishteil nagh naaseym ny smoo — Ec y traa t'ayn, cha noddym goll trooid y dorrys — saillym nagh row wheesh iut aym!”

English: Alas! it was too late to wish that! She went on growing, and growing, and very soon had to kneel down on the floor: in another minute there was not even room for this, and she tried the effect of lying down with one elbow against the door, and the other arm curled round her head.
Manx: Atreih! V’eh ro anmagh dy ghuee shen! V’ee gaase as gaase, as feer leah, beign jee gliooney sheese er y laare: ayns minnid elley, cha row reamys eer son shen, as phrow ish lhie sheese as un uillin noi’n dorrys, as y roih elley mygeayrt y mysh e kione.

English: Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out of the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself “Now I can do no more, whatever happens. What will become of me?”
Manx: V’ee gaase foast, as, myr eab jerrinagh, hug ee un roih magh ass yn uinnag, as un chass seose y chimlee, as dooyrt ee ree hene “Nish cha noddym jannoo ny smoo, cre erbee vees taghyrt. Cre’n erree hig orrym?”

English: Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy.
Manx: Va Ealish aighoil: cha row ny smoo bree faagit sy voteil veg obbee, as cha daase ee ny smoo: ny yeih, v'eh feer vee-gherjoilagh, as, myr v'eh jeeaghyn nagh row caa erbee eck scapail veih'n chamyr reesht dy bragh, cha nhyrrys dy row trimshey urree.

English: “It was much pleasanter at home,” thought poor Alice, “when one wasn’t always growing larger and smaller, and being ordered about by mice and rabbits.
Manx: “V’eh foddey ny s’taitnyssee ec y thie,” smooinee Ealish voght, “raad nagh row uss kinjagh gaase ny smoo as ny sloo, as goll er oardaghey liorish lughee as conneeyn.

English: I almost wish I hadn’t gone down that rabbit-hole —and yet — and yet — it’s rather curious, you know, this sort of life!
Manx: Ta mee bunnys guee nagh row mee er ngoll sheese y towl-conning shen — as foast — as foast — t’eh quaagh dy liooar, ta fys ayd, y sorch shoh dy vea!

English: I do wonder what can have happened to me!
Manx: Cre sy teihll ta er jeet orrym, ta mee smooinaghtyn!

English: When I used to read fairy-tales, I fancied that kind of thing never happened, and now here I am in the middle of one!
Manx: Tra va mee lhaih skeealyn-ferrish, heill mee nagh ren y lheid rieau taghyrt, as nish shoh mee hene sy vean jeh skeeal-ferrish!

English: There ought to be a book written about me, that there ought! And when I grow up, I’ll write one — but I’m grown up now,” she added in a sorrowful tone; “at least there’s no room to grow up any more here.”
Manx: Dy jarroo, lhisagh lioar ve scruit my my chione! As tra vees mee aasit, screeuym nane — agh ta mee aasit nish,” as dooyrt ee lesh coraa treih: “er y chooid sloo, cha nel reamys ayns shoh dy aase ny smoo.”

English: “But then,” thought Alice, “shall I never get any older than I am now?
