Manx: “Agh eisht,” smooinee Ealish, “nagh jigym dy ve ny shinney na ta mish ec y traa t'ayn?

English: That’ll be a comfort, one way—never to be an old woman — but then — always to have lessons to learn!
Manx: Bee shen mie, er aght ennagh — dyn y ve my henn ven dy bragh — agh eisht — lessoonyn ayms son dy bragh ry ynsaghey!

English: Oh, I shouldn’t like that!”
Manx: Ogh, cha beigns graihagh er shen!”

English: “Oh, you foolish Alice!” she answered herself.
Manx: “Ealish ommidjagh!” hug ee freggyrt jee hene.

English: “How can you learn lessons in here?
Manx: “Cre'n aght oddys oo jannoo lessoonyn ayns shoh?

English: Why, there’s hardly room for _you_, and no room at all for any lesson-books!”
Manx: Cammah, s’goan y reamys dhyt hene, as cha nel reamys erbee da lioaryn-lessoon!”

English: And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.
Manx: As v’ee goll er myr shen, gra yn derrey yeh as yn jeh elley, as jannoo coloayrtys mie dy liooar jeh; agh lurg shiartanse dy vinnidyn, cheayll ee coraa cheu-mooie, as scuirr ee dy eaishtagh.

English: “Mary Ann! Mary Ann!” said the voice. “Fetch me my gloves this moment!”
Manx: “Voirrey Ann! Voirrey Ann!” dooyrt y coraa. “Cur lhiat dou my laueanyn dy chelleeragh!”

English: Then came a little pattering of feet on the stairs.
Manx: Eisht va clabberaght veg jeh maaigyn er ny greeishyn.

English: Alice knew it was the Rabbit coming to look for her, and she trembled till she shook the house, quite forgetting that she was now about a thousand times as large as the Rabbit, and had no reason to be afraid of it.
Manx: Va fys ec Ealish dy row shen y Chonning va er jeet dy hirrey ee, as v’ee goll er craa gys va'n thie goll er craa, as ish jarrood dy row ee nish red goll rish thousane keayrt cho mooar as y Chonning, as cha row oyr erbee eck dy ghoaill aggle roish.

English: Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as the door opened inwards, and Alice’s elbow was pressed hard against it, that attempt proved a failure.
Manx: Dy gerrid, haink y Chonning gys y dorrys, as phrow eh dy ’osley eh; agh, er y fa dy row y dorrys fosley stiagh, as va uillin Ealish traastey dy trome noi echey, ren yn eab shen failleil.

English: Alice heard it say to itself “Then I’ll go round and get in at the window.”
Manx: Cheayll Ealish dy dooyrt eh rish hene “Hem mygeayrt as neeym cosney stiagh ec yn uinnag.”

English: “That you won’t!” thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her hand, and made a snatch in the air.
Manx: “Cha jean!” smooinee Ealish, as, erreish jee v'er fuirraghtyn gys heill ee dy geayll ee y Chonning kiart fo'n uinnag, dy doaltattym heeyn ee magh e laue, as ghreim ee er yn aer.

English: She did not get hold of anything, but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass, from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.
Manx: Cha dooar ee greim er red erbee, agh cheayll ee screeagh beg as red ennagh tuittym, as polt dy ghless vrisht, as veih shen hoig ee dy row eh jantagh dy row eh er duittym stiagh ayns frame-cucowr, ny red ennagh myr shen.

English: Next came an angry voice—the Rabbit’s —“Pat! Pat! Where are you?” And then a voice she had never heard before, “Sure then I’m here!
Manx: Eisht va coraa corree ry chlashtyn — coraa y Chonning — “Pat! Pat! C'raad t'ou er ve?” As eisht coraa nagh geayll ee roie, “Son shickyrys ta mee ayns shoh!

English: Digging for apples, yer honour!”
Manx: Cleiy ooyllyn, ghooinney ooasle!”

English: “Digging for apples, indeed!” said the Rabbit angrily.
Manx: “Cleiy ooyllyn, dy jarroo!” dooyrt y Chonning dy corree.

English: “Here! Come and help me out of this!” (Sounds of more broken glass.)
Manx: “Dys shoh! Tar as coon lhiam dy scapail veih shoh!” (Sheeanyn jeh tooilley gless vrisht.)

English: “Now tell me, Pat, what’s that in the window?”
Manx: “Insh dou nish, Pat, cre shen syn uinnag?”

English: “Sure, it’s an arm, yer honour!” (He pronounced it “arrum.”)
Manx: “Son shickyrys, she roih t’ayn, ghooinney ooasle!”

English: “An arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole
Manx: “Roih, ommidan! Quoi ren rieau fakin nane cho mooar as shen? Cammah, t’eh lhieeney y clane uinnag!”

English: window!”
“Sure, it does, yer honour: but it’s an arm for all that.”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, ta, ghooinney ooasle: agh she roih t’ayn, ny yeih shen as ooilley.”

English: “Well, it’s got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!”
Manx: “Cha lhisagh eh ve ayns shoh noadyr: gow as cur lhiat ersooyl eh!”

English: There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, “Sure, I don’t like it, yer honour, at all, at all!”
Manx: Va tostid liauyr lurg shoh, as cha dod Ealish clashtyn agh sannishyn nish as reesht, goll rish, “Son shickyrys, cha mie lhiam eh, ghooinney ooasle, er chor erbee!”

English: “Do as I tell you, you coward!” and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air.
Manx: “Jean myr ta mee gra rhyt, aggleydagh!”, as fy yerrey, heeyn ee e laue magh reesht, as ghreim ee syn aer reesht.

English: This time there were two little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. “What a number of cucumber-frames there must be!” thought Alice.
Manx: Y keayrt shoh, va daa screeagh beg, as tooilley sheeanyn jeh gless vrisht. “Ta frameyn-cucowr ass towse ayns shen!” smooinee Ealish.

English: “I wonder what they’ll do next! As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they could! I’m sure I don’t want to stay in here any longer!”
Manx: “Cre nee ad nish, ta mee sheiltyn! Dy row ad abyl tayrn mish ass yn uinnag! Ta mee lane shickyr nagh naillym tannaghtyn ayns shoh ny sodjey!”

English: She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices all talking together: she made out the words: “Where’s the other ladder?
Manx: Duirree ish tammylt gyn clashtyn red erbee ny smoo: fy yerrey, cheayll ee tharmaneaghey jeh queeylyn beggey ec cairt, as y sheean jeh coraaghyn dy liooar va ooilley loayrt ry cheilley: hoig ee ny focklyn: “C’raad ta’n aarey elley?

English: Why, I hadn’t to bring but one; Bill’s got the other Bill! fetch it here, lad! — Here, put ’em up at this corner — No, tie ’em together first — they don’t reach half high enough yet — Oh! they’ll do well enough; don’t be particular —
Manx: Cammah, cha beign dou cur lhiam agh nane. Ta'n fer elley ec Illiam - Illiam! Cur lhiat eh dys shoh, ghuilley! — Shoh, cur ad seose ec y chorneil shoh - Cha nel, kiangle ad ry cheilley hoshiaght — cha nel ad roshtyn lieh ard dy liooar foast — Ogh, bee ad mie dy liooar. Ny bee mynchooishagh —

English: Here, Bill! catch hold of this rope — Will the roof bear? — Mind that loose slate —
Manx: Shoh, Illiam! Gow greim er y tead shoh - jean y chlea gymmyrkey eh? - Cur twoaie da'n leac shen —

English: Oh, it’s coming down! Heads below!” (a loud crash) —“Now, who did that? — It was Bill, I fancy —
Manx: Ogh, t’eh cheet neose! Sheese lhiu!” (polt mooar) – “Nish, quoi ren shen? Illiam, ta mee sheiltyn —

English: Who’s to go down the chimney? — Nay, I shan’t! You do it! —That I won’t, then! — Bill’s to go down—
Manx: Quoi vees goll sheese y chimlee? - Cha jeanyms! Uss vees jannoo eh! — Cha bee eh jeant ayms noadyr —

English: Here, Bill! the master says you’re to go down the chimney!”
Manx: Shen eh, Illiam! Ta'n mainstyr gra dy vel oo eginit goll sheese y çhimlee!”

English: “Oh! So Bill’s got to come down the chimney, has he?” said Alice to herself.
Manx: “Dy jarroo! Ta Illiam eginit cheet neose sy chimlee, vel?” dooyrt Ealish ree hene.

English: “Shy, they seem to put everything upon Bill!
Manx: “Cammah, t'eh jeeaghyn dy vel ad cur er Illiam jannoo gagh red!

English: I wouldn’t be in Bill’s place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but I think I can kick a little!”
Manx: Cha beigns ayns ynnyd Illiam son dellal mie: ta'n chiollagh shoh coon, son shickyrys; agh er lhiam dy noddym brebbal beggan!”

English: She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn’t guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself “This is Bill,” she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next.
Manx: Hayrn ee e cass cho foddey sheese y chimlee as v'ee abyl, as duirree ish gys cheayll ee baagh beg (cha dod ee cur cheb er gra cre'n sorch v'ayn) as eh scrabey as clamey mygeayrt sy chimlee ayns boayl faggys jee as erskyn eck: eisht, dooyrt ee ree hene “Shoh Illiam,” hug ee un vreb niartal, as duirree ish dy 'eddyn magh cre haghyragh lurg shen.

English: The first thing she heard was a general chorus of “There goes Bill!” then the Rabbit’s voice along — “Catch him, you by the hedge!” then silence, and then another confusion of voices —
Manx: Y chied red cheayll ee, va shen coraaghyn gyllagh magh ry cheilley “Shen Illiam goll seose!" eisht coraa y Chonning ny lomarcan —

English: “Hold up his head —Brandy now — Don’t choke him — How was it, old fellow? What happened to you? Tell us all about it!”
Manx: “Gow greim er, uss faggys da’n chleigh!" eisht tostid, as eisht corvaal elley dy choraaghyn — “Trog seose e chione - Brandee nish — Ny ploogh eh — Cre’n aght v’eh, henn charrey? Insh dooin ooilley my e chione?"

English: Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, (“That’s Bill,” thought Alice,) “Well, I hardly know—No more, thank ye; I’m better now—but I’m a deal too flustered to tell you—all I know is, something comes at me like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!”
Manx: Ec y jerrey, va coraa beg, faase, jeestyrnee ry chlashtyn (“Shen Illiam,” smooinee Ealish), “Dy jarroo, s’goan y fys ayms — S’liooar shen, gura mie eu; ta mee ny share nish - agh ta mee fud y cheilley dy kiart, as cha noddym ginsh diu - ooilley ta mee toiggal, shen dy daink red ennagh noi aym goll rish Jack-ayns-kishtey, as seose lhiam goll rish roggad!"

English: “So you did, old fellow!” said the others.
Manx: “Shen y red ren taghyrt!” dooyrt ny fir elley.

English: “We must burn the house down!” said the Rabbit’s voice; and Alice called out as loud as she could, “If you do, I’ll set Dinah at you!”
Manx: “Shegin dooin lostey sheese y thie!” dooyrt coraa ny Conning. As dyllee Ealish magh, cho niartal as dod ee, “My nee shiu shen, neeym soiaghey Dinah erriu!”

English: There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, “I wonder what they will do next! If they had any sense, they’d take the roof off.” After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and Alice heard the Rabbit say, “A barrowful will do, to begin with.”
Manx: Haink tostid dowin dy chelleeragh, as smooinee Ealish ree hene "Cre nee ad nish, ta mee sheiltyn! Dy beagh keeayl erbee oc, ghoghe ad y chlea jeh'n thie." Lurg minnid ny ghaa, ghow ad toshiaght gleashaghey mygeayrt reesht, as cheayll Ealish y Chonning as eshyn gra “Nee lane barrey jannoo, dy ghoaill toshiaght.”

English: “A barrowful of what?” thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt, for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the window, and some of them hit her in the face.
Manx: “Barrey lane dy c’red?” smooinee Ealish. Agh cha row monney traa eck dy smooinaghtyn: ayns grig, haink frass beg dy vynchlaghyn ren clabbarey stiagh ec yn uinnag, as woaill paart jeu ish syn eddin.

English: “I’ll put a stop to this,” she said to herself, and shouted out, “You’d better not do that again!” which produced another dead silence.
Manx: “Verym jerrey er shoh,” dooyrt ee ree hene, as dyllee ee magh, “Bare diu dyn jannoo shen reesht!”, as va tostid dowin elley ayn.

English: Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her head.
Manx: Hug Ealish my ner, as yindys dy liooar urree, dy row ooilley ny mynchlaghyn cheet dy ve nyn merreenyn beggey, nyn lhie er y laare, as haink eie mie stiagh ayns e kione. "

English: “If I eat one of these cakes,” she thought, “it’s sure to make some change in my size; and as it can’t possibly make me larger, it must make me smaller, I suppose.”
Manx: “My eeym nane jeh ny berreenyn shoh,” smooinee ish “t’eh shickyr dy bee eh caghlaa my vooadys er aght ennagh; as, er y fa nagh vod eh cur orrym ve ny smoo, shegin da cur orrym ve ny sloo, ta mee sheiltyn.”

English: So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly.
Manx: Er y hon shen, ’lug ee nane jeh ny berreenyn, as v'ee jeant feer wooiagh dy ’eddyn magh dy ghow ee toshiaght dy chelleeragh dy gholl er cribbey.

English: As soon as she was small enough to get through the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting outside.
Manx: Cho leah’s v’ee beg dy liooar dy chosney trooid y dorrys, roie ee magh ass y thie, as hooar ee chionnal dy veiyn as ushagyn fuirraghtyn cheu-mooie.

English: The poor little Lizard, Bill, was in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it something out of a bottle.
Manx: Y Jiolgan Leaghyr beg boght, Illiam, v’eshyn sy vean, as eshyn cummit seose liorish daa vuc rangagh, va cur red ennagh da ass boteil.

English: They all made a rush at Alice the moment she appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself safe in a thick wood.
Manx: Hiyree ad gys Ealish cho leah's haink ee ree; agh roie ee ersooyl cho tappee as dod ee, as dy gerrid v'ee sauchey ayns keyll gloo.

English: “The first thing I’ve got to do,” said Alice to herself, as she wandered about in the wood, “is to grow to my right size again; and the second thing is to find my way into that lovely garden.
Manx: “Y chied red shegin dou jannoo,” dooyrt Ealish ree hene as ish rouail sy cheyll, “shen gaase gys my vooadys kiart reesht; as y nah red, shen feddyn y raad stiagh sy gharey aalin shen.

English: I think that will be the best plan.”
Manx: Ta mee sheiltyn dy bee shen y plan share.”

English: It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry.
Manx: V’eh sheeanal goll rish plan mie er bashtal, gyn ourys, as reaghit feer jesh as aashagh: yn ynrican doilleeid bentyn rish, cha row yn eie sloo eck cre’n aght dy ghoaill eh ayns laue; as, choud as v’ee speeikey dy h-imneagh mastey ny biljyn, ren gounstyrnee beg gear kiart erskyn e kione cur urree jeeaghyn seose dy siyragh.

English: An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes, and feebly stretching out one paw, trying to touch her.
Manx: Va quallian gloutagh jeeaghyn neose urree lesh sooillyn mooarey cruinn, as, sheeyney magh un vaaig dy faase, v’eh prowal dy ventyn ree.

English: “Poor little thing!” said Alice, in a coaxing tone, and she tried hard to whistle to it; but she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be hungry, in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of all her coaxing.
Manx: “Y red beg boght!” dooyrt Ealish lesh coraa cleaynagh, as phrow ee dy niartal dy ’eddanagh huggey; agh v’ee goaill aggle atchimagh car y traa dy row accrys er, foddee, as er y hon shen dy beagh eh liklee dy neeagh eh seose ee, ga dy row ee shirrey cleayney y quallian.

English: Hardly knowing what she did, she picked up a little bit of stick, and held it out to the puppy; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off all its feet at once, with a yelp of delight, and rushed at the stick, and made believe to worry it;
Manx: Cha row fys kiart eck cre ren ee, agh ghow ee greim er maidjey beg, as heeyn ee magh eh gys y whallian: er shen, daag ooilley ny maaigyn jeh'n whallian y thalloo ec yn un cheayrt as eh lheim seose lesh screeagh dy ard-voggey, as hiyree eh gys y vaidjey, as lhig eh er dy row eh soie er:,

English: then Alice dodged behind a great thistle, to keep herself from being run over; and the moment she appeared on the other side, the puppy made another rush at the stick, and tumbled head over heels in its hurry to get hold of it;
Manx: eisht hug Ealish ee hene cheu-heear jeh onnane mooar dy tappee, dy haghney ish y ve bwoaillt sheese;as, cho leah’s haink ee ree er y cheu elley, roie y quallian dy tappee gys y vaidjey reesht, as huitt eh gour e ching sy driss dy gheddyn greim er:

English: then Alice, thinking it was very like having a game of play with a cart-horse, and expecting every moment to be trampled under its feet, ran round the thistle again; then the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick, running a very little way forwards each time and a long way back, and barking hoarsely all the while, till at last it sat down a good way off, panting, with its tongue hanging out of its mouth, and its great eyes half shut.
Manx: eisht, roie Ealish mygeayrt y mysh yn onnane reesht, as ish coontey eh y ve kiart goll rish gamman marish cabbyl mooar, raad v'ee smooinaghtyn gagh minnid dy beagh ee sthampit fo ny hingnyn echey: eisht ghow y quallian toshiaght dy roie reesht as reesht noi'n vaidjey, roie raad feer veg er e hoshiaght gagh keayrt as raad feer liauyr ergooyl, as eh gounstyrnee dy peeaghaneagh car y traa, gys, fy yerrey, hoie eh sheese foddey dy liooar ersooyl, as eh pandoogh, lesh e hengey cheet magh ass e veeal as e hooillyn mooarey lieh dooint.

English: This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape; so she set off at once, and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath, and till the puppy’s bark sounded quite faint in the distance.
Manx: Heill Ealish dy row shoh ny chaa mie dy scapail: myr shen, hie ee roee dy çhelleeragh, as ren ee roie derrey v'ee skee dy liooar as ass ennal, as va gounstyrnee y whallian sheeanal faase dy liooar sy foddid.

English: “And yet what a dear little puppy it was!” said Alice, as she leant against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the leaves:
Manx: “As ny yeih, cre’n quallian beg meen v’ayn!” dooyrt Ealish, as ish lieh-lhie er cass fannag dy ghoaill fea, as fasney ee hene lesh nane jeh ny duillagyn.

English: “I should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if—if I’d only been the right size to do it! Oh dear! I’d nearly forgotten that I’ve got to grow up again!
Manx: “By vie lhiam dy mooar gynsaghey clickyn da, dy — dy beigns y mooadys kiart shen y yannoo! Atreih! Va mee er nyarrood, bunnys, dy nhegin dou gaase reesht!

English: Let me see — how is it to be managed? I suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great question is, what?”
Manx: Lhig dou jeeaghyn, cre’n aght vees eh jeant? Ta mee sheiltyn dy lhisins ee ny iu red ennagh; agh shoh yn feysht mooar, ‘C’red?’”

English: The great question certainly was, what?
Manx: Dy jarroo, she C’red? va’n feysht mooar.

English: Alice looked all round her at the flowers and the blades of grass, but she did not see anything that looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances.
Manx: Yeeagh Ealish ooilley mygeayrt y mooee er ny blaaghyn as ny hoashyryn dy ’aiyr, agh cha dod ee fakin red erbee va jeeaghyn goll rish y red kiart dy ee ny iu lesh y tuittymys v’ayn.

English: There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what was on the top of it.
Manx: Va shalmane mooar gaase faggys jee, mysh yn yrjid cheddin as ee hene; as, tra v’ee er nyeeaghyn fo, as er gagh lhiattee jeh, as cheu-heear jeh, heill ee dy bare jee jeeaghyn as feddyn magh c'red v’er y vaare jeh.

English: She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large blue caterpillar, that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.
Manx: Heeyn ish ee hene seose er baare e h-ordaagyn-coshey, as ren ee peeikearagh harrish oirr y chalmane, as dy çhelleeragh veeit e sooillyn roosyn ec praddag vooar ghorrym, va ny soie er y vaare as e roihaghyn fillit, toghtaney hookah liauyr dy feagh, dyn geill y chur jeeish ny da red erbee elley.

English: CHAPTER V.
Manx: CABDYL 5

English: Advice from a Caterpillar
Manx: Coyrle voish Praddag

English: The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence: at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed her in a languid, sleepy voice.
Manx: Yeeagh y Phraddag as Ealish er y cheilley rish tammylt ayns tostid: fy yerrey, ghow y Phraddag y hookah magh ass e beeal, as loayr ee ree ayns coraa liastey, cadlagh.

English: “Who are you?” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Quoi uss?” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied, rather shyly, “I — I hardly know, sir, just at present — at least I know who I was when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.”
Manx: Cha row shoh greinnaghey ee as y coloayrtys goaill toshiaght. Dreggyr Ealish, faitagh dy liooar, “Cha - cha nel fys kiart aym, Vainstyr, ec y traa t'ayn - er y chooid sloo, va fys aym quoi va mish tra hrog mee orrym moghrey jiu, agh er lhiam dy vel mee er ve caghlaait keayrt ny ghaa neayrs y traa shen.”

English: “What do you mean by that?” said the Caterpillar sternly. “Explain yourself!”
Manx: “C’red ta’n bun jeh shen?” dooyrt y Phraddag dy loghtal. “Soilshee magh oo hene!”

English: “I can’t explain myself, I’m afraid, sir,” said Alice, “because I’m not myself, you see.”
Manx: “Cha noddym soilshaghey magh mee hene, s’treih lhiam gra, Vainstyr,” dooyrt Ealish, “er y fa nagh nee mish hene mish, t’ou toiggal.”

English: “I don’t see,” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cha nel mee toiggal,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: “I’m afraid I can’t put it more clearly,” Alice replied very politely, “for I can’t understand it myself to begin with; and being so many different sizes in a day is very confusing.”
Manx: “S’treih lhiam, agh cha noddym gra eh ny smoo baghtal,” dreggyr Ealish, feer chooyrtoil, er y fa nagh voddyms hene toiggal eh, dy ghoaill toshiaght; as lurg dou ve whilleen mooadys ayns un laa, t’eh er chur orrym ve fud y cheilley dy bollagh.”

English: “It isn’t,” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cha nel,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: “Well, perhaps you haven’t found it so yet,” said Alice; “but when you have to turn into a chrysalis — you will some day, you know — and then after that into a butterfly, I should think you’ll feel it a little queer, won’t you?”
Manx: “Foddee nagh vel y lheid er jeet orts foast,” dooyrt Ealish; “agh tra vees oo eginit caghlaa gys cryslaid — bee uss eginit laa ennagh, ta fys ayd — as lurg shen, gys foillycan, veigns smooinaghtyn dy bee uss gennaghtyn red beg quaagh, nagh bee?”

English: “Not a bit,” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cha bee noadyr,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: “Well, perhaps your feelings may be different,” said Alice; “all I know is, it would feel very queer to me.”
Manx: “Foddee nagh bee uss gennaghtyn goll rhym pene,” dooyrt Ealish: “ooilley ta mish toiggal, shen dy beigns hene gennaghtyn feer whaagh.”

English: “You!” said the Caterpillar contemptuously. “Who are you?”
Manx: “Uss!” dooyrt y Phraddag dy lunagh. “Quoi uss?”

English: Which brought them back again to the beginning of the conversation.
Manx: Ren shen cur ad erash dys toshiaght y choloayrtys.

English: Alice felt a little irritated at the Caterpillar’s making such very short remarks, and she drew herself up and said, very gravely, “I think, you ought to tell me who you are, first.”
Manx: Va raaghyn feer yiare ny Praddag cur er Ealish dy ve beggan brasnit, as hayrn ee ee hene seose as dooyrt ee, feer trome-chooishagh, “Er lhiam dy lhisagh uss ginsh dooys quoi oo hene hoshiaght.”

English: “Why?” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cre’n oyr?” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a very unpleasant state of mind, she turned away.
Manx: Er hoh feysht boiragh elley; as, er y fa nagh dod Ealish smooinaghtyn er oyr mie erbee, as v'eh jeeaghyn dy row aigney ny Praddag ayns stayd feer neu-haitnyssagh, hyndaa ee ee hene ersooyl.

English: “Come back!” the Caterpillar called after her. “I’ve something important to say!”
Manx: “Tar erash!” dyllee y Phraddag ny lurg. “Ta red ennagh scanshoil aym dy ghra!”

English: This sounded promising, certainly: Alice turned and came back again.
Manx: Foddee dy beagh shoh gialdyn red ennagh. Hyndaa Ealish mygeayrt as haink ee erash.

English: “Keep your temper,” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Freill dty happey,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: “Is that all?” said Alice, swallowing down her anger as well as she could.
Manx: “Vel shen ooilley?” dooyrt Ealish, va keiltyn e ferg chammah as dod ee.

English: “No,” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cha nel,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: Alice thought she might as well wait, as she had nothing else to do, and perhaps after all it might tell her something worth hearing.
Manx: Heill Ealish dy bare jee fuirraghtyn, er y fa nagh row veg elley eck dy yannoo, as foddee dy ninshagh ee jee red ennagh va feeu clashtyn lurg ooilley.

English: For some minutes it puffed away without speaking, but at last it unfolded its arms, took the hookah out of its mouth again, and said, “So you think you’re changed, do you?”
Manx: Son paart dy vinnidyn v’ee toghtaney fegooish loayrt; agh fy yerrey ren ee feaysley e roihaghyn, ghow ee y hookah magh ass e beeal reesht, as dooyrt ee “T’ou uss smooinaghtyn dy vel oo caghlaait, vel?”

English: “I’m afraid I am, sir,” said Alice;
Manx: “S'treih lhiam dy vel, Vainstyr,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “I can’t remember things as I used to — and I don’t keep the same size for ten minutes together!”
Manx: “Cha noddym cooinaghtyn er reddyn myr va mee cliaghtit - as cha nel mee tannaghtyn y mooadys cheddin son jeih minnid cooidjagh!”

English: “Can’t remember what things?” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cre ny reddyn nagh vod oo cooinaghtyn er?” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: “Well, I’ve tried to say “How doth the little busy bee,” but it all came different!” Alice replied in a very melancholy voice.
Manx: “Dy jarroo, phrow mee dy ghra ‘Cre’n aght taʼn shellan beg tarroogh,’ agh haink red ennagh elley magh!” dreggyr Ealish ayns coraa feer treih.

English: “Repeat, “You are old, Father William,’” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Jean gra ‘T’ou uss shenn, Yishag Illiam’,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: Alice folded her hands, and began:—
Manx: Dill Ealish e laueyn, as ghow ee toshiaght :—

English: “You are old, Father William,” the young man said,
Manx: “Yishag Illiam, t’ou shenn,” as y mac cho gastey,

English: “And your hair has become very white;
Manx: “As ta’n folt ayd cho bane as lḥeeah;

English: And yet you incessantly stand on your head
Manx: Agh er dty chione t’ou dty hassoo dy daaney

English: — Do you think, at your age, it is right?”
Manx: — Vel oo sheiltyn dy vel shen creeney?”

English: “In my youth,” Father William replied to his son,
Manx: Jishag Illiam, v’eh freggyrt dy mie rishyn eisht,

English: “I feared it might injure the brain; But, now that I’m perfectly sure I have none,
Manx: “Va aggle orrym roish lhottey my chione, Agh shickyr ta mish nagh vel enneeyn aym nish

English: Why, I do it again and again.”
Manx: Ta mee jannoo eh reesht as dy beayn.'”

English: “You are old,” said the youth, “as I mentioned before,
Manx: “T’ou uss shenn,” dooyrt y mac, “ren mee gra, ghooinney voght,

English: And have grown most uncommonly fat;
Manx: T’ou er jeet dy ve roauyr erskyn towse,

English: Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door —
Manx: Agh lheim bun ry skyn tra ren oo cheet stiagh,

English: Pray, what is the reason of that?”
Manx: Nee keoi v’ou ny brisht lesh jymmoose?"

English: “In my youth,” said the sage, as he shook his grey locks,
Manx: Y shenn dooinney, v’eh gra, tra v’eh aeg, fegooish craa,

English: “I kept all my limbs very supple
Manx: V’eh freayll eh hene skibbylt as loobagh

English: By the use of this ointment—one shilling the box—
Manx: Lesh y niart jeh’n aaly veagh eshyn y ’laa,

English: Allow me to sell you a couple?”
Manx: “By vie lhiat kishteig y chionnagh?”

English: “You are old,” said the youth, “and your jaws are too weak
Manx: “T'ou uss shenn,” dooyrt y mac, “ta dty chab ro annoon

English: For anything tougher than suet;
Manx: Son red ta feer chiu goll rish feill;

English: Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak—
Manx: Agh dee uss y guiy mooar gyn sthap ny bardoon —

English: Pray, how did you manage to do it?”
Manx: Ta mee guee ort dy insh dou dty skeeal.”

English: “In my youth,” said his father, “I took to the law,
Manx: “Ayns my aegid,” v’eh gra, “turneyr mie va mee,

English: And argued each case with my wife;
Manx: Va resooney gagh red lesh my ven;

English: And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw,
Manx: As y niart dynsee mee, da my chab ren cur bree

English: Has lasted the rest of my life.”
Manx: Ren tannaght dy mie as dy slane.”

English: “You are old,” said the youth, “one would hardly suppose
Manx: “T’ou uss shenn,” dooyrt y mac, “as cha noddagh oo gra

English: That your eye was as steady as ever;
Manx: Dy vel sooill ayd ta lajer as gial;

English: Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose—
Manx: Agh va astan ny lhie er y ’troin ayd gyn craa —

English: What made you so awfully clever?”
Manx: Cre’n aght v’ou cho mie as schleioil?”

English: “I have answered three questions, and that is enough,”
Manx: “Dansoor mee tree feyshtyn, as ta shen dy liooar,”

English: Said his father; “don’t give yourself airs!
Manx: Va’n jishag cur freggyrt dy bieau;

English: Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff?
Manx: “Freill rick mie ort hene as giarr sheese dty phooar -

English: Be off, or I’ll kick you down stairs!”
Manx: Ersooyl lhiat, my phaitchey neufeeu!”

English: “That is not said right,” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cha row eh grait dy kiart,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: “Not quite right, I’m afraid,” said Alice, timidly; “some of the words have got altered.”
Manx: “Cha row eh slane kiart, s’treih lhiam gra,” dooyrt Ealish dy faitagh: "va kuse jeh ny focklyn caghlaait.”

English: “It is wrong from beginning to end,” said the Caterpillar decidedly, and there was silence for some minutes.
Manx: “T’eh aggairagh veih’n toshiaght gys y jerrey,” dooyrt y Phraddag, ayns coraa shickyr; as eisht va tostid ayn son shiartanse dy vinnidyn.

English: The Caterpillar was the first to speak.
Manx: Va’n Phraddag y chied fer dy loayrt.

English: “What size do you want to be?” it asked.
Manx: “Cre’n mooadys t’ou laccal dy ve?” vrie ee.

English: “Oh, I’m not particular as to size,” Alice hastily replied; “only one doesn’t like changing so often, you know.”
Manx: “Ogh, cha nel mee soit er mooadys er lheh,” dreggyr Ealish dy siyragh; “cha mie lhiam ve goll er caghlaa cho mennick, ta fys ayd.”

English: “I don’t know,” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Cha nel fys ayms,” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: Alice said nothing: she had never been so much contradicted in her life before, and she felt that she was losing her temper.
Manx: Cha dooyrt Ealish veg: cha row ee rieau wheesh loayrit noi sy vea eck roie, as v'ee gennaghtyn dy row ee coayl e tappey.

English: “Are you content now?” said the Caterpillar.
Manx: “Vel oo jeant booiagh nish?” dooyrt y Phraddag.

English: “Well, I should like to be a little larger, sir, if you wouldn’t mind,” said Alice: “three inches is such a wretched height to be.”
Manx: “By vie lhiam ve beggan ny smoo, Vainstyr, choud's nagh vees oo boirit,” dooyrt Ealish: “tree oarlagh, shen yrjid treih dy ve.”

English: “It is a very good height indeed!” said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).
Manx: "She yrjid feer vie t'ayn, dy jarroo!" dooyrt y Phraddag dy fergagh, troggal ee hene dy jeeragh seose as ish loayrt (v'ee kiart tree oarlagh er yrjid).

English: “But I’m not used to it!” pleaded poor Alice in a piteous tone. And she thought of herself, “I wish the creatures wouldn’t be so easily offended!”
Manx: “Agh cha nel mee cliaghtit rish!” phlead Ealish voght ayns coraa treih. As smooinee ish ree hene, “Saillym nagh beagh yn olk currit er ny beiyn cho aashagh!”

English: “You’ll get used to it in time,” said the Caterpillar; and it put the hookah into its mouth and began smoking again.
Manx: “Hig oo dy ve cliaghtit rish ayns traa,” dooyrt y Phraddag; as hug ee y hookah stiagh sy veeal eck, as ghow ee toshiaght dy hoghtaney reesht.

English: This time Alice waited patiently until it chose to speak again.
Manx: Y keayrt shoh, duirree Ealish dy surransagh gys va'n Phraddag arryltagh loayrt reesht.

English: In a minute or two the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth and yawned once or twice, and shook itself.
Manx: Ayns minnid ny ghaa, ghow y Phraddag y hookah magh ass e beeal, ren ee mennuigh keayrt ny ghaa, as chrie ee hene.

English: Then it got down off the mushroom, and crawled away in the grass, merely remarking as it went, “One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter.”
Manx: Eisht haink ee neose veih’n chalmane, as ren ee snaue ersooyl stiagh sy faiyr, as ish gra myr v'ee goll, “Ver un lhiattee ort dy aase ny s'toallee, as ver y lhiattee elley ort dy ve ny s'girrey.”

English: “One side of what? The other side of what?” thought Alice to herself.
Manx: “Un lhiattee jeh c’red? Y lhiattee elley jeh c’red?” smooinee Ealish ree hene.

English: “Of the mushroom,” said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.
Manx: “Jeh’n chalmane,” dooyrt y Phraddag, myr dy beagh ee er vriaght er ard; as ayns grig elley v’ee ass shilley.

English: Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute, trying to make out which were the two sides of it; and as it was perfectly round, she found this a very difficult question.
Manx: Hannee Ealish as ish jeeaghyn er y chalmane dy smooinaghtagh rish minnid, prowal dy hoiggal y daa lhiattee jeh; as, er y fa dy row ee cruinn, hooar ee dy nee feysht doillee v’ayn.

English: However, at last she stretched her arms round it as far as they would go, and broke off a bit of the edge with each hand.
Manx: Aghterbee, sy jerrey heeyn ee e roihaghyn mygeayrt y mysh cho foddey as v’ad roshtyn, as vrish ee peesh jeh’n oirr lesh gagh laue.

English: “And now which is which?” she said to herself, and nibbled a little of the right-hand bit to try the effect: the next moment she felt a violent blow underneath her chin: it had struck her foot!
Manx: “Nish, cre’n pheesh ta kiart?” dooyrt ee ree hene, as huilg ee minniag veih'n lhiattee er y laue yesh dy ’eddyn magh cre haghyragh. Dy chelleeragh, v'ee bwoaillit dy h-eulyssagh fo’n smeggyl eck: v’ee er woalley e cass!

English: She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she set to work at once to eat some of the other bit.
Manx: V’ee agglit dy mooar liorish y caghlaa feer doaltattym shoh, agh dennee ish nagh row traa erbee faagit, er y fa dy row ee goll er cribbey dy bieau: myr shen, ghow ee ayns laue dy chelleeragh dy ee paart jeh’n pheesh elley.

English: Her chin was pressed so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the lefthand bit.
Manx: Va’n smeggyl eck traastit cho chionn noi e cass as nagh row monney reamys faagit dy ’osley e beeal; agh doshil ee eh fy yerrey, as haink eh lhee dy ‘luggey minniag jeh'n pheesh hoshtal.

English: “Come, my head’s free at last!” said Alice in a tone of delight, which changed into alarm in another moment, when she found that her shoulders were nowhere to be found: all she could see, when she looked down, was an immense length of neck, which seemed to rise like a stalk out of a sea of green leaves that lay far below her.
Manx: “Jeeagh, ta’n kione aym seyr fy yerrey!” dooyrt Ealish as ard- voggey sy choraa eck, va caghlaait gys atchim ayns grig elley, tra hooar ee magh nagh row e geayltyn ry gheddyn boayl erbee: ooilley v’ee abyl fakin, tra yeeagh ee sheese, va shen lhiurid ass towse jeh mwannal, va jeeaghyn myr dy beagh eh girree goll rish gass ass keayn dy ghuillagyn glassey va nyn lhie foddey foee.

English: “What can all that green stuff be?” said Alice. “And where have my shoulders got to?
Manx: “Cre sy teihll ta’n stoo glass shen?” dooyrt Ealish. “As c’raad ta my ghealtyn ersooyl?

English: And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can’t see you?”
Manx: As ogh, my laueyn boghtey, cre’n aght nagh voddym fakin ad?”

English: She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow, except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.
Manx: V’ee gleashaghey ad mygeayrt as ish loayrt, agh v’eh jeeaghyn nagh row eiyrtys erbee ayn, er lhimmey jeh craa beg mastey ny duillagyn glassey feer foddey ersooyl.

English: As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent.
Manx: Er yn oyr nagh row eh jeeaghyn dy row caa erbee ayn dy chur e laueyn seose gys e kione, phrow ee dy chur e kione sheese huc, as v'ee jeant feer wooiagh dy ’eddyn magh dy jinnagh e mwannal goll er loobey dy h-aashagh raad erbee, goll rish aarnieu.

English: She had just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made her draw back in a hurry: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and was beating her violently with its wings.
Manx: V’eh er jeet lhee dy loobey sheese e mwannal dy h-aalin camstram, as ish er chee lheim stiagh mastey ny duillagyn, nagh row agh baareyn ny biljyn v’ee rouail fo, tra hug thassane gear urree tayrn ergooyl dy siyragh: va calmane mooar er netlagh stiagh syn eddin eck, as v’eh bwoalley ee dy h-eulyssagh lesh e skianyn.

English: “Serpent!” screamed the Pigeon.
Manx: “Aarnieu!” screeagh y Calmane.

English: “I’m not a serpent!” said Alice indignantly. “Let me alone!”
Manx: “Cha nee aarnieu mish!” dooyrt Ealish dy fergagh. “Faag mee ayns shee!”

English: “Serpent, I say again!” repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone, and added with a kind of sob, “I’ve tried every way, and nothing seems to suit them!”
Manx: “Aarnieu, ta mish dy ghra reesht!” dooyrt y Calmane reesht, agh ayns coraa va ny smoo kiune, as dooyrt eh lesh sorch dy hogh, “Ta mee er phrowal gagh aght, agh t'eh jeeaghyn nagh vel veg cooie daue!”

English: “I haven’t the least idea what you’re talking about,” said Alice.
Manx: “Cha nel eie erbee aym cre t’ou taggloo mychione,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “I’ve tried the roots of trees, and I’ve tried banks, and I’ve tried hedges,” the Pigeon went on, without attending to her; “but those serpents! There’s no pleasing them!”
Manx: “Ta mee er phrowal ny fraueyn jeh biljyn, as ta mee er phrowal brooinyn, as ta mee er phrowal cleighyn,” hie y Calmane er, gyn cur geill jee; “agh ny aarnieughyn shen! Cha nod ad ve jeant bwooiagh!”

English: Alice was more and more puzzled, but she thought there was no use in saying anything more till the Pigeon had finished.
Manx: Va Ealish cheet dy ve ny smoo as ny smoo fud y cheilley, agh heill ee nagh row eh feeu dy ghra red erbee elley derrey va'n Calmane er jeet gy kione.

English: “As if it wasn’t trouble enough hatching the eggs,” said the Pigeon; “but I must be on the look-out for serpents night and day! Why, I haven’t had a wink of sleep these three weeks!”
Manx: “She boirey dy liooar t’ayn y ve guirr ny h-oohyn,” dooyrt y Calmane; “agh shegin dou freayll arrey son aarnieughyn, fud ny h-oie as feiy yn laa! Cammah, cha nel veg dy chadley er ve aym rish tree shiaghtyn nish!”

English: “I’m very sorry you’ve been annoyed,” said Alice, who was beginning to see its meaning.
Manx: “S’treih lhiam dy mooar dy row uss boirit,” dooyrt Ealish, va goaill toshiaght dy hoiggal y bun jeh’n chooish.

English: “And just as I’d taken the highest tree in the wood,” continued the Pigeon, raising its voice to a shriek, “and just as I was thinking I should be free of them at last, they must needs come wriggling down from the sky! Ugh, Serpent!”
Manx: “As cho leah’s ta mee er ngoaill y billey syrjey sy cheyll,” hie y Calmane er, as eh troggal e choraa seose gys screeagh, “as kiart ec y traa va mee sheiltyn dy beigns rey roo fy yerrey, shegin daue cheet neose veih’n speyr as ad cassey mygeayrt! Ugh, Aarnieu!”

English: “But I’m not a serpent, I tell you!” said Alice. “I’m a — I’m a — ”
Manx: “Agh cha nel mee my aarnieu, ta mish dy ghra rhyt!” dooyrt Ealish. “Ta mee — ta mee — ”

English: “Well! What are you?” said the Pigeon. “I can see you’re trying to invent something!”
Manx: “C’red? C’red t’ou?” dooyrt y Calmane. “Ta mee fakin dy vel oo prowal croo red ennagh!”

English: “I — I’m a little girl,” said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she remembered the number of changes she had gone through that day.
Manx: “Ta- ta mee my inneen veg,” dooyrt Ealish ouryssagh dy liooar, myr va cooinaghtyn eck er ny caghlaaghyn earrooagh haink urree y laa shen.

English: “A likely story indeed!” said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest contempt.
Manx: “Skeeal liklee dy jarroo!” dooyrt y Calmane ayns coraa feer lunagh.

English: “I’ve seen a good many little girls in my time, but never one with such a neck as that!
Manx: “Ta mee er nakin inneenyn beggey dy liooar sy vea aym, agh cha vaik rieau nane erbee as lheid y wannal shen eck!

English: No, no! You’re a serpent; and there’s no use denying it.
Manx: Cha nel, cha nel! She aarnieu uss; cha neeu eh y obbal.

English: I suppose you’ll be telling me next that you never tasted an egg!”
Manx: Ta mee sheiltyn dy bee uss ginsh dou nagh ren oo rieau blasstyn ooh!”

English: “I have tasted eggs, certainly,” said Alice, who was a very truthful child; “but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you know.”
Manx: “Ta mee er vlasstyn oohyn, son shickyrys,” dooyrt Ealish, va ny paitchey feer firrinagh; “agh ta inneenyn beggey gee whilleen oohyn as aarnieughyn, ta fys ayd.”

English: “I don’t believe it,” said the Pigeon; “but if they do, why then they’re a kind of serpent, that’s all I can say.”
Manx: “Cha nel mee credjal eh,” dooyrt y Calmane; “agh my ta shen firrinagh, t’ad nyn sorch dy aarnieu: shen ooilley foddym gra.”

English: This was such a new idea to Alice, that she was quite silent for a minute or two, which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding,
Manx: Va shoh ny eie noa niartal son Ealish, as, kyndagh rish, v'ee ny tost rish minnid ny ghaa, ren cur da'n Chalmane y caa dy ghra,

English: “You’re looking for eggs, I know that well enough; and what does it matter to me whether you’re a little girl or a serpent?”
Manx: “T’ou shirrey oohyn, shione dou shen mie dy liooar; as nagh gummey lhiams vel uss dty inneen veg ny dty aarnieu?”

English: “It matters a good deal to me,” said Alice hastily; “but I’m not looking for eggs, as it happens; and if I was, I shouldn’t want yours: I don’t like them raw.”
Manx: “T'eh jeh scansh vooar dooys," dooyrt Ealish dy tappee; “agh cha nel mee shirrey oohyn, ta fys ayd; as dy beigns shirrey ad, cha beigns laccal ny fir ayds: cha mie lhiam ad y ve aw.”

English: “Well, be off, then!” said the Pigeon in a sulky tone, as it settled down again into its nest.
Manx: “Ersooyl lhiat eisht!” dooyrt y Calmane dy pooitchagh, as eshyn soiaghey sheese syn edd echey.

English: Alice crouched down among the trees as well as she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches, and every now and then she had to stop and untwist it.
Manx: Chroym Ealish sheese mastey ny biljyn chammah as dod ee, er y fa dy row e mwannal kinjagh cheet dy ve kianlt seose ayns ny banglaneyn, as nish as reesht beign jee scuirr dy ’easyley eh.

English: After a while she remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands, and she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at the other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter, until she had succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.
Manx: Lurg tammylt, va cooinaghtyn eck dy row ee foast cummal greim er ny peeshyn jeh shalmane ayns e laueyn, as ghow ee yn obbyr ayns laue feer chiarailagh as ish shuilgey un pheesh hoshiaght as eisht y pheesh elley, as ny keayrtyn v’ee gaase ny smoo toallee, as ny keayrtyn ny s’girrey, gys v’eh er jeet lhee dy gholl erash gys e h-yrjid cliaghtagh.

English: It was so long since she had been anything near the right size, that it felt quite strange at first; but she got used to it in a few minutes, and began talking to herself, as usual.
Manx: V’eh cho foddey neayr’s v’ee er ve red erbee goll rish e mooadys kiart dy row eh gennaghtyn quaagh dy liooar ec y toshiaght; agh haink ee dy ve cliaghtit rish ayns shiartanse dy vinnidyn, as ghow ee toshiaght dy loayrt ree hene, myr dy cliaghtagh,

English: “Come, there’s half my plan done now! How puzzling all these changes are! I’m never sure what I’m going to be, from one minute to another!
Manx: “Jeeagh, ta lieh my phlan jeant nish! Nagh keishtagh ooilley ny caghlaaghyn shoh! Cha noddym ve shickyr dy bragh cre vees mee, veih un vinnid gys y nah vinnid!

English: However, I’ve got back to my right size: the next thing is, to get into that beautiful garden — how is that to be done, I wonder?”
Manx: Aghterbee, ta mee er ngoll erash gys my vooadys kiart: y nah red, shen dy chosney stiagh sy gharey aalin shen - cre'n aght vees shen jeant, ta mee sheiltyn?”

English: As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open place, with a little house in it about four feet high.
Manx: Myr v’ee gra shoh, haink ee dy doaltattym gys boayl feaynfoshlit as thie beg ayn va mysh kiare trie er yrjid.

English: “Whoever lives there,” thought Alice, “it’ll never do to come upon them this size: why, I should frighten them out of their wits!”
Manx: “Quoi erbee ta cummal ayns shoh,” smooinee Ealish, “cha bee eh cooie dy bragh dy heet orroo as mish y mooadys shoh: cammah, veagh ad agglit ass nyn geeall aym!”

English: So she began nibbling at the righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she had brought herself down to nine inches high.
Manx: Myr shen, ghow ee toshiaght dy huilgey er y pheesh er y laue yesh reesht, as cha b’loys jee goll faggys da’n thie derrey v'ee er chur lhee ee hene sheese gys nuy oarlagh er yrjid.

English: CHAPTER VI.
Manx: CABDYL 6

English: Pig and Pepper
Manx: Muc as Pibbyr

English: For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the wood — (she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery: otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a fish) — and rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles.
Manx: Rish minnid ny ghaa v’ee ny shassoo jeeaghyn er y thie, as ish smooinaghtyn c’red dy yannoo, tra, dy doaltattym, roie guilley drid va coamrit ayns eaddagh shirveishagh magh ass y cheyll - (v'ee contey eh dy ve ny ghuilley drid er y fa dy row eh coamrit myr shen: er nonney, veih'n eddin echey ny lomarcan, veagh ee er ghra eeast rish) - as chrank eh dy sheeanagh er y dorrys lesh ny h-uddaneyn echey.

English: It was opened by another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled all over their heads.
Manx: V'eh er ny 'osley ec guilley drid elley ayns eaddagh shirveishagh, lesh eddin cruinn, as sooillyn mooarey goll rish rannag; as hug Ealish my ner dy row folt poodyrit ec y daa ghuilley drid, folt casagagh va ooilley harrish nyn ging.

English: She felt very curious to know what it was all about, and crept a little way out of the wood to listen.
Manx: V’ee feer pheeikearagh as by vie lhee dy mooar feddyn magh c'red va goll er, as ren ee snaue magh ass y cheyll, beggan, dy eaishtagh.

English: The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter, nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other, saying, in a solemn tone, “For the Duchess.
Manx: Ghow y Guilley Drid Eeastee toshiaght as eshyn goaill magh screeuyn mooar va er ve fo’n roih echey. Va’n screeuyn bunnys cho mooar as eshyn, as hug eh eh da’n fer elley, as dooyrt eh dy trome-chooishagh, “Son y Vendiuic.

English: An invitation from the Queen to play croquet.”
Manx: Cuirrey veih’n Venrein dy chloie croquet.”

English: The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn tone, only changing the order of the words a little,
Manx: Va shoh grait reesht ec y Ghuilley Drid Rannag, dy trome-chooishagh neesht, agh va oardagh ny focklyn caghlaait beggan,

English: “From the Queen. An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.”
Manx: “Veih’n Venrein. Cuirrey da’n Vendiuic dy chloie croquet.”

English: Then they both bowed low, and their curls got entangled together.
Manx: Eisht chroym y jees jeu sheese dy h-injil, as haink ny casagyn oc dy ve kianlt ry cheilley.

English: Alice laughed so much at this, that she had to run back into the wood for fear of their hearing her; and when she next peeped out the Fish-Footman was gone, and the other was sitting on the ground near the door, staring stupidly up into the sky.
Manx: Hug shoh er Ealish garaghtee wheesh as dy beign jee roie erash sy cheyll er aggle dy gluinnagh ad ee; as, tra speeik ee magh lurg shoh, va’n Guilley Drid Eeastee ersooyl, as va’n fer elley ny hoie er y thalloo faggys da’n dorrys, as eshyn blakey dy bolvaneagh seose sy speyr.

English: Alice went timidly up to the door, and knocked.
Manx: Hie Ealish dy faitagh gys y dorrys as chrank ee er.

English: “There’s no sort of use in knocking,” said the Footman, “and that for two reasons. First, because I’m on the same side of the door as you are; secondly, because they’re making such a noise inside, no one could possibly hear you.”
Manx: “Cha neeu eh ve crankal myr shen,” dooyrt y Guilley Drid, “as ta shen er daa oyr. Hoshiaght, er y fa dy vel mish er y cheu cheddin jeh’n dorrys as uss: as y nah oyr, t'ad feiyral cho niartal cheu-sthie as nagh vod peiagh erbee clashtyn oo.”

English: And certainly there was a most extraordinary noise going on within — a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.
Manx: As son shickyrys v’ad feiyral erskyn insh cheu-sthie — gullal as streighyraght gyn scuirr, as polt mooar nish as reesht, myr dy beagh jyst ny coirrey veg er ny vrishey ayns peeshyn.

English: “Please, then,” said Alice, “how am I to get in?”
Manx: “Kyndagh rish shen, my sailliu,” dooyrt Ealish, “cre'n aght foddym cosney stiagh?”

English: “There might be some sense in your knocking,” the Footman went on without attending to her, “if we had the door between us.
Manx: “Foddee dy beagh eh keeallagh dy beagh uss crankal,” ren y Guilley Drid goll er, gyn cur geill jee, “dy beagh y dorrys eddyr ain.

English: For instance, if you were inside, you might knock, and I could let you out, you know.”
Manx: Myr sampleyr, dy beagh uss cheu-sthie, oddagh oo crankal, as oddins lhiggey stiagh oo, ta fys ayd.”

English: He was looking up into the sky all the time he was speaking, and this Alice thought decidedly uncivil.
Manx: V’eh jeeaghyn seose sy speyr ooilley yn traa v'eh loayrt, as heill Ealish dy row shoh neu- ghoiagh, son shickyrys.

English: “But perhaps he can’t help it,” she said to herself; “his eyes are so very nearly at the top of his head. But at any rate he might answer questions. —How am I to get in?” she repeated, aloud.
Manx: “Agh foddee nagh vel niart echey er,” dooyrt ee ree hene; “ta e hooillyn feer, feer faggys da baare e ching. Agh er y chooid sloo oddagh eh cur freggyrt da feyshtyn. — Cre’n aght foddym cosney stiagh?” dooyrt ee reesht, er ard.

English: “I shall sit here,” the Footman remarked, “till tomorrow — ”
Manx: “Soieym ayns shoh,” dimraa yn Guilley Drid, “gys laa ny vairagh —”

English: At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came skimming out, straight at the Footman’s head: it just grazed his nose, and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.
Manx: Ec y vinnid shoh, va dorrys y thie foshlit, as detlee moggaid mooar magh, dy jeeragh lesh kione y Ghuilley Drid: screeb eh yn ’troin echey, as v’eh brisht ayns peeshyn noi nane jeh ny biljyn ny chooyl.

English: “— or next day, maybe,” the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly as if nothing had happened.
Manx: “— er nonney y laa nuyr, foddee,” hie y Guilley Drid er lesh y choraa cheddin, myr nagh row veg er daghyrt.

English: “How am I to get in?” asked Alice again, in a louder tone.
Manx: “Cre’n aght bee’m cosney stiagh?” vrie Ealish reesht, ny stroshey.

English: “Are you to get in at all?” said the Footman. “That’s the first question, you know.”
Manx: “Bee uss cosney stiagh er chor erbee?” dooyrt y Guilley Drid. “Shen y chied feysht, ta fys ayd.”

English: It was, no doubt: only Alice did not like to be told so. “It’s really dreadful,” she muttered to herself, “the way all the creatures argue. It’s enough to drive one crazy!”
Manx: V’eh kiart, gyn ourys: agh cha by vie lesh Ealish dy ve inshit. “Dy firrinagh, t’eh agglagh,” ren Ealish tallagh ree hene, “yn aght ta gagh cretoor jannoo arganys. S'liooar shen dy chur ort dy gholl keoi!”

English: The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his remark, with variations. “I shall sit here,” he said, “on and off, for days and days.”
Manx: V'eh jeeaghyn dy row y Guilley Drid coontey shoh dy ve ny chaa mie dy ghra yn un red reesht, lesh caghlaayn beggey. “Soieym ayns shoh,” dooyrt eh, “nish as reesht, son laghyn as laghyn.”

English: “But what am I to do?” said Alice.
Manx: “Agh cre veem's hene jannoo?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Anything you like,” said the Footman, and began whistling.
Manx: “Red erbee sailt,” dooyrt y Guilley Drid, as ghow eh toshiaght dy ’eddanagh.

English: “Oh, there’s no use in talking to him,” said Alice desperately: “he’s perfectly idiotic!” And she opened the door and went in.
Manx: “Ogh, cha nel eh feeu dy loayrt rishyn,” dooyrt Ealish dy debejagh: “t'eh slane ommidjagh!” As doshil ee y dorrys as hie ish stiagh.

English: The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.
Manx: Haink ee dy jeeragh stiagh ayns shamyr-aarlee vooar, va lane dy yaagh veih’n derrey kione gys y jeh elley: va’n Vendiuic ny soie er stoyl tree chassagh sy vean as ish boandyrys oikan: va’n aarlider croymmey harrish yn aile, as eh mestey coirrey vooar va jeeaghyn dy ve lane dy awree.

English: “There’s certainly too much pepper in that soup!” Alice said to herself, as well as she could for sneezing.
Manx: “Son shickyrys ta rouyr pibbyr syn awree shen!” dooyrt Ealish ree hene, chammah as oddagh ee as ish streighyraght.

English: There was certainly too much of it in the air. Even the Duchess sneezed occasionally; and as for the baby, it was sneezing and howling alternately without a moment’s pause.
Manx: Son shickyrys, va rouyr jeh syn aer. Eer y Vendiuic, ren ish streighyraght nish as reesht; as yn oikan hene, v'eh streighyraght as eisht gullyrnee er eiyrt, gyn scuirr erbee.

English: The only things in the kitchen that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting on the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.
Manx: Yn ynrican daa chretoor sy chamyr-aarlee nagh ren streighyraght, v’ad shen yn aarlider as kayt mooar va ny lhie ec y chiollagh as gyrnal veih un chleaysh gys y fer elley.

English: “Please would you tell me,” said Alice, a little timidly, for she was not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, “why your cat grins like that?”
Manx: “Jean shiu ginsh dou, my sailliu,” dooyrt Ealish, beggan faitagh, er y fa nagh row ee lane shickyr row eh cooyrtoil dy loayrt hoshiaght, “cre'n fa ta’n kayt eu gyrnal myr shen?”

English: “It’s a Cheshire cat,” said the Duchess, “and that’s why. Pig!”
Manx: “She kayt-Cheshire t’ayn,” dooyrt y Vendiuic, “as shen y fa, Vuc!”

English: She said the last word with such sudden violence that Alice quite jumped; but she saw in another moment that it was addressed to the baby, and not to her, so she took courage, and went on again:—
Manx: Dooyrt ee y fockle s’jerree lesh wheesh raghlid doaltattym as dy ren Ealish sprettal; agh ayns grig elley hoig ee dy row ee loayrt rish yn oikan as cha nee reeish, as, myr shen, haink ee dy ve dunnal, as hie ish er reesht:-

English: “I didn’t know that Cheshire cats always grinned; in fact, I didn’t know that cats could grin.”
Manx: “Cha row fys aym dy row kiyt-Cheshire kinjagh gyrnal; dy jarroo, cha row fys aym dy noddagh kiyt gyrnal.”

English: “They all can,” said the Duchess; “and most of ’em do.”
Manx: “Foddee ad ooilley gyrnal,” dooyrt y Vendiuic: “as shen ny ta'n chooid smoo jeu jannoo.”

English: “I don’t know of any that do,” Alice said very politely, feeling quite pleased to have got into a conversation.
Manx: “Cha nel fys aym er kiyt erbee ta jannoo shen,” dooyrt Ealish feer chooyrtoil, as ish bwooiagh dy liooar dy ghoaill ayrn ayns coloayrtys.

English: “You don’t know much,” said the Duchess; “and that’s a fact.”
Manx: “Cha nel fys ayd er monney,” dooyrt y Vendiuic; “as s’feer shen.”

English: Alice did not at all like the tone of this remark, and thought it would be as well to introduce some other subject of conversation.
Manx: Cha bynney lesh Ealish yn aght va shoh grait, as heill ee dy bare jee loayrt mychione cooish ennagh elley.

English: While she was trying to fix on one, the cook took the cauldron of soup off the fire, and at once set to work throwing everything within her reach at the Duchess and the baby — the fire-irons came first; then followed a shower of saucepans, plates, and dishes.
Manx: Choud’s v’ee prowal smooinaghtyn er cooish ennagh, ghow yn aarlider y choirrey dy awree jeh'n aile, as dy chelleeragh ghow ee toshiaght dy cheau dy chooilley red v'ee abyl roshtyn lesh y Vendiuic as yn oikan — haink ny yiarnyn-ailey hoshiaght; eisht haink frass dy phannaghyn, moggaidyn as jystyn.

English: The Duchess took no notice of them even when they hit her; and the baby was howling so much already, that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.
Manx: Cha dug y Vendiuic geill erbee daue, eer tra v'ee bwoaillit oc; as va'n oikan gullyrnee wheesh hannah as dy row eh slane neu-yantagh dy ghra row ny bwoaillaghyn lhottey eh ny dyn.

English: “Oh, please mind what you’re doing!” cried Alice, jumping up and down in an agony of terror. “Oh, there goes his precious nose!” as an unusually large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.
Manx: “Ogh, gow kiarail, ta mee guee ort!” dyllee Ealish, as ish lheim neese sheese lesh aggle vooar. “Ogh, shen e ’troin ennoil ersooyl!”, myr va panney feer vooar getlagh shaghey faggys jee, as bunnys cur lesh ee.

English: “If everybody minded their own business,” the Duchess said in a hoarse growl, “the world would go round a deal faster than it does.”
Manx: “Dy beagh dy chooilley pheiagh cur geill da ny cooishyn oc hene,” ren y Vendiuic gyrnal dy garroo, “ragh y seihll mygeayrt foddey ny s’tappee na t’eh goll.”

English: “Which would not be an advantage,” said Alice, who felt very glad to get an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge.
Manx: “Red nagh beagh ny vondeish,” dooyrt Ealish, va feer wooiagh dy gheddyn caa dy hoilshaghey magh beggan jeh’n fys eck.

English: “Just think of what work it would make with the day and night! You see the earth takes twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis —”
Manx: “Smooinee er yn obbyr veagh jeant echey lesh y laa as yn oie! Ta’n seihll chyndaa mygeayrt er yn essyl echey ayns kiare oor as feed, as giarrey y traa —”

English: “Talking of axes,” said the Duchess, “chop off her head!”
Manx: “Loayrt mychione giarrey, giar jeh e kione!”

English: Alice glanced rather anxiously at the cook, to see if she meant to take the hint; but the cook was busily stirring the soup, and seemed not to be listening, so she went on again:
Manx: Hug Ealish e sooillyn imneagh dy liooar er yn aarlider, jeeaghyn row ee son cur geill da'n faaue; agh va’n aarlider mestey yn awree dy tarroogh, as v’eh jeeaghyn nagh row ee geaishtagh, myr shen hie ish er reesht:

English: “Twenty-four hours, I think; or is it twelve? I —”
Manx: “Kiare oor as feed, er-lhiam; er nonney vel eh daa-yeig? Ta mee —”

English: “Oh, don’t bother me,” said the Duchess; “I never could abide figures!”
Manx: “Ogh, ny bee dy my voirey!” dooyrt y Vendiuic. “Cha dod mee rieau jannoo lesh earrooyn!”

English: And with that she began nursing her child again, singing a sort of lullaby to it as she did so, and giving it a violent shake at the end of every line:
Manx: As er shen, ghow ee toshiaght dy voandyrys yn oikan reesht, as ish goaill sorch dy arrane-cadlee, as craa eh dy niartal ec y jerrey jeh gagh linney:—

English: “Speak roughly to your little boy,
Manx: “Loayr dy barb rish dty ghuilley aeg,

English: And beat him when he sneezes:
Manx: As bwoaill eh tra t'eh streighyraght:

English: He only does it to annoy,
Manx: Cha nel eh laccal dy yannoo veg

English: Because he knows it teases.”
Manx: As lhisagh eh ve geaishtagh.”

English: CHORUS.
Manx: COCHIAULL

English: (In which the cook and the baby joined):
Manx: (yn aarlider as yn oikan ry cheilley): —

English: “Wow! wow! wow!”
Manx: “Wow! wow! wow!”

English: While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she kept tossing the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing howled so, that Alice could hardly hear the words:—
Manx: Choud’s va’n Vendiuic goaill y nah ronney jeh’n arrane, v’ee kinjagh ceau yn oikan dy raghtal neese sheese, as va'n red beg boght gullyrnee wheesh as dy row eh doillee da Ealish clashtyn ny goan:-

English: “I speak severely to my boy,
Manx: “Loayrym dy barb rish y ghuilley,

English: I beat him when he sneezes;
Manx: Bwoaillym eh tra t’eh streighyraght;

English: For he can thoroughly enjoy
Manx: Shione dou dy vel eh goaill soylley Jeh'n

English: The pepper when he pleases!”
Manx: phibbyr bwee ta jannoo cragh!”

English: CHORUS.
Manx: COCHIAULL

English: “Wow! wow! wow!”
Manx: “Wow! wow! wow!”

English: “Here! you may nurse it a bit, if you like!” the Duchess said to Alice, flinging the baby at her as she spoke.
Manx: “Shoh eh! Foddee uss eh y voandyrys son tammylt, my t'ou laccal!” dooyrt y Vendiuic rish Ealish, as ee ceau yn oikan lhee myr v’ee loayrt.

English: “I must go and get ready to play croquet with the Queen,” and she hurried out of the room.
Manx: “Shegin dou goll as jannoo aarloo dy chloie croquet marish y Venrein,” as hiyree ish magh ass y chamyr.

English: The cook threw a frying-pan after her as she went out, but it just missed her.
Manx: Cheau yn aarlider frynepan lhee myr v’ee goll magh, as v'ee bunnys bwoaillit echey.

English: Alice caught the baby with some difficulty, as it was a queer-shaped little creature, and held out its arms and legs in all directions, “just like a star-fish,” thought Alice.
Manx: Hayr Ealish yn oikan lesh doilleeid dy liooar, er y fa dy row eh ny chretoor as cummey quaagh echey va sheeyney magh e roihaghyn as lurgaghyn dy chooilley ard, “kiart goll rish crossag varrey,” smooinee Ealish.

English: The poor little thing was snorting like a steam-engine when she caught it, and kept doubling itself up and straightening itself out again, so that altogether, for the first minute or two, it was as much as she could do to hold it.
Manx: Va’n red beg boght stronnaghey goll rish greie-bree tra hayr ee eh, as v’eh kinjagh doobley eh hene as eisht jeeraghey eh hene reesht. Myr shen, son y chied vinnid ny jees, v’eh feer doillee cummal greim er.

English: As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried it out into the open air.
Manx: Cho leah’s hooar ee magh yn aght kiart dy voandyrys eh (va shen dy chassey eh ayns sorch dy chront as eisht cummal greim niartal er e chleaysh yesh dyn y chur caa da feaysley eh hene), ren ee cur eh lhee magh fo’n speyr.

English: “If I don’t take this child away with me,” thought Alice, “they’re sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn’t it be murder to leave it behind?”
Manx: “Mannagh derym lhiam yn oikan shoh,” smooinee Ealish, “t’eh lane shickyr dy bee eh marrooit oc ayns laa ny jees. Nagh beagh eh dunverys faagail eh ayns shoh?"

English: She said the last words out loud, and the little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time).
Manx: Dooyrt ee ny goan s’jerree er ard, as ghroaish y red beg myr freggyrt (cha row eh streighyraght ec y traa shoh).

English: “Don’t grunt,” said Alice; “that’s not at all a proper way of expressing yourself.”
Manx: “Ny groaish,” dooyrt Ealish, “cha nel shen ny aght cooie dy hoilshaghey magh dty smooinaghtyn.”

English: The baby grunted again, and Alice looked very anxiously into its face to see what was the matter with it.
Manx: Ghroaish yn oikan reesht, as yeeagh Ealish feer imneagh syn eddin echey dy ’eddyn magh c’red va jannoo er.

English: There could be no doubt that it had a very turn-up nose, much more like a snout than a real nose; also its eyes were getting extremely small for a baby: altogether Alice did not like the look of the thing at all.
Manx: Gyn ourys erbee, va stroin echey va kiart goll rish strooh syn ynnyd jeh stroin chiart: as, red elley, va e hooillyn cheet dy ve feer veg son babban: cha row Ealish coontey veg jeh'n red noadyr.

English: “But perhaps it was only sobbing,” she thought, and looked into its eyes again, to see if there were any tears.
Manx: “Agh foddee nagh row eh agh soghal," smooinee ish, as yeeagh ee stiagh ayns e hooillyn reesht, dy ’akin row jeir erbee ayndaue.

English: No, there were no tears.
Manx: Cha row, cha row jeir ayn.

English: “If you’re going to turn into a pig, my dear,” said Alice, seriously, “I’ll have nothing more to do with you. Mind now!”
Manx: “My t’ou kiarail cheet dy ve dty vuc, veen,” dooyrt Ealish, dy trome-chooishagh, “cha bee’m dellal rhyt reesht. Gow kiarail nish!”

English: The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.
Manx: Hogh y red beg boght reesht (er nonney, ghroaish eh, v’eh neu-yantagh clashtyn yn anchaslys), as hie ad er son tammylt foddey dy liooar ayns tostid.

English: Alice was just beginning to think to herself, “Now, what am I to do with this creature when I get it home?” when it grunted again, so violently, that she looked down into its face in some alarm.
Manx: Va Ealish goaill toshiaght dy smooinaghtyn ree hene, “Nish, cre foddym jannoo lesh y chretoor shoh, tra higym dy valley marish?” tra ghroaish eh reesht cho niartal as dy yeeagh ee sheese syn eddin echey as aggle dy liooar urree.

English: This time there could be no mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than a pig, and she felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it further.
Manx: Y keayrt shoh, cha dod ee ve aggairagh: she muc v'ayn son shickyrys, as dennee ish dy beagh eh ommidjagh erskyn towse dy derragh ee lhee eh ny sodjey.

English: So she set the little creature down, and felt quite relieved to see it trot away quietly into the wood.
Manx: Myr shen hug ee sheese y cretoor beg, as v'ee jeant bwooiagh dy liooar tra honnick ee dy row eh troytal dy kiune stiagh sy cheyll.

English: “If it had grown up,” she said to herself, “it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes rather a handsome pig, I think.”
Manx: “Dy beagh eh er naase seose,” dooyrt ee ree hene, “veagh eh er jeet dy ve ny phaitchey graney agglagh: agh she muc waagh dy liooar t’ayn, ta mee sheiltyn.”

English: And she began thinking over other children she knew, who might do very well as pigs, and was just saying to herself, “if one only knew the right way to change them —” when she was a little startled by seeing the Cheshire Cat sitting on a bough of a tree a few yards off.
Manx: As ghow ee toshiaght dy smooinaghtyn er paitchyn elley va enney eck orroo veagh feer chooie dy ve nyn muic, foddee, as v’ee gra ree hene “dy beagh fys ec peiagh er yn aght kiart dy chaghlaa ad —” tra v’ee beggan agglit liorish fakin y Kayt-Cheshire va ny hoie er banglane paart dy stundayrtyn ersooyl.

English: The Cat only grinned when it saw Alice.
Manx: Cha ren y Kayt agh gyrnal tra honnick eh Ealish.

English: It looked good-natured, she thought: still it had very long claws and a great many teeth, so she felt that it ought to be treated with respect.
Manx: V'eh jeeaghyn coar, heill ee: ny yeih shen, va ingynyn feer liauyr echey as ram feeacklyn, as heill ee dy lhisagh ee cur arrym da.

English: “Cheshire Puss,” she began, rather timidly, as she did not at all know whether it would like the name: however, it only grinned a little wider.
Manx: “Phussag-Cheshire,” ghow ee toshiaght, faitagh dy liooar, er y fa nagh row fys eck beagh eh graihagh er yn ennym: agh cha ren eh agh gyrnal beggan ny stroshey.

English: “Come, it’s pleased so far,” thought Alice, and she went on.
Manx: “Jeeagh, t’eh jeant bwooiagh choud's shoh,” smooinee Ealish, as hie ee er.

English: “Would you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?”
Manx: “Jinnagh shiu ginsh dou, my sailliu, c’raad lhisins goll voish shoh?”

English: “That depends a good deal on where you want to get to,” said the Cat.
Manx: “Ta shen croghey dy mooar er y voayl t’ou laccal goll huggey.” dooyrt y Kayt.

English: “I don’t much care where—” said Alice.
Manx: “S’cummey lhiam y boayl —” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Then it doesn’t matter which way you go,” said the Cat.
Manx: “Eisht s’cummey raad t’ou goll,” dooyrt y Kayt.

English: “— so long as I get somewhere,” Alice added as an explanation.
Manx: “— choud’s ta mee roshtyn boayl ennagh,” dooyrt Ealish myr soilsheydys.

English: “Oh, you’re sure to do that,” said the Cat, “if you only walk long enough.”
Manx: “Ogh, t’eh shickyr dy jean oo shen,” dooyrt y Kayt, “eer my vees oo shooyl foddey dy liooar.”

English: Alice felt that this could not be denied, so she tried another question. “What sort of people live about here?”
Manx: Heill Ealish nagh dod shoh ve obbit, myr shen phrow ee feysht elley. “Cre’n sorch dy ’leih ta cummal ayns shoh?”

English: “In that direction,” the Cat said, waving its right paw round, “lives a Hatter: and in that direction,” waving the other paw, “lives a March Hare. Visit either you like: they’re both mad.”
Manx: “Syn ard shen,” dooyrt y Kayt, as eh craa e vaaig yesh mygeayrt, “ta Eddeyder cummal: as syn ard shen,” as eh craa y vaaig elley, “ta Mwaagh Vart cummal. Cur shilley er y jees oc my t’ou laccal: ta’n jees oc keoi.”

English: “But I don’t want to go among mad people,” Alice remarked.
Manx: “Agh cha nel mee laccal ve mastey sleih keoi,” dimraa Ealish.

English: “Oh, you can’t help that,” said the Cat: “we’re all mad here. I’m mad. You’re mad.”
Manx: “Ogh, cha nel niart ayd er shen,” dooyrt y Kayt: “ta shin ooilley keoi ayns shoh. Ta mish keoi. T’ou uss keoi.”

English: “How do you know I’m mad?” said Alice.
Manx: “Kevys diu dy vel mish keoi?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “You must be,” said the Cat, “or you wouldn’t have come here.”
Manx: “Shegin dhyt ve keoi,” dooyrt y Kayt, “er nonney cha beagh oo er jeet dys shoh.”

English: Alice didn’t think that proved it at all; however, she went on “And how
Manx: Cha row Ealish coontey dy row shen kiart er chor erbee: aghterbee, ren ee goll er: “As kevys diu dy vel shiuish keoi?”

English: do you know that you’re mad?”
“To begin with,” said the Cat, “a dog’s not mad. You grant that?”
Manx: “Dy ghoaill toshiaght,” dooyrt y Kayt, “cha nel moddey keoi. Vel oo ayns coardailys?”

English: “I suppose so,” said Alice.
Manx: “Ta mee sheiltyn dy vel,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Well, then,” the Cat went on, “you see, a dog growls when it’s angry, and wags its tail when it’s pleased.
Manx: “Myr shen,” ren y Kayt goll er, “t’ou cur my ner dy vel moddey scryssey tra t’eh corree, as craa y famman echey tra t’eh jeant bwooiagh.

English: Now I growl when I’m pleased, and wag my tail when I’m angry. Therefore I’m mad.”
Manx: Nish ta mish scryssey tra ta mee jeant bwooiagh, as craa y famman aym tra ta mee corree. Er y hon shen, ta mee keoi."

English: “I call it purring, not growling,” said Alice.
Manx: “Ta mish gra cronnaney rish, cha nee scryssey,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Call it what you like,” said the Cat. “Do you play croquet with the Queen to-day?”
Manx: “Abbyr rish ny t’ou laccal,” dooyrt y Kayt. “Vel oo cloie croquet marish y Venrein jiu?”

English: “I should like it very much,” said Alice, “but I haven’t been invited yet.”
Manx: “By vie lhiam eh dy mooar,” dooyrt Ealish, “agh cha nel mee er ngeddyn cuirrey foast.”

English: “You’ll see me there,” said the Cat, and vanished.
Manx: “Hee oo mish ayns shen,” dooyrt y Kayt, as skell eh roish.

English: Alice was not much surprised at this, she was getting so used to queer things happening.
Manx: Cha dug shoh monney yindys er Ealish, er y fa dy row ee cheet dy ve cliaghtit rish taghyrtyn quaagh.

English: While she was looking at the place where it had been, it suddenly appeared again.
Manx: Choud’s v’ee jeeaghyn er y voayl raad v'eh er ve, haink eh rish reesht dy doaltattym.

English: “By-the-bye, what became of the baby?” said the Cat. “I’d nearly forgotten to ask.”
Manx: “Aghterbee, cre haink er yn oikan?” dooyrt y Kayt. “Yarrood mee dy vriaght, bunnys.”

English: “It turned into a pig,” Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back in a natural way.
Manx: “Haink eh dy ve ny vuc,” dreggyr Ealish feer feagh, myr dy beagh y Kayt er jeet erash er aght dooghyssagh.

English: “I thought it would,” said the Cat, and vanished again.
Manx: “Heill mee dy jinnagh,” dooyrt y Kayt, as skell eh roish reesht.

English: Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in which the March Hare was said to live. “I’ve seen hatters before,” she said to herself; “the March Hare will be much the most interesting, and perhaps as this is May it won’t be raving mad — at least not so mad as it was in March.”
Manx: Duirree Ealish beggan, as ish lieh yerkal rish fakin eh reesht, agh cha daink eh rish, as lurg minnid ny ghaa hooill ee gys yn ard raad v’ad gra dy row y Mwaagh Vart cummal. “Ta mee er nakin eddeyderyn roie,” dooyrt ee ree hene: “bee y Mwaagh Vart y fer smoo anaasagh son shickyrys, as foddee, er y fa dy nee Boaldyn t’ayn, nagh bee eh slane keoi - er y chooid sloo, cha nee cho keoi as v’eh ayns Mee Vart.”

English: As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat again, sitting on a branch of a tree.
Manx: Myr dooyrt ee shoh, yeeagh ee seose, as va’n Kayt ayn reesht as eshyn ny hoie er y vanglane jeh billey.

English: “Did you say pig, or fig?” said the Cat.
Manx: “Dooyrt oo ‘muc’ ny ‘bock’?” dooyrt y Kayt.[2]
Notes: [2] [muck ny bock] — [bock] ‘gelding’ / ‘male goat’ (used instead of [fig] to fit the narrative.

English: “I said pig,” replied Alice; “and I wish you wouldn’t keep appearing and vanishing so suddenly: you make one quite giddy.”
Manx: “Dooyrt mee ‘muc’,” dreggyr Ealish; “as saillym nagh beagh oo kinjagh cheet rhyt as skellal royd cho doaltattym: ta shiu cur orrym dy ve thollaneagh dy liooar!”

English: “All right,” said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly, beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which remained some time after the rest of it had gone.
Manx: “Mie dy liooar,” dooyrt y Kayt; as y keayrt shoh, skell eh roish moal dy liooar, goaill toshiaght ec kione y famman, as cheet gys jerrey lesh y ghyrn, ren tannaghtyn tammylt lurg va'n chooid elley ersooyl.

English: “Well! I’ve often seen a cat without a grin,” thought Alice; “but a grin without a cat! It’s the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!”
Manx: “Dy jarroo! Ta mee dy mennick er nakin kayt fegooish gyrn,” smooinee Ealish; “agh gyrn fegooish kayt! Shen y red smoo quaagh honnick mee rieau ayns my vea ooilliu!”

English: She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur.
Manx: Cha row ee er ngoll foddey ny sodjey roish my daink ee ayns shilley jeh thie y Waagh Vart: heill ee dy nhegin da ve y thie kiart, er y fa dy row ny chymleeyn jeant goll rish cleayshyn as va'n chlea thooit lesh fynney.

English: It was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly, saying to herself “Suppose it should be raving mad after all!
Manx: She thie cho mooar v’ayn as nagh row ee laccal goll ny sniessey da derrey v’ee er shuilgey tooilley jeh peesh hoshtal y chalmane, as v’ee er nyrjaghey ee hene gys red goll rish daa hrie er yrjid: ny yeih shen as ooilley, hooill ee huggey beggan faitagh, as ish gra ree hene “Cre haghyrys my vees eh slane keoi lurg ooilley!

English: I almost wish I’d gone to see the Hatter instead!”
Manx: Ta mee bunnys guee dy row mee er ngoll lesh shilley er yn Eddeyder syn ynnyd jeh shoh!”

English: CHAPTER VII.
Manx: CABDYL 7

English: A Mad Tea-Party
Manx: Giense-Tey Keoi

English: There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head.
Manx: Va boayrd currit magh fo billey beeal rish y thie, as va’n Mwaagh Vart as yn Eddeyder goaill tey ayns shen: va Lugh Vagheragh ny soie eddyr oc as ee ny cadley dy dowin, as va'n jees elley gymmydey ee myr clooishag, nyn uiljyn nyn lhie urree, as ad taggloo harrish e kione.

English: “Very uncomfortable for the Dormouse,” thought Alice; “only, as it’s asleep, I suppose it doesn’t mind.”
Manx: “Feer vee-gherjoilagh da’n Lugh Vagheragh,” smooinee Ealish; “choud’s t’ee ny cadley, er lhiam nagh gummey lhee, foddee.”

English: The table was a large one, but the three were all crowded together at one corner of it: “No room! No room!” they cried out when they saw Alice coming.
Manx: She boayrd mooar v’ayn, agh va’n troor ooilley jingit ry cheilley ec un chorneil jeh. “Dyn reamys! Dyn reamys!” dyllee ad magh tra honnick ad dy row Ealish cheet.

English: “There’s plenty of room!” said Alice indignantly, and she sat down in a large arm-chair at one end of the table.
Manx: “Ta reamys dy liooar ayn!” dooyrt Ealish dy fergagh, as hoie ee sheese ayns stoyl drommey mooar v’ec un chione jeh’n voayrd.

English: “Have some wine,” the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.
