Manx: “Gow bine feeyn,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart lesh coraa greinnaghey.

English: Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea. “I don’t see any wine,” she remarked.
Manx: Yeeagh Ealish ooilley mygeayrt y voayrd, agh cha row veg er agh tey. “Cha nel mee fakin feeyn erbee,” dimraa ee.

English: “There isn’t any,” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Cha nel y lheid ayn,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: “Then it wasn’t very civil of you to offer it,” said Alice angrily.
Manx: “Cha row uss feer choar dy hebbal eh eisht,” dooyrt Ealish dy jymmoosagh.

English: “It wasn’t very civil of you to sit down without being invited,” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Cha row uss feer choar tra hoie uss sheese fegooish cuirrey,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: “I didn’t know it was your table,” said Alice; “it’s laid for a great many more than three.”
Manx: “Cha row fys aym dy row yn boayrd lhiats,” dooyrt Ealish: “t'eh er ny yeshaghey son foddey ny smoo sleih na troor.”

English: “Your hair wants cutting,” said the Hatter. He had been looking at Alice for some time with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.
Manx: “Lhisagh y folt ayd ve giarrit,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder. V’eh er ve jeeaghyn er Ealish son paart dy hraa er aght feer pheeikearagh, as v'ad shoh ny chied goan echey.

English: “You should learn not to make personal remarks,” Alice said with some severity; “it’s very rude.”
Manx: “Lhisagh oo gynsaghey gyn reddyn persoonagh y ghra,” dooyrt Ealish barb dy liooar: “t’eh feer lunagh.”

English: The Hatter opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; but all he said was, “Why is a raven like a writing-desk?”
Manx: Doshil yn Eddeyder e hooillyn feer lhean erreish da v'er clashtyn shoh; agh ooilley va grait echey, cha row shen agh “Cre hon ta feeagh goll rish coir-screeuee?"

English: “Come, we shall have some fun now!” thought Alice. “I’m glad they’ve begun asking riddles. — I believe I can guess that,” she added aloud.
Manx: “Dy jarroo, bee paart dy spoyrt ain nish!” smooinee Ealish. “S'mie lhiam dy vel ad er ngoaill toshiaght dy ronsaghey raaghyn dorraghey — ta mee credjal dy noddym cur cheb er shen,” dooyrt ee er ard.

English: “Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Vel oo smooinaghtyn dy nod oo cur y bun jeh?” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: “Exactly so,” said Alice.
Manx: “Dy jarroo, ta,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Then you should say what you mean,” the March Hare went on.
Manx: “Eisht Ihisagh oo gra ny t’ou cheet er,” ren y Mwaagh Vart goll er.

English: “I do,” Alice hastily replied; “at least — at least I mean what I say — that’s the same thing, you know.”
Manx: “Ta mee jannoo shen,” dreggyr Ealish dy siyragh, “er y chooid sloo — er y chooid sloo ta mee cheet er ny ta mee gra — shen yn un red, t’ou toiggal.”

English: “Not the same thing a bit!” said the Hatter.
Manx: “Cha nee yn un red t’ayn noadyr!” dooyrt yn Eddeyder.

English: “You might just as well say that ‘I see what I eat’ is the same thing as ‘I eat what I see’!”
Manx: “Cammah, veagh eh chammah dhyt gra dy vel ‘Ta mee fakin ny ta mee gee’ yn un red as ‘Ta mee gee ny ta mee fakin’!”

English: “     You might just as well say,” added the March Hare, “that ‘I like what I get’ is the same thing as ‘I get what I like’!”
Manx: “Veagh eh chammah dhyt gra,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart, “dy vel ‘S’mie lhiam ny ta mee geddyn’ yn un red as ‘Ta mee geddyn ny s’mie lhiam’!”

English: “You might just as well say,” added the Dormouse, who seemed to be talking in his sleep, “that ‘I breathe when I sleep’ is the same thing as ‘I sleep when I breathe’!”
Manx: “Veagh eh chammah dhyt gra,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh, va jeeaghyn dy ve taggloo as ee ny cadley, “dy vel ‘Ta mee tayrn ennal tra ta mee my chadley' yn un red as ‘Ta mee my chadley tra ta mee tayrn ennal!’”

English: “It is the same thing with you,” said the Hatter, and here the conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks, which wasn’t much.
Manx: “Dy jarroo, she yn un red t’ayn bentyn rhyts,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder, as ayns shoh scuirr y coloayrtys, as va’n cheshaght ny soie as ad nyn dost son minnid, choud’s va Ealish smooinaghtyn er ooilley ny reddyn as cooinaghtyn eck orroo va bentyn rish fee as coiyr-screeuee: va ny reddyn shen goan.

English: The Hatter was the first to break the silence. “What day of the month is it?” he said, turning to Alice:
Manx: Va’n Eddeyder y chied ’er dy vrishey yn tostid. “Cre’n laa jeh’n vee t’ayn?" dooyrt eh, as eh çhyndaa gys Ealish:

English: he had taken his watch out of his pocket, and was looking at it uneasily, shaking it every now and then, and holding it to his ear.
Manx: v’eh er ngoaill e ooreyder magh ass e phoggaid, as v’eh jeeaghyn er dy h-imneagh as craa eh nish as reesht as cur eh faggys da’n chleaysh echey.

English: Alice considered a little, and then said “The fourth.”
Manx: Smooinee Ealish son tammylt beg as eisht dooyrt ee “Y chiarroo.”

English: “Two days wrong!” sighed the Hatter. “I told you butter wouldn’t suit the works!” he added looking angrily at the March Hare.
Manx: “Daa laa ersooyl cam!” dosnee yn Eddeyder. “Dinsh mee dhyt nagh beagh eeym cooie da ny obbraghyn!" dooyrt eh as eh jeeaghyn er y Waagh Vart dy fergagh.

English: “It was the best butter,” the March Hare meekly replied.
Manx: “She yn eeym share v'ayn,” dreggyr y Mwaagh Vart dy meein.

English: “Yes, but some crumbs must have got in as well,” the Hatter grumbled: “you shouldn’t have put it in with the bread-knife.”
Manx: “She, agh gyn ourys chosne paart dy chinneigyn stiagh neesht,” ren yn Eddeyder gaccan: “Cha lhisagh oo er chur eh stiagh lesh y skynn arran.”

English: The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of nothing better to say than his first remark, “It was the best butter, you know.”
Manx: Ghow y Mwaagh Vart yn ooreyder as yeeagh eh er dy groamagh: eisht humm eh eh sy chappan dy hey echey, as yeeagh eh er reesht: agh cha dod eh smooinaghtyn er red erbee share dy ghra na e chied goan, “She yn eeym share v'ayn, ta fys ayd.”

English: Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity. “What a funny watch!” she remarked. “It tells the day of the month, and doesn’t tell what o’clock it is!”
Manx: Va Ealish er ve jeeaghyn harrish e gheaylin peeikearagh dy liooar. “Cre'n ooreyder quaagh!” dooyrt ee. "T'eh soilshaghey magh y laa jeh'n vee, as cha nee c'red t'eh er y chlag!"

English: “Why should it?” muttered the Hatter. “Does your watch tell you what year it is?”
Manx: “Cre hon lhisagh eh?” ren yn Eddeyder tallaghey. “Vel yn ooreyder ayds soilshaghey magh cre'n vlein t'ayn?”

English: “Of course not,” Alice replied very readily: “but that’s because it stays the same year for such a long time together.”
Manx: “Cha nel, son shickyrys,” dreggyr Ealish feer arryltagh: “agh shen er y fa dy vel yn vlein cheddin ayn son traa cho liauyr agglagh.”

English: “Which is just the case with mine,” said the Hatter.
Manx: “Ta’n fer ayms kiart myr shen,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder.

English: Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter’s remark seemed to have no sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English. “I don’t quite understand you,” she said, as politely as she could.
Manx: Va Ealish fud y cheilley dy bollagh. Ny va grait ec yn Eddeyder, cha row ee coontey dy row keeall erbee ayn, agh ny yeih, she Gailck[3] v’ayn son shickyrys. "Cha nel mee toiggal shiu,” dooyrt ee, cho cooyrtoil as v'ee abyl.
Notes: [3] Gailck] ‘Manx (language’, used here instead of [Baarle] ‘English’, to fit the narrative.

English: “The Dormouse is asleep again,” said the Hatter, and he poured a little hot tea upon its nose.
Manx: “Ta'n Lugh Vagheragh ny cadley reesht,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder, as gheayrt eh bine dy hey cheh er e stroin.

English: The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its eyes, “Of course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.”
Manx: Chrie y Lugh Vagheragh e kione dy mee-hurransagh, as dooyrt ee, gyn fosley e sooillyn, “Son shickyrys, son shickyrys: dy jeeragh y red va mee kiarail gra mish hene.”

English: “Have you guessed the riddle yet?” the Hatter said, turning to Alice again.
Manx: “Vel oo er veaysley y raa dorraghey foast?” dooyrt yn Eddeyder as eh chyndaa gys Ealish reesht.

English: “No, I give it up,” Alice replied: “what’s the answer?”
Manx: “Cha nel, ta mee cur seose,” dreggyr Ealish. “C’red ta’n bun jeh?”

English: “I haven’t the slightest idea,” said the Hatter.
Manx: “Cha nel fys erbee aym er,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder.

English: “Nor I,” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Cha nel fys ayms noadyr,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: Alice sighed wearily. “I think you might do something better with the time,” she said, “than waste it in asking riddles that have no
Manx: Dosnee Ealish dy skee. “Er lhiam dy noddagh shiu ceau yn traa er aght share,” dooyrt ee, “na jummal eh liorish resooney magh raaghyn dorraghey nagh vod ve feayslit.”

English: answers.”
“If you knew Time as well as I do,” said the Hatter, “you wouldn’t talk about wasting it. It’s him.”
Manx: “Dy beagh enney ayd er Traa chammah as mish,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder, “cha loayragh oo mychione jummal eh er yn aght lunagh shen.”

English: “I don’t know what you mean,” said Alice.
Manx: “Cha nel fys aym ny ta shiu çheet er,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Of course you don’t!” the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously. “I dare say you never even spoke to Time!”
Manx: “Son shickyrys cha nel!” dooyrt yn Eddeyder as eh craa e chione dy connaasagh. “Yiarrins nagh loayr oo rieau rish Traa!”

English: “Perhaps not,” Alice cautiously replied: “but I know I have to beat time when I learn music.”
Manx: “Foddee nagh loayr,” dreggyr  Ealish dy kiarailagh: “agh ta fys aym dy nhegin dou bwoalley traa tra ta mee gynsaghey kiaulleeaght.”

English: “Ah! that accounts for it,” said the Hatter. “He won’t stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he’d do almost anything you liked with the clock.
Manx: “Ah, shen eh,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder. “Cha jean eh shassoo son bwoalley. Nish, dy beagh oo foast coardit rish, yinnagh eh red erbee by vie lhiat lesh y chlag, bunnys.

English: For instance, suppose it were nine o’clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you’d only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!”
Manx: Myr sampleyr, abbyr dy row eh nuy er y chlag sy voghrey, kiart ec y toshiaght jeh lessoonyn: cha beagh ort agh sansheraght faaue rish Traa, as ta'n clag goll mygeayrt ayns grig! Lieh oor lurg nane, traa jinnairagh!”

English: (“I only wish it was,” the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)
Manx: (“Saillym dy row,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart rish hene myr sannish.)

English: “That would be grand, certainly,” said Alice thoughtfully: “but then—I shouldn’t be hungry for it, you know.”
Manx: “Veagh shen yindyssagh, son shickyrys,” dooyrt Ealish dy smooinaghtagh; “agh eisht — cha beagh accrys orrym kyndagh rish, ta fys ayd.”

English: “Not at first, perhaps,” said the Hatter: “but you could keep it to half-past one as long as you liked.”
Manx: “Cha nee ec y toshiaght, foddee,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder: “agh oddagh oo freayll eh ec lieh oor lurg nane cho foddey as by vie lhiat.”

English: “Is that the way you manage?” Alice asked.
Manx: “Nee shen yn aght ta shiuish goll er?” vrie Ealish.

English: The Hatter shook his head mournfully. “Not I!” he replied. “We quarrelled last March —just before he went mad, you know —” (pointing with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) “—it was at the great concert given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing:
Manx: Chrie yn Eddeyder e chione dy trimshagh. “Cha nee!” dreggyr eh. “Huitt shin magh Mee Vart shoh chaie - kiart roish my jagh eh ass e cheeall, ta fys ayd —" (jeeraghey lesh e spein-tey lesh y Waagh Vart,) “— v’eh ec y chuirrey-kiaullee mooar currit ec Benrein ny Creeaghyn, as beign dou goaill yn arrane:

English: ‘Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
Manx: ‘Jean soilshean, chraitnag veen!

English: How I wonder what you’re at!’
Manx: Nagh vel uss dty chretoor reen!’

English: You know the song, perhaps?”
Manx: Nhione dhyt yn arrane, foddee?”

English: “I’ve heard something like it,” said Alice.
Manx: “Ta mee er chlashtyn red ennagh goll rish,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “It goes on, you know,” the Hatter continued, “in this way:—
Manx: “T’eh goll er, ta fys ayd,” ren yn Eddeyder goll er, “er yn aght shoh :—

English: ‘Up above the world you fly,
Manx: ‘Heose erskyn y teihll t’ou nish,

English: Like a tea-tray in the sky.
Manx: Trenshoor-tey, t’ou goll rish.

English: Twinkle, twinkle—’”
Manx: Jean soilshean —”

English: Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep “Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle” and went on so long that they had to pinch it to make it stop.
Manx: Ec y traa shoh, chrie y Lugh Vagheragh ee hene as ghow ee toshiaght dy ghoaill arrane as ee ny cadley “Jean soilshean, jean soilshean —” as hie ee er cho foddey as dy beign daue ee y vingey dy chur urree scuirr.

English: “Well, I’d hardly finished the first verse,” said the Hatter, “when the Queen jumped up and bawled out, ‘He’s murdering the time! Off with his head!’”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, s’goan va mee er chur jerrey er y chied ronney,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder, “tra dyllee y Venrein ‘T’eh jannoo dunverys er yn traa! Giarr e chione jeh!’”

English: “How dreadfully savage!” exclaimed Alice.
Manx: “Nagh oaldey agglagh shen!” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “And ever since that,” the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, “he won’t do a thing I ask! It’s always six o’clock now.”
Manx: “As maghey shen,” hie yn Eddeyder er lesh coraa treih, “cha jean eh red erbee ta mee shirrey! T'eh kinjagh shey er y chlag nish.”

English: A bright idea came into Alice’s head. “Is that the reason so many tea-things are put out here?” she asked.
Manx: Haink eie mie stiagh ayns kione Ealish. “Nee shen y fa dy vel whilleen reddyn-tey soiet magh ayns shoh?” vrie ee.

English: “Yes, that’s it,” said the Hatter with a sigh: “it’s always tea-time, and we’ve no time to wash the things between whiles.”
Manx: “She, shen eh,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder lesh osney: “t'eh kinjagh traa-tey, as cha nel traa dy liooar ain dy niee ny reddyn.”

English: “Then you keep moving round, I suppose?” said Alice.
Manx: “Myr shen, ta shiu kinjagh gleashaghey mygeayrt, ta mee sheiltyn?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Exactly so,” said the Hatter: “as the things get used up.”
Manx: “Dy jeeragh, ta,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder: “myr ta ny reddyn er nyn ymmydey.”

English: “But what happens when you come to the beginning again?” Alice ventured to ask.
Manx: “Agh cre ta taghyrt tra ta shiu cheet gys y toshiaght reesht?” va Ealish daaney dy liooar dy vriaght.

English: “Suppose we change the subject,” the March Hare interrupted, yawning. “I’m getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story.”
Manx: “Abbyr dy jeanmayd caghlaa y chooish,” vrish y Mwaagh Vart stiagh as eh jannoo menniugh. “Ta shoh cur skeeys orrym. Ta mish votal dy ninshys y ven aeg skeeal dooin.”

English: “I’m afraid I don’t know one,” said Alice, rather alarmed at the proposal.
Manx: “S’doogh lhiam nagh nhione dou fer,” dooyrt Ealish as aggle dy liooar urree kyndagh rish y treealtys.

English: “Then the Dormouse shall!” they both cried.
Manx: “Inshee y Lugh Vagheragh skeeal myr shen!” dyllee y jees jeu.

English: “Wake up, Dormouse!” And they pinched it on both sides at once.
Manx: “Dooisht, Lugh Vagheragh!” As ving ad ee er yn daa lhiattee ec yn un cheayrt.

English: The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. “I wasn’t asleep,” he said in a hoarse, feeble voice: “I heard every word you fellows were saying.”
Manx: Doshil y Lugh Vagheragh e sooillyn dy moal. “Cha row mee my chadley,” dooyrt ee lesh coraa peeaghaneagh as annoon, “Cheayll mee gagh fockle va shiuish gra.”

English: “Tell us a story!” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Insh skeeal dooin!” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: “Yes, please do!” pleaded Alice.
Manx: “She, insh!” ghuee Ealish.

English: “And be quick about it,” added the Hatter, “or you’ll be asleep again before it’s done.”
Manx: “As bee tappee,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder ny sodjey, “ er -nonney bee uss dty chadley reesht roish my vees eh inshit.”

English: “Once upon a time there were three little sisters,” the Dormouse began in a great hurry; “and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and they lived at the bottom of a well—”
Manx: “Keayrt dy row, va tree shuyraghyn beggey ayn,” ghow y Lugh Vagheragh as driss mooar er; “as va ny enmyn orroo Elsie, Lacie as Tillie; as v'ad cummal ec y vun jeh çhibbyr –”

English: “What did they live on?” said Alice, who always took a great interest in questions of eating and drinking.
Manx: “C’red v’ad beaghey er?” dooyrt Ealish, va kinjagh anaase mooar eck er cooishyn bentyn rish gee as giu.

English: “They lived on treacle,” said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or two.
Manx: “V’ad beaghey er treagyl,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh, erreish jee v'er smooinaghtyn son minnid ny jees.

English: “They couldn’t have done that, you know,” Alice gently remarked; “they’d have been ill.”
Manx: “Cha noddagh ad er nyannoo shen, ta fys ayd,” dooyrt Ealish dy meeley. “Veagh ad er ve çhing.”

English: “So they were,” said the Dormouse; “very ill.”
Manx: “Shen myr v’ad,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh; “feer çhing.”

English: Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: “But why did they live at the bottom of a well?”
Manx: Phrow Ealish dy heiltyn ree hene cre goll rish veagh lheid yn aght-beaghee cho neu-chadjin as shen, agh v'eh cur urree ve fud y cheilley dy h-agglagh: myr shen, hie ee er: “Agh cre’n fa v’ad cummal ec y vun jeh çhibbyr?”

English: “Take some more tea,” the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.
Manx: “Gow tooilley tey,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart rish Ealish, feer jeean.

English: “I’ve had nothing yet,” Alice replied in an offended tone, “so I can’t take more.”
Manx: “Cha nel mee er ngoaill veg foast,” dooyrt Ealish as snee urree: “myr shen cha noddym goaill ny smoo.”

English: “You mean you can’t take less,” said the Hatter: “it’s very easy to take more than nothing.”
Manx: “By chiart dhyt gra nagh vod oo goaill ny sloo,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder: “t’eh feer aashagh dy ghoaill ny smoo na veg.”

English: “Nobody asked your opinion,” said Alice.
Manx: “Cha hirr peiagh erbee y barel ayds,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Who’s making personal remarks now?” the Hatter asked triumphantly.
Manx: “Quoi ta loayrt dy persoonagh nish?” vrie yn Eddeyder dy barriaghtagh.

English: Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and repeated her question. “Why did they live at the bottom of a well?”
Manx: Cha row fys kiart ec Ealish c’red dy ghra myr freggyrt: myr shen hooar ee jee hene paart dy hey as arran as eeym, as eisht hyndaa ee gys y Lugh Vagheragh, as vrie ee y feysht reesht. “Cre’n fa v’ad cummal ec y vun jeh çhibbyr?”

English: The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then said, “It was a treacle-well.”
Manx: Smooinee y Lugh Vagheragh er y chooish son minnid ny jees, as eisht dooyrt ee “She chibbyr-treagyl v'ayn.”

English: “There’s no such thing!” Alice was beginning very angrily, but the Hatter and the March Hare went “Sh! sh!” and the Dormouse sulkily remarked, “If you can’t be civil, you’d better finish the story for yourself.”
Manx: “Cha nel y lheid ayn!” Va Ealish cheet dy ve feer chorree, agh dooyrt yn Eddeyder as y Mwaagh Vart “Sh! Sh!” as dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh dy pooitchagh “Mannagh vod oo ve cooyrtoil, bare dhyt cur kione er y skeeal dhyt hene.”

English: “No, please go on!” Alice said very humbly;
Manx: “Ogh, cha nee, gow er, my saillt!” dooyrt Ealish feer imlee.

English: “I won’t interrupt again. I dare say there may be one.”
Manx: “Cha derym stiagh ort reesht. Yiarrins dy vod nane ve ayn.”

English: “One, indeed!” said the Dormouse indignantly. However, he consented to go on. “And so these three little sisters — they were learning to draw, you know —”
Manx: “Nane, dy jarroo!” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh dy fergagh. Aghterbee, v'eh arryltagh dy gholl er. “As myr shen, ny tree shuyraghyn beggey shoh - v'ad gynsaghey tayrn, ta fys ayd —”

English: “What did they draw?” said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.
Manx: “C'red v'ad tayrn?” dooyrt Ealish, ren jarrood e gialdin dy bollagh.

English: “Treacle,” said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.
Manx: “Treagyl,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh gyn smooinaght erbee y keayrt shoh.

English: “I want a clean cup,” interrupted the Hatter: “let’s all move one place on.”
Manx: “Ta mish laccal cappan glen,” ren yn Eddeyder cur stiagh: “lhig dooin ooilley gleashagh un ynnyd er oaie.”

English: He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare moved into the Dormouse’s place, and Alice rather unwillingly took the place of the March Hare.
Manx: Ghleash eh er oaie myr v'eh loayrt, as deiyr y Lugh Vagheragh er: ghleash y Mwaagh stiagh ayns ynnyd ny Lugh Vagheragh, as, beggan neu-arryltagh, ghow Ealish ynnyd y Waagh Vart.

English: The Hatter was the only one who got any advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.
Manx: She yn Eddeyder yn ynrican fer hooar vondeish erbee veih'n chaghlaa; as va Ealish foddey ny smessey na roie, er y fa dy row y Mwaagh Vart er lhieggey yn cruishtin bainney sy voggaid echey kiart roish shen.

English: Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very cautiously: “But I don’t understand. Where did they draw the treacle from?”
Manx: Cha row Ealish laccal cur yn olk er y Lugh Vagheragh reesht as, myr shen, ghow ee toshiaght feer chiarailagh: "Agh cha nel mee toiggal. Cre woish t'ad tayrn y treagyl?"

English: “You can draw water out of a water-well,” said the Hatter; “so I should think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well — eh, stupid?”
Manx: “Foddee oo tayrn treagyl veih chibbyr-ushtey,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder; “myr shen ta mee sheiltyn dy noddagh oo tayrn treagyl magh ass chibbyr-treagyl, nagh noddagh, hoot?”

English: “But they were in the well,” Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to notice this last remark.
Manx: “Agh v’ad ayns y çhibbyr,” dooyrt Ealish rish y Lugh Vagheragh, dyn cur geill da’n ’ockle s’jerree.

English: “Of course they were,” said the Dormouse; “—well in.”
Manx: “Son shickyrys v’ad,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh: “slane sthie.”

English: This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for some time without interrupting it.
Manx: Hug y freggyrt shoh er Ealish voght dy ve cho fud y cheilley as dy lhig ee da'n Lugh Vagheragh goll er son paart dy hraa gyn cur stiagh urree.

English: “They were learning to draw,” the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; “and they drew all manner of things—everything that begins with an M—”
Manx: “V’ad gynsaghey tayrn,” hie yn Lugh Vagheragh er as ee jannoo menniugh as rubbal e sooillyn, er y fa dy row ee cheet dy ve feer chadlagh; “as v'ad tayrn dy chooilley horch dy red - reddyn ta goaill toshiaght lesh C —”

English: “Why with an M?” said Alice.
Manx: “Cre'n fa C?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Why not?” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Cre'n fa nagh?” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: Alice was silent.
Manx: Va Ealish ny tost.

English: The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with a little shriek, and went on:
Manx: Va’n Lugh Vagheragh er ghooney e sooillyn ec y traa shoh, as va cadley cheet urree; agh, lurg jee ve mingit ec yn Eddeyder, ghooisht ee reesht lesh screeagh beg, as hie ee er:

English: “—that begins with an M, such as mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness—you know you say things are “much of a muchness”— did you ever see such a thing as a drawing of a muchness?”
Manx: “— ta goaill toshiaght lesh C, goll rish coleayrtys, as caashey, as cooinaghtyn, as castreycairys - ta fys eu dy vel shiu gra dy vel reddyn ‘castreycair’ — vaik shiu y lheid jeh red goll rish tayrn jeh castreycairys?”

English: “Really, now you ask me,” said Alice, very much confused, “I don’t think—”
Manx: “Dy firrinagh, er y fa dy vel oo briaght jeem,” dooyrt Ealish as ish fud y cheilley, “cha nel mee smooinaghtyn—”

English: “Then you shouldn’t talk,” said the Hatter.
Manx: “Cha lhisagh oo loayrt eisht,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder.

English: This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her: the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.
Manx: Va’n lunaght shoh ny smoo na va Ealish abyl jannoo lesh: dirree ish ny shassoo as feoh mooar urree as ersooyl lhee: huitt y Lugh Vagheragh ny cadley dy chelleeragh, as cha dug ny fir elley geill erbee dy row ee ersooyl, ga dy yeeagh ee erash keayrt ny ghaa, as ee lieh-hreishteil dy nyllagh ad lurg eck: y keayrt s’jerree honnick ee ad, v'ad shirrey cur y Lugh Vagheragh stiagh sy phash-hey.

English: “At any rate I’ll never go there again!” said Alice as she picked her way through the wood. “It’s the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all my life!”
Manx: “Cha jem dys shen dy bragh reeshtagh!” dooyrt Ealish, myr v'ee goll trooid y cheyll dy kiarailagh. “Shen y giense-tey smoo bolvaneagh ren mee rieau goll huggey sy clane vea ayms!”

English: Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it. “That’s very curious!” she thought. “But everything’s curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.” And in she went.
Manx: Myr v’ee gra shoh, hug ee my ner dy row dorrys ayns nane jeh ny biljyn. "Shen feer whaagh!" smooinee ish. “Agh ta dy chooilley red quaagh y laa jiu. Er lhiam dy bee eh chammah dou goll stiagh kiart nish.” As stiagh lhee.

English: Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little glass table. “Now, I’ll manage better this time,” she said to herself, and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that
Manx: Keayrt elley, hooar ee magh dy row ee sy halley liauyr as faggys da'n voayrd beg gless. “Nish, hig eh ny share lhiam y

English: led into the garden.
Manx: keayrt shoh,” dooyrt ee ree hene, as ghow ee toshiaght liorish goaill yn ogher veg airhey, as neu-ghlassey yn dorrys va leeideil gys y gharey.

English: Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high: then she walked down the little passage: and then — she found herself at last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool fountains.
Manx: Eisht ghow ee ayns laue dy huilgey yn shalmane (v'ee er vreayll peesh jeh sy phoggaid eck) derrey v'ee mysh trie er yrjid: eisht hooill ee sheese y cassan beg: as eisht - fy yerrey v'ee sy gharey aalin, mastey ny h-ymmraghyn-blaa gial as ny farraneyn feayr.

English: CHAPTER VIII.
Manx: CABDYL 8

English: The Queen’s Croquet-Ground
Manx: Faaie-Croquet y Venrein

English: A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red.
Manx: Va billey-rose mooar faggys da entreilys y gharey: ny roseyn va gaase er, v'ad bane, agh va tree gareyderyn ayn va slaa ad jiarg dy breeoil.

English: Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of them say, “Look out now, Five! Don’t go splashing paint over me like that!”
Manx: Heill Ealish dy row shoh ny red feer whaagh, as haink ee ny sniessey dy yeeaghyn orroo, as, kiart myr v'ee cheet huc, cheayll ee nane jeu gra “Bee er dty hwoaie nish, Wheig! Ny skeoll peint harrym myr shen!"”

English: “I couldn’t help it,” said Five, in a sulky tone; “Seven jogged my elbow.”
Manx: “Cha row niart aym er,” dooyrt Queig dy pooitchagh. “Ren Shiaght yn uillin aym y honkal.”

English: On which Seven looked up and said, “That’s right, Five! Always lay the blame on others!”
Manx: Geiyrt er shen, yeeagh Shiaght seose as dooyrt eh “Shen kiart, Wheig! Cur y loght er fir elley car y traa!”

English: “You’d better not talk!” said Five. “I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!”
Manx: “Bare dhyts dyn taggloo!” dooyrt Queig. “Cheayll mee y Venrein gra y laa jea dy row uss toilchin dty chione y ve giarrit jeed.”

English: “What for?” said the one who had spoken first.
Manx: “Cre hon?” dooyrt y fer loayr hoshiaght.

English: “That’s none of your business, Two!” said Seven.
Manx: “Cha nel shen veg bentyn rhyts, Yees!” dooyrt Shiaght.

English: “Yes, it is his business!” said Five, “and I’ll tell him — it was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, ta!” dooyrt Queig. “As inshym da – v’eh son cur lesh hug y choagyrey fraueyn-tulip ayns ynnyd unnishyn.”

English: Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun “Well, of all the unjust things—” when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and all of them bowed low.
Manx: Cheau Shiaght sheese e skeaban, as v’eh kiart er ngoaill toshiaght “Dy jarroo, cre cho neuchairagh —” tra haghyr eh dy yeeagh eh er Ealish as ish ny shassoo jeeaghyn orroo, as ren eh lhiettallys ersyn hene dy doaltattym: yeeagh ny fir elley mygeayrt neesht, as ren ad ooilley croymmey sheese dy h-injil.

English: “Would you tell me,” said Alice, a little timidly, “why you are painting those roses?”
Manx: “Jinnagh shiu ginsh dou, my sailliu,” dooyrt Ealish beggan faitagh, “yn oyr dy vel shiu slaa ny roseyn shen?”

English: Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two.
Manx: Cha dooyrt Queig as Shiaght veg, agh yeeagh ad er Jees.

English: Two began in a low voice, “Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a red rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know.
Manx: Ghow Jees toshiaght, ayns coraa injil, “Cammah, ta’n bun jeh, Inneen, lhisagh eh shoh ve ny villey-rose jiarg, as, dy marranagh, hug shin stiagh fer bane; as, dy voghe y Venrein magh, veagh ooilley nyn ging giarrit jin, ta fys ayd.

English: So you see, Miss, we’re doing our best, afore she comes, to — ”
Manx: Myr shen, t’ou toiggal, Inneen, ta shin jannoo nyn gooid share, roish my jig ee, dy — ”

English: At this moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called out “The Queen! The Queen!” and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces.
Manx: Kiart ec y traa shoh, Queig, va er ve jeeaghyn dy h-imneagh tessen y garey, dyllee eshyn “Y Venrein! Y Venrein!”, as dy çhelleeragh cheau ny tree gareyderyn ad hene sheese nyn lhie er nyn eddinyn.

English: There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.
Manx: Va ram kesmadyn coshey ry chlashtyn, as yeeagh Ealish mygeayrt dy jeean dy 'akin y Venrein.

English: First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers;
Manx: Hoshiaght, haink jeih sidooryn gymmyrkey spaagyn: va'n cummey oc shoh goll rish ny tree gareyderyn, far-cherrinagh as rea as ny laueyn as cassyn oc ec ny corneilyn; eisht, haink ny jeih cooyrteyryn;

English: these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did.
Manx: v’ad shoh jesheenit ooilley harrish lesh daimanyn, as v'ad shooyl jees as jees, goll rish ny sidooryn.

English: After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented with hearts.
Manx: Lurg shoh, haink ny paitchyn reeoil: va jeih jeu ayn, as va ny paitchyn ennoil corlheimyraght dy gennal, laue ayns laue, ayns cubbil: v'ad ooilley jesheenit lesh creeaghyn.

English: Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit:
Manx: Lurg shen haink ny goaldee, Reeaghyn as Mraane-Rein son y chooid smoo, as hug Ealish enney er y Chonning Vane ny mast’oc:

English: it was talking in a hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without noticing her.
Manx: v’eh loayrt er aght siyragh as imneagh, as vong eh myr eiyrtys er gagh red va grait, as hie eh shaghey gyn cur my ner dy row ee ayn.

English: Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.
Manx: Eisht haink Fieaumanagh ny Creeaghyn, va gymmyrkey attey yn Ree er clooishag velvad yiarg; as, ec y jerrey jeh'n chosheeaght vooar shoh, haink REE AS BENREIN NY CREEAGHYN.

English: Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions; “and besides, what would be the use of a procession,” thought she, “if people had all to lie down upon their faces, so that they couldn’t see it?”
Manx: Va Ealish beggan ouryssagh Ihisagh ee lhie sheese er e h-eddin goll rish ny tree gareyderyn, agh cha dod ee cooinaghtyn dy geayll rieau reill myr shen ec cosheeaghtyn; “as aghterbee, cre’n feeuid veagh ec cosheeaght,” smooinee Ealish, “dy beagh ooilley y sleih eginit lhie sheese er nyn eddinyn, as cha noddagh ad fakin veg?”

English: So she stood still where she was, and waited.
Manx: Myr shen, hass ee raad v’ee, as duirree ish.

English: When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely “Who is this?”
Manx: Tra raink y chosheeaght Ealish, scuirr ad ooilley as yeeagh ad urree, as dooyrt y Venrein dy barb, “Quoi shoh?"

English: She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
Manx: Dooyrt ee shen rish Fieaumanagh ny Creeaghyn, nagh ren agh croymmey sheese as mongey myr freggyrt.

English: “Idiot!” said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, “What’s your name, child?”
Manx: “Ommidan!” dooyrt y Venrein, craa e kione dy mee-hur- ransagh; as, chyndaa gys Ealish, hie ee er: “Cre’n ennym t’ort, phaitchey?”

English: “My name is Alice, so please your Majesty,” said Alice very politely; but she added, to herself, “Why, they’re only a pack of cards, after all. I needn’t be afraid of them!”
Manx: “Ealish, ta’n ennym orrym, my sailliu, Venrein Ooasle,” dooyrt Ealish, feer chooyrtoil; agh dooyrt ee neesht, ree hene, “Cammah, cha nee agh sthock dy chaartyn t’ayn, lurg ooilley. Cha lhiass dou goaill aggle rhymboo!”

English: “And who are these?” said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
Manx: “As quoi ad shoh?” dooyrt y Venrein, as ish cowraghey magh ny tree gareyderyn va nyn lhie mygeayrt y mysh y villey-rose; t'ou toiggal, er y fa dy row ad nyn lhie er nyn eddinyn, as va'n soylley er ny dreeymyn oc yn un red as v'er ny fir elley, cha dod y Venrein fakin nee gareyderyn, ny sidooryn, ny cooyrteyryn, ny troor jeh ny paitchyn eck hene v’ayn.

English: “How should I know?” said Alice, surprised at her own courage.
Manx: “Cre’n aght veagh fys ayms?” dooyrt Ealish as e creeaght hene cur yindys urree.

English: “It’s no business of mine.”
Manx: “Cha nee red erbee bentyn rhyms t’ayn.”

English: The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off —”
Manx: Haink y Venrein dy ve jiarg lesh eulys, as, erreish jee v'er vlakey urree rish grig goll rish cretoor oaldey, ghow ee toshiaght dy screeaghey "Ersooyl lesh e kione! Ersooyl lesh — ”

English: “Nonsense!” said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent.
Manx: “Boghtynid!” dooyrt Ealish feer niartal as lesh shickyrys mooar, as va’n Venrein ny tost.

English: The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said “Consider, my dear: she is only a child!”
Manx: Hug y Ree e laue er y roih eck as dooyrt eh dy faitagh “Smooinee er, veen: cha nee agh paitchey ish!”

English: The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave “Turn them over!”
Manx: Hyndaa y Venrein er aght feer chorree ersooyl voish, as dooyrt  ee rish y Fieaumanagh “chyndaa ad harrish!”

English: The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
Manx: Hyndaa y Fieaumanagh ad, feer chiarailagh, lesh un chass.

English: “Get up!” said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.
Manx: “Seose lhiu!” dooyrt y Venrein ayns coraa ard as lajer, as dy chelleeragh lheim ny gareyderyn seose as ghow ad toshiaght dy chroymmey sheese roish yn Ree, y Venrein, ny paitchyn reeoil, as gagh peiagh elley.

English: “Leave off that!” screamed the Queen. “You make me giddy.”
Manx: “Ny jean-jee shen!” screeagh y Venrein. “Ta shiu cur thollaneys orrym.”

English: And then, turning to the rose-tree, she went on, “What have you been doing here?”
Manx: As eisht, çhyndaa gys y villey-rose, hie ee er “C’red ta shiuish er ve jannoo ayns shoh?”

English: “May it please your Majesty,” said Two, in a very humble tone, going down on one knee as he spoke, “we were trying—”
Manx: “My sailliu, Venrein Ooasle,” dooyrt Jees feer imlee as eshyn goll sheese er un ghlioon tra v’eh loayrt, “va shin prowal — ”

English: “I see!” said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses.
Manx: “Ta mish toiggal!” dooyrt y Venrein, va er ve goaill baght jeh ny roseyn.

English: “Off with their heads!” and the procession moved on, three of the soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
Manx: “Ersooyl lesh ny king oc!” as dimmee y chosheeaght roish, faagail troor dy hidooryn va goll dy varroo ny gareyderyn treih, ren roie gys Ealish as ad shirrey coadey.

English: “You shan’t be beheaded!” said Alice, and she put them into a large flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the others.
Manx: “Cha bee ny king eu giarrit jiu!” dooyrt Ealish, as hug ee ad ayns crockan-blaa mooar va faggys jee. Ren ny tree sidooryn rouail mygeayrt son minnid ny jees, shirrey ad, as eisht ren ad cosheeaght dy feagh er oaie lurg ny fir elley.

English: “Are their heads off?” shouted the Queen.
Manx: “Vel ny king oc ersooyl?” dyllee y Venrein.

English: “Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!” the soldiers shouted in reply.
Manx: “Ta ny king oc ersooyl, my sailliu, Venrein Ooasie!” dyllee ny sidooryn myr freggyrt.

English: “That’s right!” shouted the Queen. “Can you play croquet?”
Manx: “Shen kiart!” dyllee y Venrein. “Vod oo cloie croquet?”

English: The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was evidently meant for her.
Manx: Va ny sidooryn nyn dost, as yeeagh ad er Ealish, er y fa dy row eh baghtal dy row y feysht er ny vriaght jeeish.

English: “Yes!” shouted Alice.
Manx: “Foddym!” dyllee Ealish.

English: “Come on, then!” roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.
Manx: “Hooin roin eisht!” wuirroogh y Venrein, as hie Ealish stiagh marish y chosheeaght as ish smooinaghtyn dy jeean cre haghyragh lurg shoh.

English: “It’s—it’s a very fine day!” said a timid voice at her side.
Manx: “She - she laa feer vraew t’ayn!” dooyrt coraa faitagh ec y lhiattee eck.

English: She was walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.
Manx: V’ee shooyl marish y Chonning Vane, va peeikearagh dy h-imneagh syn eddin eck.

English: “Very,” said Alice: “—where’s the Duchess?”
Manx: “She, dy jarroo,” dooyrt Ealish. “C’raad ta’n Vendiuic?”

English: “Hush! Hush!” said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered “She’s under sentence of execution.”a
Manx: “Tostid, my sailt!” dooyrt y Chonning dy h-injil as dy siyragh. Yeeagh eh dy h-imneagh harrish e gheaylin myr loayr eh, as eisht hrog eh eh hene er baare e ordaagyn-coshey, hug eh e veeal faggys da’n chleaysh eck, as dooyrt eh myr sannish “T’ee fo deyrey baaish.”

English: “What for?” said Alice.
Manx: “Cre’n fa?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Did you say ‘What a pity!’?” the Rabbit asked.
Manx: “Dooyrt oo ‘Atreih!’?” vrie y Chonning.

English: “No, I didn’t,” said Alice: “I don’t think it’s at all a pity. I said ‘What for?’”
Manx: “Cha dooyrt,” dooyrt Ealish. “Cha nel shen treih er chor erbee. Dooyrt mish ‘Cre’n fa?’”

English: “She boxed the Queen’s ears—” the Rabbit began. Alice gave a little scream of laughter. “Oh, hush!” the Rabbit whispered in a frightened tone. “The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said—”
Manx: “Hug ee bassag da cleayshyn y Venrein —" ghow y Chonning toshiaght. Lhig Ealish magh screeagh beg dy ghearey. “Oh, tostid!” hannish y Chonning as aggle er. “Cluinnee y Venrein oo! T’ou toiggal, haink ee beggan anmagh, as dooyrt y Venrein —"

English: “Get to your places!” shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began.
Manx: “Gow-jee gys ny h-ynnydyn euish!” dyllee y Venrein goll rish taarnagh, as ghow sleih toshiaght dy roie noon as noal, as ad gymmylt ry cheilley: aghterbee, haink smaght orroo ayns minnid ny ghaa, as va’n gamman fo raad.

English: Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.
Manx: Heill Ealish nagh row ee rieau er nakin faaie-croquet cho quaagh sy vea eck: va oirragyn as creaghyn ass towse ayn: she arkanyn-sonney bio va ny bluckanyn-croquet, as she lossyraneyn bio va ny thornaneyn, as beign da ny sidooryn ad hene y ghoobley as shassoo er nyn laueyn as cassyn, dy yannoo ny h-aaeghyn.

English: The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo: she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head, it would twist itself round and look up in her face, with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself, and was in the act of crawling away:
Manx: Hoshiaght, y chied doilleeid ec Ealish, va shen cur smaght er y lossyrane eck: haink eh lhee cur e chorp, aashagh dy liooar, fo'n roih eck, as e lurgaghyn croghey sheese, agh, dy cliaghtagh, kiart myr va'n mwannal echey er ny yeeraghey eck as v'ee er chee bwoalley yn arkan sonney lesh e chione, veagh eh cassey eh hene mygeayrt as jeeaghyn seose ayns e h-eddin er aght cho boirit as nagh dod ee jannoo fegooish tuittym er garaghtee; as tra veagh e chione currit sheese eck reesht, as veagh ee er chee goaill toshiaght reesht, veagh ee brasnit dy mooar dy 'eddyn magh dy beagh yn arkan sonney neu-rowlit as er chee snaue ersooyl:

English: besides all this, there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.
Manx: as, ny sodjey na shoh, dy cliaghtagh veagh oirrag ny creagh raad erbee veagh ee laccal cur yn arkan sonney huggey, as, myr veagh ny sidooryn dooblit kinjagh girree seose as shooyl gys buill elley er y faaie, hoig Ealish feer tappee dy nee gamman feer doillee v’ayn dy jarroo.

English: The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.
Manx: Va ny cloiederyn ooilley cloie ec yn un cheayrt, gyn fuirraghtyn rish shayllyn, as ad tuittym magh car y traa, as jannoo caggey son ny h-arkanyn sonney; ayns traa feer gherrid, va eulys agglagh er y Venrein, va stampey mygeayrt as gyllagh magh “Ersooyl lesh e chione!" ny "Ersooyl lesh e kione!" red goll rish un cheayrt gagh minnid.

English: Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, “and then,” thought she, “what would become of me? They’re dreadfully fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there’s any one left alive!”
Manx: Va imnea mooar cheet er Ealish: son shickyrys, cha row ee er duittym magh lesh y Venrein foast, agh va fys eck dy noddagh eh taghyrt ec traa erbee, “as eisht,” smooinee ish, “cre’n erree harragh orrym? T'ad feer ghraihagh er giarrey ny king jeh sleih ayns shoh: t’eh ny yindys mooar dy vel peiagh erbee faagit bio!”

English: She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself “It’s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.”
Manx: V'ee shirrey aght ennagh dy scapail, as sheiltyn beagh ee abyl gimmeeaght magh ass gyn ve fakinit, tra hug ee my ner red ennagh quaagh syn aer: v’eh cur urree ve boirit hoshiaght, agh erreish jee v’er yeeaghyn er son minnid ny ghaa, honnick ee dy nee gyrn v'ayn, as dooyrt ee ree hene “She yn Kayt-Cheshire t’ayn: nish bee peiagh ennagh aym dy haggloo rish.”

English: “How are you getting on?” said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
Manx: “Kys t’ou?” dooyrt y Kayt cho leah’s va beeal dy liooar ayn dy loayrt lesh.

English: Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded.
Manx: Duirree Ealish gys haink ny sooillyn rish, as eisht snog ee.

English: “It’s no use speaking to it,” she thought, “till its ears have come, or at least one of them.”
Manx: “Cha nel eh feeu dy loayrt rish,” smooinee ish, “derrey vees ny cleayshyn echey er jeet, ny nane jeu er y chooid sloo.”

English: In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her.
Manx: Ayns minnid elley, va'n slane chione er jeet rish, as eisht hug Ealish sheese e lossyrane, as ghow ee toshiaght dy insh mychione y gamman as ish feer wooiagh dy row peiagh ayn dy eaishtagh ree.

English: The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.
Manx: V'eh jeeaghyn dy row y Kayt smooinaghtyn dy row dy liooar jeh ayns shilley nish, as cha daink ny smoo jeh rish.

English: “I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak —and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them —and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground — and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”
Manx: “Cha nel mee smooinaghtyn dy vel ad cloie dy cairal noadyr,” ghow Ealish toshiaght, beggan goll rish accanagh, “as t’ad ooilley jannoo arganys cho agglagh as nagh vod oo clashtyn oo hene loayrt - as cha nel eh jeeaghyn dy vel reillyn erbee oc: er y chooid sloo, my ta reillyn oc, cha nel peiagh erbee cur geill erbee daue - as cha nod oo toiggal yn aght t’eh cur ort ve fud y cheilley, yn aght dy vel ny reddyn shen bio: myr sampleyr, yn aae shegin dou goll trooid y nah cheayrt, t'eh shooyl mygeayrt ec y chione elley jeh'n faaie - as lhisins er chroquetal arkan sonney y Venrein er y gherrit, agh roie eh ersooyl tra honnick eh dy row y fer ayms cheet!”

English: “How do you like the Queen?” said the Cat in a low voice.
Manx: “C’red t’ou coontey jeh’n Venrein?” dooyrt y Kayt ayns coraa injl.

English: “Not at all,” said Alice: “she’s so extremely —” Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, “— likely to win, that it’s hardly worth while finishing the game.”
Manx: “Cha mie lhiam ee,” dooyrt Ealish: “t’ee feer — “Kiart ec y traa shen, hug ee my ner dy row y Venrein feer faggys jee, cooyl eck as ish geaishtagh: myr shen, hie ee er “ — liklee dy chosney y varriaght, as cha nel eh feeu dy chur kione er y ghamman.”

English: The Queen smiled and passed on.
Manx: Vong y Venrein as hie ee roee.

English: “Who are you talking to?” said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat’s head with great curiosity.
Manx: “Quoi t'ou loayrt rish?" dooyrt y Ree as eh cheet lesh Ealish as jeeaghyn seose er kione y Chayt feer pheeikearagh.

English: “It’s a friend of mine — a Cheshire Cat,” said Alice: “allow me to introduce it.”
Manx: “She carrey lhiams t’ayn — Kayt-Cheshire,” dooyrt Ealish: “lhig dou cur eh er enney diu.”

English: “I don’t like the look of it at all,” said the King: “however, it may kiss my hand if it likes.”
Manx: “Cha mie lhiam e chummey noadyr," dooyrt y Ree: "aghterbee, foddee eh my laue y phaagey, my s'mian lesh."

English: “I’d rather not,” the Cat remarked.
Manx: “Bare lhiam dyn shen y yannoo,” dooyrt y Kayt.

English: “Don’t be impertinent,” said the King, “and don’t look at me like that!” He got behind Alice as he spoke.
Manx: “Ny bee mee-arrymagh," dooyrt y Ree, "as ny jeeagh orrym myr shen!" Hie eh cheu-heear jeh Ealish myr v'eh loayrt.

English: “A cat may look at a king,” said Alice. “I’ve read that in some book, but I don’t remember where.”
Manx: “Foddee kayt jeeaghyn er ree,” dooyrt Ealish. “Ta mee er lhaih shen ayns lioar ennagh, agh cha gooin lhiam c’raad.”

English: “Well, it must be removed,” said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, “My dear! I wish you would have this cat removed!”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, shegin da ve scughit,” dooyrt y Ree lesh shickyrys mooar; as dyllee eh rish y Venrein va goll shaghey ec y traa shen, “Saillym dy derragh oo er peiagh ennagh y kayt shoh y scughey magh ass, veen!”

English: The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. “Off with his head!” she said, without even looking round.
Manx: Cha row agh un aght ec y Venrein dy chiartaghey gagh doilleeid, mooar ny beg. “Ersooyl lesh e chione!” dooyrt ee fegooish jeeaghyn mygeayrt.

English: “I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.
Manx: “Verym lhiam y marrooder mish hene,” dooyrt y Ree dy jeean, as ersooyl lesh dy bieau.

English: Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion.
Manx: Heill Ealish dy beagh eh chammah jee goll erash as fakin cre’n aght va’n gamman goll er, er y fa dy geayll ee coraa y Venrein sy foddid as ish screeaghey dy h-eulyssagh.

English: She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not.
Manx: Hannah, v’ee er chlashtyn dy gheyr ee troor jeh ny cloiederyn gy baase son coayl nyn shayllyn, as cha bynney lhee yn aght va reddyn goll, er y fa dy row y gamman cho fud y cheilley as nagh row rieau fys eck row e shayll ayn ny dyn.

English: So she went in search of her hedgehog.
Manx: Myr shen, hie ee dy hirrey lurg e h-arkan sonney.

English: The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other:
Manx: Va’n arkan sonney caggey rish arkan sonney elley, as va Ealish coontey shoh dy ve ny chaa feer vie dy chroquetal nane jeu marish y fer elley:

English: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.
Manx: yn ynrican doilleeid, va shen dy row y lossyrane eck ersooyl gys y cheu elley jeh’n gharey, raad oddagh Ealish fakin eh as eh prowal er aght moal dy etlagh seose ayns billey.

English: By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: “but it doesn’t matter much,” thought Alice, “as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.”
Manx: Tra v’ee er dayrtyn y lossyrane as er chur lhee eh erash, va'n caggey harrish, as va'n daa arkan sonney ass shilley: “agh s'cummey shen,” smooinee Ealish, “er y fa dy vel ooilley ny aaeghyn ersooyl veih’n cheu shoh jeh'n faaie.”

English: So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.
Manx: Myr shen, hug ee eh fo'n aghlish eck er aght nagh dod eh scapail reesht, as hie ee erash dy ghoaill cowag veg elley marish e carrey.

English: When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
Manx: Tra hie ee erash gys y Chayt-Cheshire, va yindys urree tra hooar ee magh dy row chionnal mooar mygeayrt y mysh: va arganys goll er eddyr y varrooder, y Ree, as y Venrein, va ooilley taggloo ec yn un cheayrt, choud's va ny fir elley nyn dost dy bollagh as jeeaghyn feer vee-gherjoilagh.

English: The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.
Manx: Cho leah’s haink Ealish ree, ren y troor aghin jee y feysht y ’eaysley, as docklee ad nyn arganyssyn ree reesht, agh, er yn oyr dy loayr ad ooilley ec yn un cheayrt, v'eh feer doillee dy hoiggal dy kiart c’red v’ad gra.

English: The executioner’s argument was, that you couldn’t cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn’t going to begin at his time of life.
Manx: Arganys y varrooder, va shen nagh noddagh oo giarrey kione veih corp mannagh row corp ayn dy yiarrey eh veih: nagh row rieau er jannoo y lheid roie, as nagh row eh kiarail goaill toshiaght ec yn eash echeysyn.

English: The King’s argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren’t to talk nonsense.
Manx: Arganys y Ree, va shen dy ghra dy noddagh oo giarrey kione veih red erbee as kione echey, as cha lhisagh oo loayrt boghtynid.

English: The Queen’s argument was, that if something wasn’t done about it in less than no time she’d have everybody executed, all round.
Manx: Arganys y Venrein, va shen dy ghra mannagh row red ennagh jeant my e chione ayns traa ny sloo na veg, veagh ee cur er dy chooilley pheiagh dy ve currit gy baase.

English: (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
Manx: (She y raa s’jerree shoh hug er y clane cheshaght jeeaghyn cho fastagh as imneagh.)

English: Alice could think of nothing else to say but “It belongs to the Duchess: you’d better ask her about it.”
Manx: Cha dod Ealish smooinaght er red erbee elley dy ghra agh “S’lesh y Vendiuic eh: bare diu briaght jeeish my e chione.”

English: “She’s in prison,” the Queen said to the executioner: “fetch her here.”
Manx: “T’ee ayns pryssoon,” dooyrt y Venrein rish y varrooder: “cur lhiat ee gys shoh.”

English: And the executioner went off like an arrow.
Manx: As ersooyl lesh y varrooder goll rish side.

English: The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.
Manx: Ghow kione y Chayt toshiaght dy 'ioghey ersooyl cho leah’s v’eh ersooyl, as, liorish y traa v’eh er jeet erash marish y Vendiuic, v’eh er skellal roish dy bollagh: myr shen, roie y Ree as y marrooder noon as noal dy keoi, dy hirrey, choud’s va’n chooid elley jeh'n çheshaght goll erash gys y gamman.

English: CHAPTER IX.
Manx: CABDYL 9

English: The Mock Turtle’s Story
Manx: Skeeal y Far-Ligganagh Marrey

English: “You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.
Manx: “Cha nod oo toiggal cre cho bwooiagh as ta mee dy ’akin oo reesht, my henn charrey veen!” dooyrt y Vendiuic, myr v’ee cur e laue dy graihagh ayns uillin Ealish, as hooill ad ersooyl ry cheilley.

English: Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.
Manx: Va Ealish feer wooiagh dy row ee ayns gien cho mie, as smooinee ish ree hene foddee dy nee yn pibbyr ny lomarcan va cur urree ve cho oaldey tra haink ad nyn guaiyl sy chamyr-aarlee.

English: “When I’m a Duchess,” she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), “I won’t have any pepper in my kitchen at all.
Manx: “Traa veeyms my Vendiuic,” dooyrt ee ree hene (agh cha nee ayns coraa feer treishteilagh) “cha bee pibbyr erbee sy chamyr-aarlee aym noadyr.

English: Soup does very well without — Maybe it’s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,” she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, “and vinegar that makes them sour — and camomile that makes them bitter — and — and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered.
Manx: Ta awree jannoo feer vie n'egooish - Foddee she pibbyr ta kinjagh cur er sleih ve eulyssagh,” hie ee er, as ish jeant feer wooiagh dy row ee er ngeddyn sorch noa dy reill, “as feeyn geayr ta cur orroo ve geayr — as fennel ny moddee ta cur orroo ve sharroo — as — as shugyr oarn ta cur er paitchyn ve soccaragh.

English: I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn’t be so stingy about it, you know —”
Manx: Dy row fys ec sleih er shen, ta mish dy ghuee: eisht cha beagh ad cho peajeogagh my e chione, ta fys ayd —”

English: She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear.
Manx: V’ee er nyarrood y Vendiuic dy bollagh liorish y traa shoh, as v’ee currit er moostey beggan tra cheayll ee e coraa faggys da'n chleaysh eck.

English: “You’re thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk.
Manx: “T'ou smooinaghtyn er red ennagh, veen, as ta shen cur ort dy yarrood dy loayrt.

English: I can’t tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.”
Manx: Cha noddym ginsh dhyt kiart nishtagh c’red ta’n voraltaght jeh shen, agh bee cooinaghtyn aym ayns tammylt.”

English: “Perhaps it hasn’t one,” Alice ventured to remark.
Manx: “Foddee nagh vel moraltaght echey,” va Ealish daaney dy liooar dy ghra.

English: “Tut, tut, child!” said the Duchess. “Everything’s got a moral, if only you can find it.”
Manx: “Eaisht, eaisht, phaitchey!” dooyrt y Vendiuic. “Ta moraltaght ec dy chooilley red, choud’s t’ou abyl feddyn eh.”

English: And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice’s side as she spoke.
Manx: As hraast ee ee hene ny sniessey da lhiattee Ealish myr v’ee loayrt.

English: Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was very ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice’s shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.
Manx: Cha by vie lesh Ealish ve cho faggys jee: hoshiaght, er y fa dy row y Vendiuic feer ghraney; as y nah red, er y fa dy row ee dy jeeragh yn yrjid kiart dy lhiggey da'n smeg eck lhie er geaylin Ealish, as she smeg vee-gherjoilagh, virragh v'ayn. Agh cha bynney lhee ve neu-chooyrtoil: myr shen, v'ee jannoo lesh chammah as oddagh ee.

English: “The game’s going on rather better now,” she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.
Manx: “Ta’n gamman goll er beggan ny share nish,” dooyrt ee, as ish freayll y coloayrtys fo raad, beggan.

English: “’Tis so,” said the Duchess: “and the moral of that is —‘Oh, ’tis love, ’tis love, that makes the world go round!’”
Manx: “Shen eh,” dooyrt y Vendiuic: “as ta’n voraltaght jeh shen — ‘Ogh, she yn graih, yn graih, ta cur er yn teihll chyndaa!

English: “Somebody said,” Alice whispered, “that it’s done by everybody minding their own business!”
Manx: “Dooyrt peiagh ennagh,” hannish Ealish, “dy vel shen jeant liorish dy chooilley pheiagh as eh cur geill da ny cooishyn echey hene!”

English: “Ah, well! It means much the same thing,” said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice’s shoulder as she added, “and the moral of that is — ‘Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of themselves.’”
Manx: “Dy jarroo! Ta shen bunnys yn un red,” dooyrt y Vendiuic as ish puttey e smeg veg virragh stiagh ayns geaylin Ealish myr loayr ee ny sodjey “as taʼn voraltaght jeh shen- ‘Cur geill da'n cheeall, as ver ny sheeanyn geill dauesyn hene.”

English: “How fond she is of finding morals in things!” Alice thought to herself.
Manx: “Nagh mie lhee feddyn moraltaght ayns gagh red!” smooinee Ealish ree hene.

English: “I dare say you’re wondering why I don’t put my arm round your waist,” the Duchess said after a pause: “the reason is, that I’m doubtful about the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?”
Manx: “Yiarrins dy vel oo smooinaghtyn cre’n fa nagh vel mee cur my roih mygeayrt dty vouin,” dooyrt y Vendiuic, lurg sthap: “she yn oyr er shen dy vel drogh-ourys aym er tappey dty lossyrane. Jeanym prowal feddyn magh cre haghyrys?”

English: “He might bite,” Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.
Manx: “Foddee dy jean eh greimmey,” dreggyr Ealish dy twoaieagh as ish neu-arryltagh dy ’eddyn magh cre haghyragh.

English: “Very true,” said the Duchess: “flamingoes and mustard both bite.
Manx: “S’feer shen,” dooyrt y Vendiuic: “lossyraneyn as mustart, ta’n jees jeu greimmey.

English: And the moral of that is—‘Birds of a feather flock together.’”
Manx: As shoh y voraltaght jeh shen- ‘Myr s’doo y feeagh, yiow eh sheshey’”

English: “Only mustard isn’t a bird,” Alice remarked.
Manx: “Agh cha nee ushag mustart,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Right, as usual,” said the Duchess: “what a clear way you have of putting things!”
Manx: “Kiart, myr dy cliaghtagh,” dooyrt y Vendiuic: “nagh cronnal yn aght t’ou soilshaghey magh reddyn!”

English: “It’s a mineral, I think,” said Alice.
Manx: “She stoo meainagh t’ayn, er lhiam,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Of course it is,” said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said; “there’s a large mustard-mine near here.
Manx: “She, son shickyrys,” dooyrt y Vendiuic, va sheiltyn dy ve arryltagh dy ve ayns coardailys rish dy chooilley nhee va grait ec Ealish: "ta meain-vustart vooar faggys dys shoh.

English: And the moral of that is—‘The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.’”
Manx: As ta’n voraltaght jeh shen — Myr smoo y veain ayms, sloo y veain ayds!”

English: “Oh, I know!” exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark,
Manx: “Ogh, ta fys aym!” dooyrt Ealish, nagh dug geill da'n raa sjerree shoh.

English: “it’s a vegetable. It doesn’t look like one, but it is.”
Manx: “She losserey t’ayn. Cha nel eh jeeaghyn goll rish, agh shen myr t’eh.”

English: “I quite agree with you,” said the Duchess; “and the moral of that is—‘Be what you would seem to be’—or if you’d like it put more simply —
Manx: “Ta mee ayns slane coardailys rhyt,” dooyrt y Vendiuic; “as ta’n voraltaght jeh shen – ‘Bee ny t’ou sheiltyn dy ve’ — ny, my s’mie lhiat eh y ghra er aght sassey –

English: ‘Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.’”
Manx: ‘Ny jean dy bragh sheiltyn oo hene dyn y ve myr veagh oo jeeaghyn, foddee, rish fir elley dy nee y red v’ou uss ny foddee dy row uss er ve nagh row red elley cosoyllit rish y red veagh oo er ve jeeaghyn goll rish roosyn er aght elley.’”

English: “I think I should understand that better,” Alice said very politely, “if I had it written down: but I can’t quite follow it as you say it.”
Manx: “Er lhiams dy doiggins shen ny share," dooyrt Ealish feer chooyrtoil, “dy beagh eh screeut sheese dou: agh cha noddym toiggal eh as eh grait ayds.”

English: “That’s nothing to what I could say if I chose,” the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.
Manx: “Cha nel shen veg cosoyllit rish ny reddyn oddins gra dy beigns laccal eh,” dreggyr y Vendiuic as ish jeant bwooiagh.

English: “Pray don’t trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,” said Alice.
Manx: “Ta mee guee ort dyn y voirey ort as uss gra eh ny s’lhiurey na shen,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Oh, don’t talk about trouble!” said the Duchess. “I make you a present of everything I’ve said as yet.”
Manx: “Ogh, ny loayr mychione boirey!” dooyrt y Vendiuic. “Gagh red ta grait aym choud’s shoh, ta mee jannoo gioot jeh er dty hon.”

English: “A cheap sort of present!” thought Alice.
Manx: “Sorch neu-gheyr dy yioot!” smooinee Ealish.

English: “I’m glad they don’t give birthday presents like that!” But she did not venture to say it out loud.
Manx: “S’mie lhiam nagh vel feallagh cur giootyn laa-ruggyree myr shen!” Agh cha row ee daaney dy liooar dy ghra eh er ard.

English: “Thinking again?” the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.
Manx: “Smooinaghtyn reesht?” vrie y Vendiuic, as ren ee puttey reesht lesh e smeg veg virragh.

English: “I’ve a right to think,” said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.
Manx: “Ta cair aym smooinaghtyn,” dooyrt Ealish dy geayr, er yn oyr dy row ee cheet dy ve beggan boirit.

English: “Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m —”
Manx: “Mysh y cair cheddin as t’ec ny muic dy etlagh,” dooyrt y Vendiuic, “as shegin da ny muic etlagh; as ta’n v—”

English: But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble.
Manx: Lheie coraa y Vendiuic ersooyl eisht, eer sy vean jeh’n ’ockle ennoil eck ‘moraltaght’, as hug shoh yindys mooar er Ealish, as y roih v'ayns uillin Ealish, ghow ee toshiaght dy chraa.

English: Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
Manx: Yeeagh Ealish seose, as va’n Venrein ny shassoo rhymboo as e roihaghyn fillit as ish grouigey goll rish sterrym-taarnee.

English: “A fine day, your Majesty!” the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.
Manx: “Laa braew, Venrein ooasle!” ghow y Vendiuic toshiaght ayns coraa injil as faase.

English: “Now, I give you fair warning,” shouted the Queen, stamping on the ground as she spoke; “either you or your head must be off, and that in about half no time! Take your choice!”
Manx: “Nish, ta mee cur raaue cairagh dhyt,” dyllee y Venrein magh as ish stampey er y thalloo myr v’ee loayrt; “uss hene, ny dty chione, shegin da immeeaght nish jeeragh, as shen ayns red goll rish y lieh ayrn jeh veg dy hraa! Jean dty reih!”

English: The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
Manx: Ren y Vendiuic e reih as ersooyl lhee ayns shallid.

English: “Let’s go on with the game,” the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.
Manx: “Hooin roin lesh y ghamman," dooyrt y Venrein rish Ealish; as va Ealish wheesh agglit as nagh dooyrt ee veg, agh deiyr ee urree dy moal, erash gys y faaie-croquet.

English: The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen’s absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment’s delay would cost them their lives.
Manx: Va ny goaldee elley er nymmydey assairaght y Venrein as v’ad goaill fea sy scaa: agh, cho leah's honnick ad ee, hiyree ad erash gys y gamman, lurg da’n Venrein gra dy gaillagh ad nyn mea dy beagh lhiggey-traa erbee ayn.

English: All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!”
Manx: Ooilley yn traa v’ad cloie, va’n Venrein kinjagh tuittym magh lesh ny cloiederyn elley as gyllagh “Ersooyl lesh e chione!” ny “Ersooyl lesh e kione!”

English: Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and under sentence of execution.
Manx: Ad shid va deyrit eck, v'ad goit ec ny sidooryn, va eginit shaghney ve nyn aaeghyn dy yannoo shoh, as, lurg red goll rish lieh oor, cha row aaeghyn erbee faagit, as va ooilley ny cloiederyn goit as deyrit gy baase, er lhimmey jeh'n Ree, y Venrein, as Ealish.

English: Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, “Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?”
Manx: Eisht ren y Venrein cur seose as ish slane ass ennal, as dooyrt ee rish Ealish “Vel oo er nakin y Far-Ligganagh Marrey foast?”

English: “No,” said Alice. “I don’t even know what a Mock Turtle is.”
Manx: “Cha nel,” dooyrt Ealish. “Dy jarroo, cha nel fys erbee ayms c’red ta Far-Ligganagh Marrey.”

English: “It’s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,” said the Queen.
Manx: “Shen y red ta Awree Far-Ligganagh Marrey jeant ass,” dooyrt y Venrein.

English: “I never saw one, or heard of one,” said Alice.
Manx: “Cha vaik mee rieau nane ny cha geayll mee my nyn gione,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Come on, then,” said the Queen, “and he shall tell you his history,”
Manx: “Hooin rooin, myr shen,” dooyrt y Venrein, “as inshee eh e skeeal dhyt.”

English: As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally, “You are all pardoned.”
Manx: Myr v’ad shooyl ry cheilley, cheayll Ealish dy dooyrt y Ree ayns coraa injil rish y clane cheshaght, “Ta shiu ooilley pardoonit.”

English: “Come, that’s a good thing!” she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
Manx: “Dy jarroo, shen ny red mie!” dooyrt ee ree hene, er y fa nagh by vie lhee yn earroo dy ’leih va deyrit gy baase ec y Venrein.

English: They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.)
Manx: Feer gherrid, haink ad er Gryphon va ny lhie ny chadley ayns soilshey y laa. (Mannagh nhione dhyt cre gollrish ta Gryphon, jeeagh er y jalloo.)

English: “Up, lazy thing!” said the Queen, “and take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history.
Manx: “Seose lhiat, chretoor litcheragh!" dooyrt y Venrein, “as cur lhiat y ven aeg shoh lesh shilley er y Far-Ligganagh Marrey as dy chlashtyn e skeeal.

English: I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;” and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon.
Manx: Shegin dou goll erash as fakin dy vel paart dy ’leih currit gy baase liorish yn oardagh aym;” as hie ee roee, faagail Ealish ny lomarcan marish y Gryphon.

English: Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.
Manx: Cha row Ealish coontey monney jeh cummey y chretoor, agh, er y chooid smoo, v'ee coontey eh dy ve kiart cho sauchey dy hannaghtyn marish as dy gholl geiyrt er y Venrein oaldey shen: myr shen, hannee ish.

English: The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled.
Manx: Hoie y Gryphon seose as rub eh e hooillyn: eisht, v’eh jeeaghyn er y Venrein gys v’ee ass shilley: eisht ren eh gearey dy feagh.

English: “What fun!” said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.
Manx: “Cre’n spoyrt!” dooyrt y Gryphon, lieh rish hene, lieh rish Ealish.

English: “What is the fun?” said Alice.
Manx: “C’red ta’n spoyrt?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Why, she,” said the Gryphon. “It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!”
Manx: “Cammah, ish hene,” dooyrt y Gryphon. “Shen y farskeealeraght ecksh: cha nel ad cur peiagh erbee gy baase, ta fys ayd. Hooin roin!”

English: “Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”
Manx: “Ta dy chooilley pheiagh gra ‘hooin roin!’ ayns shoh,” smooinee Ealish as ish geiyrt er dy moal: “cha row mee rieau er my oardaghey wheesh roie!”

English: They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock,
Manx: Cha row ad er ngoll foddey derrey honnick ad y Far-Ligganagh Marrey as eh ny hoie sy foddid, trimshagh as fadaneagh er oirr beg dy chreg.

English: and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break.
Manx: Myr v’ad cheet ny sniessey da, oddagh Ealish clashtyn dy row eh gosnaghey myr dy beagh e chree brisht.

English: She pitied him deeply.
Manx: Va chymmey mooar eck er.

English: “What is his sorrow?” she asked the Gryphon,
Manx: “Cre’n trimshey ta jannoo er?” vrie ee jeh’n Ghryphon.

English: and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, “It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!”
Manx: As dreggyr y Gryphon lesh ny goan cheddin as roie, bunnys, “Shen ooilley y farskeealeraght echey: cha nel trimshey erbee jannoo er. Hooin roin!”

English: So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.
Manx: Myr shen, hie ad gys y Far-Ligganagh Marrey, ren jeeaghyn orroo lesh sooillyn mooarey lane dy yeir, agh cha dooyrt eh veg.

English: “This here young lady,” said the Gryphon, “she wants for to know your history, she do.”
Manx: “Y ven aeg shoh,” dooyrt y Gryphon, “by vie lhee clashtyn y skeeal ayd, shen y red t’ee laccal.”

English: “I’ll tell it her,” said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: “sit down, both of you, and don’t speak a word till I’ve finished.”
Manx: “Inshym eh jee,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey ayns coraa dowin as mooghit. “Soie-jee sheese, y jees jiu, as nagh abbyr-jee fockle derrey veeym jeant.”

English: So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself, “I don’t see how he can ever finish, if he doesn’t begin.” But she waited patiently.
Manx: Hoie ad sheese as cha loayr peiagh erbee son paart dy vinnidyn. Smooinee Ealish ree hene “Cha noddym toiggal cre'n aght oddys eh dy bragh cur kione er mannagh vees eh goaill toshiaght.” Agh duirree ish dy surransagh.

English: “Once,” said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, “I was a real Turtle.”
Manx: “Keayrt dy row,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey fy yerrey, lesh osney mooar, “va mee my Ligganagh Marrey kiart.”

English: These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of “Hjckrrh!” from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle.
Manx: Haink tostid feer liauyr lurg ny goan shoh. Nish as reesht, va'n tostid brisht ec yllagh jeh “Hjckrrh!” veih'n Ghryphon, as y soghal trome gyn scuirr va jeant ec y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, “Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,” but she could not help thinking there must be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.
Manx: Car y traa, va Ealish bunnys er chee troggal urree as gra “Gura mie eu, Vainstyr, son y skeeal feer anaasagh eu." agh cha dod ee jannoo fegooish smooinaghtyn dy beagh tooilley cheet, as myr shen ren ee tannaghtyn ny soie, dyn gra veg.

English: “When we were little,” the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, “we went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle — we used to call him Tortoise—”
Manx: “Tra va shin beg,” hie y Far-Ligganagh Marrey er fy yerrey, ny s'kiuney, ga dy row eh soghal beggan nish as reesht foast, “hie shin dys y scoill sy cheayn. She shenn Ligganagh Marrey va’n mainstyr — veagh shin gra Yndyragh rish —

English: “Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?” Alice asked.
Manx: “Cre’n fa va shiu gra Yndyragh rish mannagh row eh ny yndyragh?” vrie Ealish.

English: “We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle angrily: “really you are very dull!”
Manx: “Va shin gra Yndyragh rish er y fa dy row eh gynsaghey dooin,” dooyrt y Far Ligganagh Marrey dy fergagh. “Dy firrinagh, t’ou uss moal agglagh!”

English: “You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,” added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth.
Manx: “Lhisagh oo goaill nearey jeed hene son briaght feysht cho aashagh as shen,” dooyrt y Gryphon; as eisht va'n jees jeu nyn dost, as v’ad jeeaghyn er Ealish voght, va guee dy 'luggagh y seihll ee seose.

English: At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, “Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!” and he went on in these words:
Manx: Fy yerrey dooyrt y Gryphon rish y Far-Ligganagh Marrey “Jean imman er oaie, ghooinney veen! Ny gow y slane laa!”, as hie eh er lesh ny goan shoh:—

English: “Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—”
Manx: “She, hie shin dys y scoill sy cheayn, ga nagh jean oo credjal eh, foddee –“

English: “I never said I didn’t!” interrupted Alice.
Manx: “Cha ren mee rieau gra shen!” vrish Ealish stiagh er.

English: “You did,” said the Mock Turtle.
Manx: “Ren,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “Hold your tongue!” added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.
Manx: “Cum dty hengey!” dooyrt y Gryphon, roish my oddagh Ealish loayrt reesht. Hie y Far-Ligganagh Marrey er.

English: “We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—”
Manx: “Va’n edjaghys share ain — dy jarroo, hie shin dys y scoill gagh laa—”

English: “I’ve been to a day-school, too,” said Alice; “you needn’t be so proud as all that.”
Manx: “Ta mish er ve ec scoill-laa neesht,” dooyrt Ealish. “Cha lhiass dhyt ve cho moyrnagh ass, ta fys ayd.”

English: “With extras?” asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.
