Manx: “Lesh ynsagh-sheeyney, ta shen dy ghra, stoo brash?” vrie y Far-Ligganagh Marrey, beggan imneagh.

English: “Yes,” said Alice, “we learned French and music.”
Manx: “She,” dooyrt Ealish: “va shin gynsaghey Frangish as kiaulleeaght.”

English: “And washing?” said the Mock Turtle.
Manx: “As nhiee?” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “Certainly not!” said Alice indignantly.
Manx: “Cha nee, son shickyrys!” dooyrt Ealish dy jymmoosagh.

English: “Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school,” said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief.
Manx: “Dy jarroo! Cha row y scoill ayds ny scoill chiart eisht,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey as eh feayslit veih imnea.

English: “Now at ours they had at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, and washing —extra.’”
Manx: Nish, ec y scoill ainyn, ec y jerrey jeh'n choontey-argid, va ‘Frangish, kiaulleeaght, as nhiee - stoo brash.’

English: “You couldn’t have wanted it much,” said Alice; “living at the bottom of the sea.”
Manx: “Gyn ourys cha row uss ayns feme mooar jeh,” dooyrt Ealish, “as uss cummal ec bun ny marrey.”

English: “I couldn’t afford to learn it.” said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. “I only took the regular course.”
Manx: “Cha dod mee fordrail gynsaghey eh,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey lesh osney. “Cha ghow mish agh y coorse reiltagh.”

English: “What was that?” inquired Alice.
Manx: “Cre va shen?” denee Ealish.

English: “Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,” the Mock Turtle replied; “and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.”
Manx: “Lheie as Screebey dy ghoaill toshiaght, dy dooghyssagh,” dreggyr y Far-Ligganagh Marrey; “as eisht ny banganyn jeh Earrooaght - Curhuggaght, Gowhuggaght, Bishaght as Rheynnaght.”

English: “I never heard of ‘Uglification,’” Alice ventured to say. “What is it?”
Manx: “Cha geayll mee rieau mychione ‘Bishaght’,” va Ealish daaney dy liooar dy vriaght. “Cre shen?”

English: The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. “What! Never heard of uglifying!” it exclaimed. “You know what to beautify is, I suppose?”
Manx: Hrog y Gryphon seose e ghaa spaaig as yindys er. "Nagh geayll oo rieau mychione bishaghey!" docklee eh magh. "T'ou toiggal beggaghey, ta mee sheiltyn?”

English: “Yes,” said Alice doubtfully: “it means —to — make — anything — prettier.”
Manx: “Ta,” dooyrt Ealish dy h-ouryssagh: “ta’n bun jeh shen — dy — yannoo — red erbee — ny sloo.”

English: “Well, then,” the Gryphon went on, “if you don’t know what to uglify is, you are a simpleton.”
Manx: “Myr shen,” hie y Gryphon er, “mannagh nhione dhyt y bun jeh Bishaght, she toot uss, dy jarroo.”

English: Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said “What else had you to learn?”
Manx: Cha row shoh greinnaghey Ealish dy vriaght tooilley feyshtyn my e chione: er y fa shen, hyndaa ee gys y Far-Ligganagh Marrey as dooyrt ee “C’red elley beign dhyt gynsaghey?”

English: “Well, there was Mystery,” the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, “—Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: he taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, Shaghrynys,” dreggyr y Far-Ligganagh Marrey, va coontey ny cooishyn er e vaaigyn, — Shaghrynys, shenn as jeianagh, lesh Feer-Oaylleeaght: eisht Cayrn – va’n Mainstyr Cayrn ny henn astan marrey, veagh cheet un cheayrt sy çhiaghtyn: dynsee eshyn dooin Cayrn Scuitchal as Craa ayns Sooillyn.”

English: “What was that like?” said Alice.
Manx: “Cre goll rish va shen?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Well, I can’t show it you myself,” the Mock Turtle said: “I’m too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.”
Manx: “Cha noddym jeeaghyn eh dhyt, mish hene,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey: “ta mee ro neu-lhoobagh. As cha row eh rieau ynsit ec y Ghryphon.”

English: “Hadn’t time,” said the Gryphon: “I went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, he was.”
Manx: “Genney traa,” dooyrt y Gryphon: “agh hie mee gys y vainstyr classicagh. V’eh ny henn phartan, eshyn.”

English: “I never went to him,” the Mock Turtle said with a sigh:
Manx: “Cha jagh mish rieau huggey,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey lesh osney.

English: “he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say.”
Manx: “V’eh gynsaghey Laggan as Greeishyn[4], v’ad gra.”
Notes: [4] [Laggan as Greeishyn] ‘little hollow and stairs’ used unstead of ‘Laughing and Grief’.

English: “So he did, so he did,” said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.
Manx: “Shen eh, shen eh,” dooyrt y Gryphon as eshyn gosnaghey neesht; as dollee yn daa chretoor nyn eddinyn lesh nyn maaigyn.

English: “And how many hours a day did you do lessons?” said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.
Manx: “As quoid dy ooryn sy laa va shiu jannoo lessoonyn?” dooyrt Ealish as driss urree y chooish y chaghlaa.

English: “Ten hours the first day,” said the Mock Turtle: “nine the next, and so on.”
Manx: “Va shin gra ‘slooyn’ roo, as va shin jannoo[5] jeih oor y chied laa,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey: “nuy y laa er giyn, as myr shen maghey shen."
Notes: [5] [Va shin gra ‘slooyn’ roo, as va shin jannoo ...] ‘We were calling them ‘lesses’ (made up word based on [sloo] ‘less’) — not in the English original, but intserted in absence of a suitable pun in Manx between ‘lessen’ and ‘lesson’.

English: “What a curious plan!” exclaimed Alice.
Manx: “Cre’n plan quaagh!” docklee Ealish.

English: “That’s the reason they’re called lessons,”[6] the Gryphon remarked: “because they lessen from day to day.”
Manx: “Shen y fa dy vel ad enmyssit ‘slooyn’,” dooyrt y Gryphon: “er y fa dy vel ad gaase ny sloo gagh laa.”

English: This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark.
Manx: Va shoh ny eie thalk-noa da Ealish, as smooinee ish er son tammylt roish my dooyrt ee red ennagh elley.

English: “Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?”
Manx: “Va’n chied laa jeig ny laa seyr myr shen?”

English: “Of course it was,” said the Mock Turtle.
Manx: “Son shickyrys, v’eh,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “And how did you manage on the twelfth?” Alice went on eagerly.
Manx: “As cre’n aght va shiu goll er, y nah laa yeig?” hie Ealish er dy jeean.

English: “That’s enough about lessons,” the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: “tell her something about the games now.”
Manx: “S’liooar shen mychione slooyn,” vrish y Gryphon stiagh er aght feer hickyr. “Abbyr red ennagh ree mysh ny gammanyn nish.”

English: CHAPTER X.
Manx: CABDYL 10

English: The Lobster Quadrille
Manx: Y Quadrille-Gimmagh

English: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes.
Manx: Dosnee y Far-Ligganagh Marrey dy dowin, as hayrn eh un vaaig harrish e hooillyn.

English: He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice. “Same as if he had a bone in his throat,” said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him inthe back.
Manx: Yeeagh eh er Ealish as phrow eh dy loayrt, agh, son minnid ny ghaa, phloogh soghyn e scoarnagh. "Myr dy beagh craue sy scoarnagh echey," dooyrt y Gryphon, as ghow eh toshiaght dy chraa eh as bwoalley eh sy dreeym.

English: At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:—
Manx: Fy yerrey, hooar y Far-Ligganagh Marrey e choraa, as, lesh jeir roie sheese e lieckanyn, hie eh er reesht:—

English: “You may not have lived much under the sea—” (“I haven’t,” said Alice)—“and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—” (Alice began to say “I once tasted—” but checked herself hastily, and said “No, never”) “ — so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”
Manx: “Foddee nagh vel oo er chummal monney fo’n cheayn —” (“Cha nel,” dooyrt Ealish) – “as foddee nagh row gimmagh rieau currit er enn dhyt —” (ghow Ealish toshiaght dy ghra “Keayrt dy row, vlayst mee — “ agh scuirr ee ee hene dy tappee, as dooyrt ee “Cha row, rieau”) “— eisht cha nel eie erbee ayd cre cho eunyssagh as ta Quadrille-Gimmagh?”

English: “No, indeed,” said Alice. “What sort of a dance is it?”
Manx: “Cha nel, dy jarroo,” dooyrt Ealish. “Cre’n sorch dy ghaunse t’ayn?”

English: “Why,” said the Gryphon, “you first form into a line along the sea-shore —”
Manx: “Cammah,” dooyrt y Gryphon, “hoshiaght, ta shiu shassoo ayns strane ec oirr ny marrey —”

English: “Two lines!” cried the Mock Turtle. “Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you’ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way—”
Manx: “Daa ’trane!” dyllee y Far-Ligganagh Marrey. “Raunyn, shligganee- marrey, braddanyn as myr shen foast: eisht, tra vees ooilley ny smuggyn-rauney scughit ass y raad —”

English: “That generally takes some time,” interrupted the Gryphon. “— you advance twice —”
Manx: “Ta shen cliaghtey goaill traa dy liooar,” vrish y Gryphon stiagh. “— ta goll er oaie daa cheayrt —”

English: “Each with a lobster as a partner!” cried the Gryphon.
Manx: “Gagh nane marish gimmagh myr sheshey!” dyllee y Gryphon.

English: “Of course,” the Mock Turtle said: “advance twice, set to partners—”
Manx: “Son shickyrys,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh: “goll er oaie daa cheayrt, marish sheshaghyn —”

English: “—change lobsters, and retire in same order,” continued the Gryphon.
Manx: “—ceaghil gimmee, as gow ergooyl syn oardagh cheddin," hie y Gryphon er.

English: “Then, you know,” the Mock Turtle went on, “you throw the—”
Manx: “Eisht, ta fys ayd,” hie y Far-Ligganagh Marrey er ny sodjey, “t’ou ceau ny —”

English: “The lobsters!” shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
Manx: “Ny gimmee!" dyllee y Gryphon magh as eh lheim seose syn aer.

English: “—as far out to sea as you can—”
Manx: “—cho foddey magh sy cheayn as oddys oo—”

English: “Swim after them!” screamed the Gryphon.
Manx: “Snaue lurg oc!” screeagh y Gryphon.

English: “Turn a somersault in the sea!” cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly
Manx: “Gow er mullagh ching sy cheayn!” dyllee y Far-Ligganagh Marrey as eh corlheimyraght dy keoi.

English: about.
“Change lobsters again!” yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
Manx: “Ceaghil gimmee reesht!" dyllee y Gryphon ec mullagh e choraa.

English: “Back to land again, and that’s all the first figure,” said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
Manx: “Erash gys y thalloo reesht, as  shen ooilley yn chied figgyr,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey, ginjillaghey e choraa dy doaltattym; as y daa chretoor, va er ve corlheimyraght goll rish reddyn keoi car y traa shoh, hoie ad sheese reesht feer trimshagh as feagh, as yeeagh ad er Ealish.

English: “It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.
Manx: “Gyn ourys, she daunse feer waagh t'ayn," dooyrt Ealish dy faitagh.

English: “Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.
Manx: “By vie lhiat fakin beggan jeh?” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “Very much indeed,” said Alice.
Manx: “By vie lhiam dy mooar,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Come, let’s try the first figure!” said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon. “We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?”
Manx: “Tar, lhig dooin prowal y chied ’iggyr!” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey rish y Gryphon. “Fodmayd jannoo fegooish gimmee, ta fys ayd. Quoi ghoys arrane?”

English: “Oh, you sing,” said the Gryphon. “I’ve forgotten the words.”
Manx: “Ogh, jean uss goaill eh,” dooyrt y Gryphon. “Ta ny focklyn jarroodit ayms.”

English: So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:—
Manx: Myr shen ghow ad toshiaght dy ghaunsin runt mygeayrt Ealish dy trome-chooishagh, cur cass er e meir choshey nish as reesht tra hie ad ro ’aggys jee, as craa nyn maaigyn dy howse y traa, choud’s va’n Far-Ligganagh Marrey goaill shoh, feer voal as trimshagh:—

English: “Will you walk a little faster?” said a whiting to a snail.
Manx: “Jean oo shooyl nish ny s’tappee?” dooyrt yn ’ynnag rish y chrammag,

English: “There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail.
Manx: “Ta perkyn kiart cheu-heear jin, as t'eh stampey goll rish fannag.

English: See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
Manx: Ta ny gimmee as ny shligganee goaill ayrn ayns y giense!

English: They are waiting on the shingle—
Manx: T’ad shoh farkiaght er y gheinnagh —

English: will you come and join the dance?
Manx: jean shiu ooilley cheet sy daunse?

English: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Manx: Jean shiu, jean shiu, jean shiu, jean shiu, jean shiu ooilley cheet sy daunse?”

English: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”
“You can really have no notion how delightful it will be,
Manx: “Vel shiu toiggal cre cho eunyssagh as vees eh, ogh, dy beayn,

English: When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!”
Manx: Tra t’ad goaill shin seose as ceau shin, marish gimmee, magh sy cheayn!”

English: But the snail replied “Too far, too far!” and gave a look askance—
Manx: Agh va’n chrammag loayrt dy trimshagh as shaghney eisht y giense —

English: Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.
Manx: Hug ee bwooise da'n ’ynnag choar as cha rag ee stiagh sy daunse.

English: Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
Manx: Cha darragh ee, cha darragh ee, cha darragh ee sy daunse.

English: Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.
Manx: Cha darragh ee, cha darragh ee, cha darragh ee sy daunse.

English: “What matters it how far we go?” his scaly friend replied.
Manx: “Nagh gummey lheid y turrys shoh?" va’n ’ynnag gra dy moal.

English: “There is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
Manx: As dooyrt eh eisht dy meen, “Ayns shid ta thalloo elley hoal.”

English: The further off from England the nearer is to France—
Manx: “Ny sodjey t’eh woish Mannin, ny sniessey t’eh daʼn giense.

English: Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.
Manx: Ny jean goaill aggle, my chrammag veen, agh jean cheet stiagh sy daunse.

English: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Manx: Jig oo, jed oo, jig oo, jed oo, jig oo stiagh sy daunse?

English: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”
Manx: Jig oo, jed oo, jig oo, jed oo, jig oo stiagh sy daunse?”

English: “Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,” said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: “and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!”
Manx: “Gura mie ayd, shen daunse feer anaasagh dy yeeaghyn er,” dooyrt Ealish, va feer wooiagh dy row eh harrish fy yerrey: “as nagh mie lhiam yn arrane quaagh shen mychione yn ’ynnag!”

English: “Oh, as to the whiting,” said the Mock Turtle, “they—you’ve seen them, of course?”
Manx: “Ogh, bentyn rish ny fynnagyn,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey, “’ou er nakin ad, gyn ourys?”

English: “Yes,” said Alice, “I’ve often seen them at dinn—” she checked herself hastily.
Manx: “Ta,” dooyrt Ealish, ‘ta mee er nakin ad dy mennick ee jinn —’ scuirr ee ee hene dy tappee.

English: “I don’t know where Dinn may be,” said the Mock Turtle, “but if you’ve seen them so often, of course you know what they’re like.”
Manx: “Cha nel fys aym c’raad oddys Jinn ve,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey; “agh, my t'ou er nakin ad cho mennick, son shickyrys ta fys ayd cre goll rish t’ad?”

English: “I believe so,” Alice replied thoughtfully. “They have their tails in their mouths —and they’re all over crumbs.”
Manx: “Ta mee credjal dy vel,” dreggyr Ealish dy smooinaghtagh. “Ta ny fammanyn oc ayns ny beill oc — as t’ad ooilley coodit lesh kinneigyn arran.”

English: “You’re wrong about the crumbs,” said the Mock Turtle: “crumbs would all wash off in the sea.
Manx: “T’ou aggairagh mysh ny kinneigyn,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey: “veagh kinneigyn nieet ersooyl sy cheayn.

English: But they have their tails in their mouths; and the reason is—” here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.
Manx: Agh son shickyrys ta ny fammanyn oc ayns ny beill oc; as ta’n bun jeh shen — ” ayns shoh ren y Far-Ligganagh Marrey mennuigh as ghoon eh e hooillyn.

English: “Tell her about the reason and all that,” he said to the Gryphon.
Manx: “Insh jee mychione y bun as ooilley shen,” dooyrt eh rish y Gryphon.

English: “The reason is,” said the Gryphon, “that they would go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea.
Manx: “Shoh y bun jeh,” dooyrt y Gryphon; “veagh ad goll marish ny gimmee gys y daunse. Myr shen, veagh ad ceaut magh sy cheayn.

English: So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn’t get them out again. That’s all.”
Manx: Myr shen, beign daue tuittym feer foddey. Myr shen, veagh ny fammanyn oc goit ayns ny beill oc. Myr shen, cha noddagh ad tayrn ad magh reesht. Shen ooilley.”

English: “Thank you,” said Alice, “it’s very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before.”
Manx: “Gura mie ayd,” dooyrt Ealish, “t’eh feer symoil. Cha row rieau wheesh fys aym er fynnagyn roie.”

English: “I can tell you more than that, if you like,” said the Gryphon. “Do you know why it’s called a whiting?”
Manx: “Foddym ginsh dhyt ny smoo na shen, my t'ou laccal,” dooyrt y Gryphon. “Vel fys ayd cre'n fa t’ad gra fynnag rish?”

English: “I never thought about it,” said Alice. “Why?”
Manx: “Cha smooinee mee er shen rieau,” dooyrt Ealish. “Cre’n fa?”

English: “It does the boots and shoes,” the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
Manx: “T’ee jannoo ny bootsyn as braagyn,” dreggyr y Gryphon feer arrymagh.

English: Alice was thoroughly puzzled. “Does the boots and shoes!” she repeated in a wondering tone.
Manx: Va Ealish fud y cheilley dy bollagh. “Jannoo ny bootsyn as braagyn!” dooyrt ee as yindys urree.

English: “Why, what are your shoes done with?” said the Gryphon. “I mean, what makes them so shiny?”
Manx: “Cammah, cre lesh ta ny braagyn ayds jeant?” dooyrt y Gryphon. “Cre ta cur orroo ve cho gloasagh, ta mee cheet er.”

English: Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer. “They’re done with blacking, I believe.”
Manx: Yeeagh Ealish sheese orroo, as smooinee ish rish tammylt roish my dug ee e freggyrt. “T’ad jeant lesh doo, ta mee credjal.”

English: “Boots and shoes under the sea,” the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, “are done with a whiting. Now you know.”
Manx: “Bootsyn as braagyn fo’n cheayn,” hie y Gryphon er lesh coraa dowin, “t’ad jeant lesh fynnaght. Nish ta fys ayd.”

English: “And what are they made of?” Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
Manx: “As c'red t’ad jeant ass?” vrie Ealish er aght feer pheeikearagh.

English: “Soles and eels, of course,” the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: “any shrimp could have told you that.”
Manx: “Bunyn-eeastee as boynyn-eeastee, son shickyrys,” dreggyr y Gryphon, cooid veg neu-hurransagh: “oddagh burdoge erbee er ninsh shen dhyt.”

English: “If I’d been the whiting,” said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, “I’d have said to the porpoise, ‘Keep back, please: we don’t want you with us!’”
Manx: “Dy beigns er ve yn ’ynnag,” dooyrt Ealish, va foast smooinaghtyn er yn arrane, “veigns er ghra rish y pherkyn ‘Gow ergooyl, my saillt! Cha nel shin laccal uss y ve marin!’”

English: “They were obliged to have him with them,” the Mock Turtle said:
Manx: “V'ad eginit ish y ve maroo,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “no wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.”
Manx: “Cha ragh yeeast creeney boayl erbee fegooish perkyn.”

English: “Wouldn’t it really?” said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
Manx: “Nagh ragh, dy firrinagh?” dooyrt Ealish as yindys mooar urree.

English: “Of course not,” said the Mock Turtle:
Manx: “Son shickyrys, cha ragh,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “why, if a fish came to me, and told me he was going a journey, I should say ‘With what porpoise?’”
Manx: “Cammah, dy darragh yeeast hyms dy insh dou dy row eh goll er turrys, yiarrins 'Lesh cre'n pherkyn?’”

English: “Don’t you mean ‘purpose’?” said Alice.
Manx: “Nagh Lhisagh oo gra ‘perkin’?” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “I mean what I say,” the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone.
Manx: “Ta mee gra y red ta mee cheet er," dreggyr y Far-Ligganagh Marrey as snee er.

English: And the Gryphon added “Come, let’s hear some of your adventures.”
Manx: As dooyrt y Gryphon, "Lhig dooin clashtyn paart jeh ny contoyrtyssyn ayds.”

English: “I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning,” said Alice a little timidly: “but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.”
Manx: “Oddins ginsh diu ooilley my chontoyrtyssyn — goaill toshiaght veih moghrey jiu," dooyrt Ealish, beggan faitagh: "agh cha nel eh feeu goll erash gys y laa jea, er y fa dy nee peiagh elley va mish eisht.”

English: “Explain all that,” said the Mock Turtle.
Manx: “Cur dooin y bun jeh shen ooilliu," dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “No, no! The adventures first,” said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: “explanations take such a dreadful time.”
Manx: “Ny jean! Ny contoyrtyssyn hoshiaght,” dooyrt y Gryphon dy neu-hurransagh: “ta soilsheydyssyn goaill traa agglagh.”

English: So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit.
Manx: Myr shen, ghow Ealish toshiaght dy insh daue mychione e contoyrtyssyn veih'n traa honnick ee y Chonning Vane hoshiaght.

English: She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so very wide, but she gained courage as she went on.
Manx: V'ee beggan faitagh my e chione, kiart ec y toshiaght, er y fa dy row y daa chretoor chionney stiagh urree, nane er gagh cheu, as fosley nyn sooillyn as beill cho lhean; agh haink creeaght huic as ish goll er.

English: Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating “You are old, Father William,” to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different,
Manx: Va’n lught-eaishtaght eck nyn soie feer feagh derrey raink ee yn ayrn jeh'n skeeal tra v’ee gra “Yishag Illiam, t'ou uss shenn,” rish y Phraddag as va ooilley ny focklyn cheet magh as cummey elley orroo.

English: and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said “That’s very curious.”
Manx: Eisht hayrn y Far-Ligganagh Marrey ennal mooar, as dooyrt eh “Ta shen feer whaagh!”

English: “It’s all about as curious as it can be,” said the Gryphon.
Manx: “T’eh ooilley cho quaagh as oddys eh ve,” dooyrt y Gryphon.

English: “It all came different!” the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully.
Manx: “Va cummey elley er ny focklyn!” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey dy smooinaghtagh.

English: “I should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to begin.”
Manx: “By vie lhiam eh dy jinnagh ee prowal dy aa-ghra red ennagh nish. Abbyr ree dy ghoaill toshiaght.”

English: He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
Manx: Yeeagh eh er y Ghryphon myr dy beagh eh smooinaghtyn dy row sorch dy phooar echey harrish Ealish.

English: “Stand up and repeat ‘’Tis the voice of the sluggard,’” said the Gryphon.
Manx: “Shass seose as jean gra ‘Shen coraa y chadlag,’” dooyrt y Gryphon.

English: “How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!” thought Alice; “I might as well be at school at once.”
Manx: “Shimmey keayrt ta ny cretooryn cur sarey dhyt as cur ort dy ghra lessoonyn!” smooinee Ealish. “Veagh eh cho mie dou ve ec y scoill nish.”

English: However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:—
Manx: Agh hrog ee urree, as ghow ee toshiaght dy ghra eh, agh va'n kione eck cho lane jeh'n Whadrille-Gimmagh as nagh row fys kiart eck er ny reddyn v’ee gra; as haink ny focklyn magh feer whaagh dy jarroo:—

English: “’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
Manx: “Shoh coraa jeh’n Ghimmagh: cheayll mee eh gra

English: “You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.”
Manx: ‘Ta mee jeant ayd ro ghone, ta mee ooilley er craa.’

English: As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
Manx: Myr farvolleeyn ny thunnag, myr shen lesh e ’troin

English: Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.”
Manx: Kiartagh cryss as meir-choshey, as puttey e voyn.

English: [later editions continued as follows]:
When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark,
Manx: Tra ta’n geinnagh kiart chirrym, myr ushag t’eh reagh,

English: And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark,
Manx: Jeh’n çharkagh t’eh loayrt dy seyr as dy bwooiagh:

English: But, when the tide rises and sharks are around,
Manx: Tra irrys y tidey, lesh sharkee mygeayrt,

English: His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.
Manx: T’eh cheet dy ve faitagh as goll magh ass reayrt.”

English: “That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
Manx: “Cha nel shen goll rish y daan va mish cliaghtey gra tra va mish my phaitchey,” dooyrt y Gryphon.

English: “Well, I never heard it before,” said the Mock Turtle; “but it sounds uncommon nonsense.”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, cha geayll mish eh roie rieau,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey; “agh t’eh sheeanal goll rish boghtynid erskyn insh.”

English: Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would ever happen in a natural way again.
Manx: Cha dooyrt Ealish veg: v’ee er soie sheese as e h-eddin ayns e laueyn, smooinaghtyn beagh red erbee dy bragh taghyrt reesht er aght dooghyssagh.

English: “I should like to have it explained,” said the Mock Turtle.
Manx: “By vie lhiams soilsheydys jeh,” dooyrt y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: “She can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon hastily. “Go on with the next verse.”
Manx: “Cha vod ee soilshaghey magh eh,” dooyrt y Gryphon dy siyragh. “Gow er lesh y nah rane.”

English: “But about his toes?” the Mock Turtle persisted.
Manx: “Agh cre mysh ny meir-choshey echey?” ren y Far-Ligganagh Marrey goll er ny sodjey.

English: “How could he turn them out with his nose, you know?”
Manx: “Cre’n aght oddagh eh kiartagh ad lesh e ’troin, vel oo sheiltyn?"

English: “It’s the first position in dancing.” Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
Manx: “Shen y chied ynnyd ayns daunsin,” dooyrt Ealish; agh v’ee jeant fud y cheilley dy h-agglagh liorish y clane red, as v'ee laccal caghlaa y chooish dy debejagh.

English: “Go on with the next verse,” the Gryphon repeated impatiently: “it begins ‘I passed by his garden.’”
Manx: “Gow er lesh y nah rane,” dooyrt y Gryphon reesht: “t’eh goaill toshiaght ‘As yeeagh mee sy gharey.’”

English: Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:—
Manx: Cha b’loys da Ealish ve mee-viallagh, ga dy heill ish dy beagh brock ayn, as hie ee er ayns coraa er craa: —

English: “I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
Manx: “As yeeagh mee sy gharey, as yeeagh lesh un tooill,

English: How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”
Manx: Er y Hullad as Panther as pye oc lesh feill:

English: [later editions continued as follows]
The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat,
Manx: Va scroig ec y Phanther, as feill vie, as soo,

English: While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat.
Manx: Choud’s va’n jyst ec y Hullad myr ayrn jeh’n stoo.

English: When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon,
Manx: Tra va’n phye ersooyl, eeit, va’n Hullad jeant bwooiagh,

English: Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon:
Manx: Tra hug ad y spein da dy chur lesh dy feagh:

English: While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl,
Manx: Ghow y Panther y skynn as yn aall lesh gurr,

English: And concluded the banquet—
Manx: Hug kione er y lhongey — ’

English: “What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on?
Manx: “Cha nel eh feeu dy ghra ooilley y stoo shen,” vrish y Far-Ligganagh Marrey stiagh, “mannagh vel oo cur y bun jeh myr t’ou goll er.

English: It’s by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!”
Manx: Cha ren mee rieau clashtyn lheid y red shen oddys cur ort dy ve cho fud y cheilley!”

English: “Yes, I think you’d better leave off,” said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
Manx: “She, er lhiam dy bare dhyt cur sthap er,” dooyrt y Gryphon, as va Ealish feer wooiagh shen y yannoo.

English: “Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?” the Gryphon went on. “Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?”
Manx: “Jeanmayd prowal figgyr elley jeh'n Whadrille-Gimmagh?” hie y Gryphon er. “Ny by vie lhiat clashtyn arrane elley veih'n Far-Ligganagh Marrey?”

English: “Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,” Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone,
Manx: “Ogh, arrane, my sailt, my vees y Far-Ligganagh Marrey cho kenjal,” dreggyr Ealish cho jeean as dy dooyrt y Gryphon as snee er, beggan,

English: “Hm! No accounting for tastes!
Manx: “Hm! Cha nod oo toiggal ‘share lhiam’!

English: Sing her ‘Turtle Soup ,’ will you, old fellow?”
Manx: Gow ‘Awree Ligganagh Marrey’ jee, jean uss, henn charrey?”

English: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:—
Manx: Dosnee y Far-Ligganagh Marrey dy dowin, as ghow eh toshiaght, ayns coraa va plooghit liorish soghyn, er yn arrane shoh:—

English: “Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Manx: “Awree Aalin, mie as glass,

English: Waiting in a hot tureen!
Manx: Fuirraght dy çheh ayns jyst jeh gless!

English: Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Manx: Quoi nagh vod goaill y stoo cho beayn?

English: Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Manx: Awree yn ’astyr, Awree aalin!

English: Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Manx: Awree yn ’astyr, Awree aalin!

English: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Manx: Aw-ree aa-lin!

English: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Manx: Aw-ree aa-lin!

English: Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
Manx: Aw-ree yn 'as-tyr,

English: Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
Manx: Awree cho aalin!”

English: “Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
Manx: “Awree Aalin! Quoi s'mie lesh eeast.

English: Game, or any other dish?
Manx: Kiark ny kellagh ruy ayns jyst?

English: Who would not give all else for two p
Manx: Quoi nagh derragh gagh nhee bwaagh

English: ennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
Manx: Son bolgum beg jeh'n vine ta bwooiagh?

English: Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
Manx: Bolgum beg jeh'n awree aalin?

English: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Manx: Aw-ree aa-lin!

English: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Manx: Aw-ree aa-lin!

English: Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
Manx: Aw-ree yn 'astyr,

English: Beautiful, beauti—FUL SOUP!”
Manx: Aw-ree cho AALIN!”

English: “Chorus again!” cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of “The trial’s beginning!” was heard in the distance.
Manx: “Co-chiaull reesht!” dyllee y Gryphon, as va'n Far-Ligganagh Marrey er ngoaill toshiaght er reesht tra va eam jeh “Ta'n chooish- leigh goaill toshiaght!” ry chlashtyn sy foddid.

English: “Come on!” cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
Manx: “Hooin roin!” dyllee y Gryphon, as, goaill greim er laue Ealish, hie eh roish, gyn fuirraght rish jerrey yn arrane.

English: “What trial is it?” Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered “Come on!” and ran the faster,
Manx: “Cre’n chooish-leigh t’ayn?” ren Ealish pandoogh myr v'ee roie; agh cha dreggyr y Gryphon agh “Hooin roin!” as roie eh ny smoo tappee.

English: while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:—
Manx: Ec y traa cheddin, va ny goan trimshagh shoh ry chlashtyn as ad er nyn ymmyrkey liorish y fynneraght beg dy gheay va geiyrt orroo:—

English: “Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
Manx: “Aw-ree yn ’as-tyr,

English: Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”
Manx: Awree cho aalin!”

English: CHAPTER XI.
Manx: CABDYL 11

English: Who Stole the Tarts?
Manx: Quoi Gheid ny Sooanyn?

English: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived,
Manx: Va Ree as Benrein ny Creeaghyn nyn soie er nyn stoyl-reeoil tra raink ad.

English: with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards:
Manx: Va chionnal mooar mygeayrt y moo - dy chooilley horch dy ushag veg as cretoor, marish y clane sthock dy chaartyn:

English: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.
Manx: va'n Fieaumanagh ny hassoo kiongoyrt roo, ayns geulaghyn, as sidoor er gagh cheu dy 'reayll rick er; as vaʼn Chonning Vane faggys da'n Ree, as cayrn ayns un laue as scrolley dy phabyr craitnagh sy laue elley.

English: In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—
Manx: Kiart ayns y vean jeh’n chooyrt va boayrd as jyst mooar lane dy hooanyn er: v’ad jeeaghyn cho mie as dy row accrys dy liooar çheet er Ealish as ish agh jeeaghyn orroo —

English: “I wish they’d get the trial done,” she thought, “and hand round the refreshments!”
Manx: “Saillym dy beagh y chooish leigh jeant oc,” smooinee ish, “as dy derragh ad magh ny h-ooridee!”

English: But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
Manx: Agh v’eh jeeaghyn nagh beagh shen taghyrt noadyr; myr shen ghow ee toshiaght dy yeeaghyn er dy chooilley nhee mygeayrt y mooee dy cheau yn traa.

English: Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there. “That’s the judge,” she said to herself, “because of his great wig.”
Manx: Cha row Ealish rieau er ve ayns cooyrt leigh roie, agh v'ee er lhaih my nyn gione ayns lioaryn, as v'ee jeant bwooiagh dy liooar tra hooar ee magh dy row fys eck er gagh nhee ayns shen, bunnys. “Shen y briw,” dooyrt ee ree hene, “kyndagh rish e washag vooar.”

English: The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
Manx: She yn Ree, ta fys ayd, va'n briw; as, er y fa dy row eh ceau e attey harrish y washag (jeeagh er y chaslys toshee my t’ou laccal fakin cre’n aght v’eh jeant echey), cha row eh jeeaghyn souyr noadyr, as son shickyrys cha row eh cooie.

English: “And that’s the jury-box,” thought Alice, “and those twelve creatures,” (she was obliged to say “creatures,” you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) “I suppose they are the jurors.”
Manx: “As shen bink ny bingey,” smooinee Ealish; “as y daa chretoor yeig shen,” (v’ee eginit gra “cretoor”, t’ou toiggal, er y fa dy row paart jeu nyn meiyn as paart nyn ushagyn,) “ta mee sheiltyn dy nee ny fir bingagh ad shen.”

English: She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all.
Manx: Dooyrt ee y raa s'jerree daa ny tree keayrtyn ree hene, er y fa dy row ee goaill moyrn dy liooar ass: er y fa dy heill ee, as v'ee kiart, nagh row agh shiartanse feer veg dy inneenyn aegey jeh'n eash eck toiggal y bun jeh noadyr.

English: However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.
Manx: Aghterbee, veagh "Fir ny bingey" mie dy liooar neesht.

English: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. “What are they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon. “They can’t have anything to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.”
Manx: Va’n daa chretoor yeig sy ving ooilley screeu feer tarroogh er sclateyn. "Cre t'ad jannoo?” hannish Ealish rish y Gryphon. "Cha nod red erbee ve oc foast, roish y toshiaght jeh'n chooish."

English: “They’re putting down their names,” the Gryphon whispered in reply, “for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.”
Manx: “Ta’d screeu sheese nyn enmyn,” hannish y Gryphon myr freggyrt, "er aggle dy bee ad jarroodit oc roish y jerrey jeh'n chooish.”

English: “Stupid things!” Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, “Silence in the court!” and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
Manx: “Cretooryn bolvaneagh!” dooyrt Ealish ayns coraa niartal as corree; agh scuirr ee ee hene dy tappee, er y hon dy dyllee y Chonning Vane magh “Tostid sy chooyrt!”, as hug y Ree mysh e speckleyryn as ghow eh toshiaght dy yeeaghyn mygeayrt dy h- imneagh dy 'eddyn magh quoi va loayrt.

English: Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down “stupid things!” on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn’t know how to spell “stupid,” and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.
Manx: Oddagh Ealish fakin, kiart cho mie as dy beagh ee jeeaghyn harrish ny geayltyn oc, dy row ooilley ny fir bingagh screeu sheese “Cretooryn bolvaneagh!” er nyn sclateyn, as v'ee abyl fakin nagh row fys ec nane jeu er yn aght kiart dy screeu "bolvaneagh" as dy beign dou shirrey cooney veih'n naboo echey. "She brock kiart vees er nyn sclateyn roish my vees y chooish harrish!" smooinee Ealish.

English: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
Manx: Va penn leoaie ren jeestyrnee ec nane jeh ny fir bingagh.

English: This of course, Alice could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away.
Manx: Dy dooghyssagh, cha dod Ealish jannoo lesh shoh, as hie ee mygeayrt y chooyrt, cooyl echey, as, ayns tammylt beg, hooar ee caa dy ghoaill ee ersooyl veih.

English: She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
Manx: Va shen jeant cho tappee eck as nagh dod y fer bingagh boght (she Illiam, y Jiolgan Leaghyr, v'ayn) toiggal cre haink er; myr shen, erreish da v'er hirrey ee dy chooilley voayl, v'eh eginit screeu lesh un vair son y chooid elley jeh'n laa; as va shoh dyn ymmyd, er y fa nagh row cowrey faagit er y sclate.

English: “Herald, read the accusation!” said the King.
Manx: “Haghter, lhaih yn cassid!” dooyrt y Ree.

English: On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—
Manx: Lesh shen, heid y Chonning Vane tree keayrtyn er y chayrn, as eisht doshil eh y scrolley pabyr craitnagh, as lhaih eh myr shoh heese:—

English: “The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
Manx: “Benrein ny Creeaghyn, ren ish ny sooanyn,

English: All on a summer day:
Manx: Sy tourey, ayns y laa:

English: The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
Manx: Y Fieaumanagh hene, gheid eh ny sooanyn,

English: And took them quite away!”
Manx: Ersooyl lesh, as eshyn er craa!”

English: “Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.
Manx: Smooinee-jee er nyn mriwnys,” dooyrt y Ree rish y ving.

English: “Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal to come before that!”
Manx: “Cha nee foast, cha nee foast!” vrish y Chonning stiagh dy siyragh. “Ta ram ry heet roish shen!”

English: “Call the first witness,” said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, “First witness!”
Manx: “Cur fys er y chied feanishagh,” dooyrt y Ree; as heid y Chonning Vane tree keayrtyn er y chayrn, as dyllee eh magh “Y chied feanishagh!”

English: The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other.
Manx: She yn Eddeyder va'n chied feanishagh. Haink eh stiagh as cappan tey ayns un laue as meer dy arran as eeym sy laue elley.

English: “I beg pardon, your Majesty,” he began, “for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for.”
Manx: “Gow-jee my leshtal, Ree Ooasle,” ghow eh toshiaght, "son cur lhiam ad shoh stiagh; agh cha row er chur kione er my hey dy kiart tra hug ad fys orrym.”

English: “You ought to have finished,” said the King. “When did you begin?”
Manx: “Lhisagh kione er ve currit ayd er,” dooyrt y Ree. “Cuin ghow uss toshiaght?”

English: The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. “Fourteenth of March, I think it was,” he said.
Manx: Yeeagh yn Eddeyder er y Waagh Vart, va er neiyrt er stiagh sy chamyr-cooyrtey as eh uillin er uillin lesh y Lugh Vagheragh. “Y chiarroo laa jeig jeh Mee Vart, er lhiam.” dooyrt eh.

English: “Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Yn wheiggoo laa jeig,” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: “Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.
Manx: “Yn cheyoo laa jeig,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh.

English: “Write that down,” the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
Manx: “Screeu-jee shen sheese,” dooyrt y Ree rish y ving; as screeu y ving sheese dy jeean ooilley ny tree dateyn er ny sclateyn oc, as eisht ren ad cur ad ry cheilley as dobbree ad magh yn ansoor ayns skilleeyn as pingyn.

English: “Take off your hat,” the King said to the Hatter.
Manx: “Cur jeed dty edd,” dooyrt y Ree rish yn Eddeyder.

English: “It isn’t mine,” said the Hatter.
Manx: “Cha nel eh lhiams,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder.

English: “Stolen!” the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
Manx: “Geidit!” docklee magh y Ree as eh çhyndaa gys y ving, ren memrane jeh’n fys shen dy çhelleeragh.

English: “I keep them to sell,” the Hatter added as an explanation; “I’ve none of my own. I’m a hatter.”
Manx: “Ta mee freayll ad dy chreck,” hoilshee yn Eddeyder magh y chooish. “Cha nel veg jeu lhiams. Ta mee my eddeyder.”

English: Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
Manx: Er shoh, hug y Venrein urree e speckleyryn, as ghow ee toshiaght dy vlakey feer jeean er yn Eddeyder, ren çheet dy ve bane-eddinagh as foostyragh.

English: “Give your evidence,” said the King; “and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot.”
Manx: “Abbyr y feanish ayds,” dooyrt y Ree; “as ny bee faitagh, er nonney bee uss currit gy baase liorish yn oardagh aym dy çhelleeragh.”

English: This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen,
Manx: Cha row eh jeeaghyn dy row shoh greinnaghey y feanishagh noadyr: v’eh kinjagh nhedderagh veih un chass gys y chass elley as eh jeeaghyn er y venrein dy h-imneagh.

English: and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
Manx: V’eh cho fud y cheilley as dy ghreim eh meer vooar ass e chappan tey syn ynnyd jeh'n arran as eeym.

English: Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.
Manx: Jeeragh ec y thootch shoh, va Ealish gennaghtyn feer whaagh, ren boirey urree dy mooar gys hoig ee cre va taghyrt: v’ee goaill toshiaght dy aase mooar reesht, as smooinee ee hoshiaght dy drog- gagh ee urree as faagail y chooyrt; agh lurg smooinaght, reih ish dy hannaghtyn raad v'ee cho foddey as va reamys ayn jee.

English: “I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her. “I can hardly breathe.”
Manx: “Saillym nagh jinnagh oo jingey myr shen,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh va ny soie sniessey jee. “S’doillee dou tayrn ennal.”

English: “I can’t help it,” said Alice very meekly: “I’m growing.”
Manx: “Cha nel niart aym er,” dooyrt Ealish feer veen: “ta mee gaase.”

English: “You’ve no right to grow here,” said the Dormouse.
Manx: “Cha nel cair dhyt gaase ayns shoh,” dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh.

English: “Don’t talk nonsense,” said Alice more boldly: “you know you’re growing too.”
Manx: “Ny jean fockley boghtynid,” dooyrt Ealish ny smoo daaney: “ta fys ayd dy vel uss gaase neesht.”

English: “Yes, but _I_ grow at a reasonable pace,” said the Dormouse: “not in that ridiculous fashion.”
Manx: “Ta, agh ta mish gaase moal dy liooar," dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh: "cha nee er yn aght faghidagh shen."

English: And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.
Manx: As hrog eh er feer phooitchagh as hie eh harrish gys y çheu elley jeh'n chooyrt.

English: All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!”
Manx: Ooilley yn traa shen, va’n Venrein kinjagh blakey er yn Eddeyder, as, kiart myr va’n Lugh Vagheragh er ngoll tessen, dooyrt ee rish nane jeh fir oik ny cooyrtey, “Cur lhiat dou rolley ny h-arraneyderyn sy chuirrey kiaull shoh chaie!”

English: on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
Manx: Er shoh, va’n Eddeyder treih er craa wheesh as dy huitt e vraagyn jeh.

English: “Give your evidence,” the King repeated angrily, “or I’ll have you executed, whether you’re nervous or not.”
Manx: “Abbyr y feanish ayd,” dooyrt y Ree reesht dy fergagh, "er nonney bee oo currit gy baase liorish yn oardagh aym, faitagh ny dyn.”

English: “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, “—and I hadn’t begun my tea—not above a week or so—and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin—and the twinkling of the tea—”
Manx: “Ta mee my ghooinney boght, Ree Ooasle," ghow yn Eddeyder as e choraa er craa, "as cha row ee er ngoaill toshiaght er my hey cha nee ny smoo na shiaghtyn er dy henney — as er y fa dy row yn arran as eeym gaase cho thanney — as lesh y toilshey jeh’n tey—”

English: “The twinkling of the what?” said the King.
Manx: “Lesh y toilshey jeh c’red?” dooyrt y Ree.

English: “It began with the tea,” the Hatter replied.
Manx: “Ghow eh toshiaght lesh y tey,” dreggyr yn Eddeyder.

English: “Of course twinkling begins with a T!” said the King sharply. “Do you take me for a dunce? Go on!”
Manx: “Son shickyrys ta toilshey goaill toshiaght lesh T!” dooyrt y Ree dy gear. “Vel uss coontey mish dy ve my volvane? Gow er!”

English: “I’m a poor man,” the Hatter went on, “and most things twinkled after that — only the March Hare said —”
Manx: “Mish my ghooinney boght,” ren yn Eddeyder goll er, “as va'n chooid smoo dy reddyn soilshean lurg shen — agh dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart —”

English: “I didn’t!” the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
Manx: “Cha dooyrt!” vrish y Mwaagh Vart stiagh siyragh agglagh.

English: “You did!” said the Hatter.
Manx: “Dooyrt!” dooyrt yn Eddeyder.

English: “I deny it!” said the March Hare.
Manx: “Ta mee gobbal eh!” dooyrt y Mwaagh Vart.

English: “He denies it,” said the King: “leave out that part.”
Manx: “T’eh gobbal eh,” dooyrt y Ree: “faag-jee magh y veer shen.”

English: “Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said —” the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
Manx: “Aghterbee, dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh —” hie yn Eddeyder er as eh jeeaghyn mygeayrt dy h-imneagh dy 'akin jinnagh ish gobbal eh neesht; agh cha dobb y Lugh Vagheragh veg er y fa dy row ee ny cadley dy dowin.

English: “After that,” continued the Hatter, “I cut some more bread-and-butter —”
Manx: “Lurg shen,” hie yn Eddeyder er, "yiarr mee paart dy arran as eeym —”

English: “But what did the Dormouse say?” one of the jury asked.
Manx: “Agh cre dooyrt y Lugh Vagheragh?” vrie nane jeh ny deiney bingey.

English: “That I can’t remember,” said the Hatter.
Manx: “Cha noddym cooinaghtyn er shen,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder.

English: “You must remember,” remarked the King, “or I’ll have you executed.”
Manx: “Shegin dhyt cooinaghtyn,” dooyrt y Ree, “er nonney bee oo currit gy baase liorym.”

English: The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee. “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” he began.
Manx: Lhig yn Eddeyder treih da'n chappan as arran as eeym echey tuittym, as chroym eh sheese er un ghlioon. "Ta mee my ghooinney feer voght, Ree Ooasle," ghow eh toshiaght.

English: “You’re a very poor speaker,” said the King.
Manx: “T'ou dty loayreyder feer voal,” dooyrt y Ree.

English: Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court.
Manx: Er shoh, dyllee nane jeh ny muic rangagh magh er ard dy chur moylley, as dy chelleeragh v’ee er ny smaghtey liorish fir oik ny cooyrtey.

English: (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done.
Manx: (Er y fa dy nee fockle beggan barb t'ayn, soilsheeym magh dhyt yn aght va shen jeant.

English: They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)
Manx: Va poagey mooar carmeish oc, oddagh ad kiangley seose lesh strengyn ec y veeal: hug ad y vuc rangagh stiagh ayn dy tappee, gour e vullee, as eisht hoie ad er.)

English: “I’m glad I’ve seen that done,” thought Alice.
Manx: “S’mie lhiam dy vaik mee y lheid," smooinee Ealish. y bun jeh gys nish."

English: “I’ve so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials,” There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court, “and I never understood what it meant till now.”
Manx: “Ta mee er lhaih cho mennick ayns ny pabyryn naight, ec y jerrey jeh cooishyn leigh,” Va eab jeant dy chur moylley er ard, agh dy chelleeragh v'eh er ny smaghtey liorish fir oik ny cooyrtey, “as cha ren mee rieau toiggal.”

English: “If that’s all you know about it, you may stand down,” continued the King.
Manx: “My ta shen ooilley y fys t'ayd er, foddee oo çheet neose," ren Ree goll er.

English: “I can’t go no lower,” said the Hatter: “I’m on the floor, as it is.”
Manx: “Cha noddym cheet ny s’inshley,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder: “ta mee er y laare ec y traa t’ayn.”

English: “Then you may sit down,” the King replied.
Manx: “Foddee oo soie sheese myr shen,” dreggyr y Ree.

English: Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
Manx: Er shoh, voyll y vuc rangagh elley er ard as v'ee er ny smaghtey.

English: “Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!” thought Alice.
Manx: “Dy jarroo, ta shen cur kione er ny muic rangagh!” smooinee Ealish.

English: “Now we shall get on better.”
Manx: “Beemayd goll er ny share nish.”

English: “I’d rather finish my tea,” said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
Manx: “Bare lhiams cur kione er y tey ayms,” dooyrt yn Eddeyder as eh jeeaghyn dy h-imneagh er y Venrein, va lhaih yn rolley dy arraneyderyn.

English: “You may go,” said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.
Manx: “Foddee oo goll,” dooyrt y Ree, as daag yn Eddeyder yn chooyrt dy siyragh, gyn eer fuirraghtyn dy chur e vraagyn er.

English: “—and just take his head off outside,” the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.
Manx: “— as gow e chione jeh cheu-mooie,” dooyrt y Venrein rish nane jeh ny fir oik; agh va'n Eddeyder ass shilley roish my row y fer oik roshtyn y dorrys.

English: “Call the next witness!” said the King.
Manx: “Cur fys er y nah ’eanish!”  dooyrt y Ree.

English: The next witness was the Duchess’s cook.
Manx: She coagyrey y Vendiuic va’n nah ’eanish.

English: She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
Manx: V’ee cur lhee y chishteig-phibbyr sy laue eck, as heill Ealish dy kiart quoi v'ayn, eer roish my daink ee stiagh sy chooyrt liorish yn aght va sleih va faggys da'n dorrys goaill toshiaght dy 'treighyrnee ooilley ry cheilley.

English: “Give your evidence,” said the King.
Manx: “Abbyr dty ’eanish,” dooyrt y Ree.

English: “Shan’t,” said the cook.
Manx: “Cha jirym,” dooyrt y coagyrey.

English: The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, “Your Majesty must cross-examine this witness.”
Manx: Yeeagh y Ree dy h-imneagh er y Chonning Vane, ren gra ayns coraa injil, “Shegin da my Ree Ooasle feyshtyn y chur er yn ’eanishagh shoh.

English: “Well, if I must, I must,” the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, “What are tarts made of?”
Manx: “Dy jarroo, my shegin dou, shegin dou," dooyrt y Ree dy trimshagh, as, erreish da v'er filley e roihaghyn as grouigey er y choagyrey derrey va ny sooillyn echey bunnys ass shilley, dooyrt eh ayns coraa dowin, “C'red ta sooanyn jeant ass?”

English: “Pepper, mostly,” said the cook.
Manx: “Pibbyr, son y chooid smoo,” dooyrt y coagyrey.

English: “Treacle,” said a sleepy voice behind her.
Manx: “Treagyl,” dooyrt coraa cadlagh cheu-heear jee.

English: “Collar that Dormouse,” the Queen shrieked out.
Manx: “Gow-jee greim er y Lugh Vagheragh shen!” screeagh y Venrein.

English: “Behead that Dormouse!
Manx: "Gow-jee y kione jeh'n Lugh Vagheragh shen!

English: Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his whiskers!”
Manx: Ceau-jee y Lugh Vagheragh magh ass y chooyrt! Cur-jee ish fo smaght! Ming-jee ish! Ersooyl lesh e robaigyn!”

English: For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.
Manx: Son paart dy vinnidyn va’n clane chooyrt ayns corvaal as y Lugh Vagheragh goll er ceau magh, as, liorish y traa v’ad reaghit reesht, va'n coagyrey er skellal roee.

English: “Never mind!” said the King, with an air of great relief. “Call the next witness.”
Manx: “S’cummey!” dooyrt y Ree as e imnea feayshlit dy mooar. "Cur fys er y nah 'eanishagh."

English: And he added in an undertone to the Queen,
Manx: As dooyrt eh neesht, ayns coraa injil rish y Venrein,

English: “Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness.
Manx: “Dy firrinagh, veen, shegin dhyts cur feyshtyn er y nah 'eanishagh.

English: It quite makes my forehead ache!”
Manx: Dy jarroo, t’eh cur kione çhing dou!”

English: Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like,
Manx: Yeeagh Ealish er y Chonning Vane myr v'eh murtaghey lesh y rolley as ish feer pheeikearagh dy 'akin cre goll rish veagh y nah 'eanishagh,

English: “—for they haven’t got much evidence yet,” she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name “Alice!”
Manx: “ — er y fa nagh vel ad er ngeddyn monney feanish foastagh,” dooyrt ee ree hene. Smooinee er yn yindys haink urree tra lhaih y Chonning Vane magh, ec mullagh e choraa beg ard, yn ennym “Ealish!”

English: CHAPTER XII.
Manx: CABDYL 12

English: Alice’s Evidence
Manx: Feanish Ealish

English: “Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below,
Manx: “Ayns shoh!” dyllee Ealish magh as ish jarrood dy bollagh sy chorvaal cre cho mooar as v’ee er naase er y gherrit, as lheim ee seose as driss cho mooar urree as dy lhiegg ee bink ny bingey lesh chemmal e rhumbyl as va ooilley fir ny bingey ceaut er king y chionnal heese.

English: and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
Manx: Ayns shen v’ad nyn lhie, sheeynt noon as noal er aght hug cooinaghtyn urree jeh cruinnag dy eeastyn airhey v'ee er lhieggey bun ry skyn dy lhag-haghyrtagh yn chiaghtyn roish shen.

English: “Oh, I beg your pardon!” she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.
Manx: “Ogh, gow-jee my leshtal!” dooyrt ee as aggle vooar urree, as ghow ee toshiaght dy hroggal seose ad cho tappee as v’ee abyl, er y fa dy row drogh-haghyrt ny eeastyn airhey soiet sy chione eck, as va eie neuchruinn eck dy beign daue ve çhymsit dy çhelleeragh as currit erash er bink ny bingey, ny yioghe ad baase.

English: “The trial cannot proceed,” said the King in a very grave voice, “until all the jurymen are back in their proper places — all,” he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.
Manx: “Cha vod y chooish leigh goll er,” dooyrt y Ree ayns coraa feer trome-chooishagh, “derrey vees fir ny bingey erash ayns yn ynnyd chooie oc — gagh nane jeu,” dooyrt eh feer trome as eshyn jeeaghyn dy jeean er Ealish myr v'eh gra shen.

English: Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move.
Manx: Yeeagh Ealish er bink ny bingey, as honnick ee dy row ee er chur y Jiolgan Leaghyr stiagh as eshyn gour e vullee kyndagh rish e driss, as va’n red beg boght craa er aght trimshagh as eshyn goit dy bollagh.

English: She soon got it out again, and put it right; “not that it signifies much,” she said to herself; “I should think it would be quite as much use in the trial one way up as the other.”
Manx: Deayshil ee eh dy tappee as hug ee eh ny hassoo dy kiart; ‘s’cummey,’ dooyrt ee ree hene; ‘er lhiam dy beagh eh un red sy chooyrt leigh dy beagh eh bun ry skyn.’

English: As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.
Manx: Cho leah’s va’n ving er chowral beggan veih’n atchim jeh goll er ceau bun ry skyn as va nyn sclateyn as pennyn-leoaie er ve feddynit as currit erash daue, ghow ad ayns laue dy screeu feer jeidagh skeeal y drogh-haghyrt, er lhimmey jeh’n Jiolgan Leaghyr, va jeeaghyn dy ve wheesh currit fo haart as nagh dod eh agh soie as e veeal foshlit, blakey seose ayns clea ny cooyrtey.

English: “What do you know about this business?” the King said to Alice.
Manx: “Cre'n fys t’ayd er y chooish shoh?” dooyrt y Ree rish Ealish.

English: “Nothing,” said Alice.
Manx: “Cha nhione dou veg,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Nothing whatever?” persisted the King.
Manx: “Veg?” vrie y Ree ny sodjey.

English: “Nothing whatever,” said Alice.
Manx: “Veg,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “That’s very important,” the King said, turning to the jury.
Manx: “Ta shen feer scanshoil,” dooyrt y Ree as eh çhyndaa gys y ving.

English: They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted:
Manx: V’ad goaill toshiaght dy screeu shoh sheese er nyn sclateyn tra vrish y Chonning Vane stiagh:

English: “Unimportant, your Majesty means, of course,” he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.
Manx: “Neu-scanshoil, lhisagh y Ree Ooasle gra, son shickyrys,” dooyrt eh er aght feer arrymagh, agh v’eh grouigey as cur sceau er e eddin ec yn un cheayrt.

English: “Unimportant, of course, I meant,” the King hastily said, and went on to himself in an undertone, “important—unimportant—unimportant—important —” as if he were trying which word sounded best.
Manx: “Neu-scanshoil, son shickyrys, lhisins er ghra,” dooyrt y Ree dy siyragh, as hie eh er rishyn hene lesh coraa injil, “scanshoil - neu-scanshoil - neu-scanshoil – scanshoil—” myr dy beagh eh prowal feddyn y fockle va sheeanal share.

English: Some of the jury wrote it down “important,” and some “unimportant.”
Manx: Screeu kuse jeh fir ny bingey eh sheese myr “scanshoil”, as kuse elley “neu-scanshoil.”

English: Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; “but it doesn’t matter a bit,” she thought to herself.
Manx: Va Ealish abyl fakin shoh, er y fa dy row ee faggys dy liooar daue dy yeeaghyn harrish ny sclateyn oc; “agh s’cummey shen,” smooinee ish ree hene.

English: At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book,
Manx: Ec y ghrig shoh, y Ree, va screeu dy tarroogh rish tammylt sy lioar-note echey, ren eshyn gyllagh magh “Tostid!”, as lhaih eh magh ass e lioar,

English: “Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court,”
Manx: “Reill Jees as Daeed. Shegin da gagh peiagh ta ny smoo na meeiley er yrjid faagail y chooyrt.”

English: Everybody looked at Alice.
Manx: Yeeagh dy chooilley pheiagh er Ealish.

English: “I’m not a mile high,” said Alice.
Manx: “Cha nel mish meeiley er yrjid,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “You are,” said the King.
Manx: “Ta,” dooyrt y Ree.

English: “Nearly two miles high,” added the Queen.
Manx: “Bunnys daa veeiley er yrjid,” dooyrt y Venrein.

English: “Well, I shan’t go, at any rate,” said Alice: “besides, that’s not a regular rule: you invented it just now.”
Manx: “Cha vaagym aghterbee,” dooyrt Ealish: “cha nee reill reiltagh shen: v’eh jeant euish er y gherrit.”

English: “It’s the oldest rule in the book,” said the King.
Manx: “Shen y reill shinney sy lioar,” dooyrt y Ree.

English: “Then it ought to be Number One,” said Alice.
Manx: “Lhisagh eh ve Reill Nane eisht,” dooyrt Ealish.

English: The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily.
Manx: Haink y Ree dy ve bane-eddinagh as ghooin eh e lioar-note dy siyragh.

English: “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.
Manx: “Smooinee-jee er y vriwnys eu,” dooyrt eh rish y ving lesh coraa injil va er craa.

English: “There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”
Manx: “Ree Ooasle, ta tooilley feanish ry heet foast, my sailliu," dooyrt y Chonning Vane, ren lheim seose as driss mooar er: “ta shin dy jeeragh er ngeddyn y pabyr shoh nish.”

English: “What’s in it?” said the Queen.
Manx: “Cre t’aynsyn?” dooyrt y Venrein.

English: “I haven’t opened it yet,” said the White Rabbit, “but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to—to somebody.”
Manx: “Cha nel eh foshlit aym foast,” dooyrt y Chonning Vane; “agh t’eh jeeaghyn dy nee screeuyn t’ayn, screeut liorish y phryssoonagh rish — rish peiagh ennagh.”

English: “It must have been that,” said the King, “unless it was written to nobody, which isn’t usual, you know.”
Manx: “Shegin da ve myr shen,” dooyrt y Ree, “mannagh row eh screeut rish neu-pheiagh, nagh vel ny red cliaghtagh, ta fys eu.”

English: “Who is it directed to?” said one of the jurymen.
Manx: “Rish quoi t’eh currit?” vrie nane jeh fir ny bingey.

English: “It isn’t directed at all,” said the White Rabbit; “in fact, there’s nothing written on the outside.”
Manx: “Cha nel eh currit rish peiagh erbee,” dooyrt y Chonning Vane: “dy jarroo, cha nel veg screeut er cheu-mooie.”

English: He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added “It isn’t a letter, after all: it’s a set of verses.”
Manx: Va’n screeuyn neu-fillit echey as eshyn loayrt, as eisht dooyrt eh “Cha nee screeuyn t'ayn lurg ooilley shen: she raneyn jeh daan t'ayn.”

English: “Are they in the prisoner’s handwriting?” asked another of the jurymen.
Manx: “Vel ad screeut liorish laue y phryssoonagh?” vrie fer elley jeh’n ving.

English: “No, they’re not,” said the White Rabbit, “and that’s the queerest thing about it.”
Manx: “Cha nel,” dooyrt y Chonning Vane, “as shen y red smoo quaagh ta bentyn rish.”

English: (The jury all looked puzzled.)
Manx: (Va ooilley fir ny bingey jeeaghyn fud y cheilley ayns ny king oc.)

English: “He must have imitated somebody else’s hand,” said the King. (The jury all brightened up again.)
Manx: “Gyn ourys ren eh arrish er screeudeyrys pheiagh ennagh elley,” dooyrt y Ree. (Haink beggan boggey er y ving reesht.)

English: “Please your Majesty,” said the Knave, “I didn’t write it, and they can’t prove I did: there’s no name signed at the end.”
Manx: “My sailliu, Ree Ooasle,” dooyrt y Fieaumanagh, “cha screeu mish eh, as cha nod ad fondaghey dy screeu: cha nel ennym erbee screeut ec y chione jeh.”

English: “If you didn’t sign it,” said the King, “that only makes the matter worse.
Manx: “Mannagh dug oo dty ennym huggey,” dooyrt y Ree, “ta shen cur er dy ve ny smessey foast.

English: You must have meant some mischief, or else you’d have signed your name like an honest man.”
Manx: Gyn ourys erbee v’ou son jannoo assee ennagh, er nonney veagh oo er chur dty ennym huggey goll rish dooinney ynrick.”

English: There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.
Manx: Er shoh, v’ad ooilley bwoalley bassyn: va shoh y chied red aghtal va'n Ree er ghra y laa shen.

English: “That proves his guilt,” said the Queen.
Manx: “Ta shen fondaghey dy vel eh oolee,” dooyrt y Venrein: “myr shen, ersooyl lesh —”

English: “It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
Manx: “Cha nel eh fondaghey red erbee myr shen!” dooyrt Ealish. “Cammah, cha nhione diu cre ta’n bun jeu!”

English: “Read them,” said the King.
Manx: “Lhaih magh ad,” dooyrt y Ree.

English: The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. “Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?” he asked.
Manx: Hug y Chonning Vane e speckleyryn mysh. “C’raad ghoym toshiaght, Ree Ooasle?” vrie eh.

English: “Begin at the beginning,” the King said gravely, “and go on till you come to the end: then stop.”
Manx: “Gow toshiaght ec y toshiaght,” dooyrt y Ree feer trome- chooishagh, “as gow er gys hig oo gys y chione: eisht scuirr.”

English: These were the verses the White Rabbit read:—
Manx: Va slane tostid sy chooyrt choud's va'n Chonning Vane lhaih magh ny raneyn shoh:-

English: “They told me you had been to her,
Manx: “Dinsh adsyn dou dy jagh oo huic,

English: And mentioned me to him:
Manx: Dimraa oo eisht mee da:

English: She gave me a good character,
Manx: Dooyrt ish dy row mee dooinney glick,

English: But said I could not swim.
Manx: Agh foast nagh noddin snaue.

English: He sent them word I had not gone
Manx: Hug eshyn fys nagh jagh mee eisht

English: (We know it to be true):
Manx: (Shione dooin dy vel shen kiart)

English: If she should push the matter on,
Manx: Dy jinnagh ish cur niart da'n chooish,

English: What would become of you?
Manx: Cre'n erree harragh ort?

English: I gave her one, they gave him two,
Manx: Hug ee jee nane, hug ad da piyr,

English: You gave us three or more;
Manx: Hug uss dooin tree ny nuy;

English: They all returned from him to you,
Manx: Haink adsyn hood reesht veihsyn riyr,

English: Though they were mine before.
Manx: Ga lhiams v'adsyn roie.

English: If I or she should chance to be
Manx: Dy beigns hene ny ish, my s'leayr,

English: Involved in this affair,
Manx: Kianlt seose sy chooish shoh nish,

English: He trusts to you to set them free,
Manx: T’eh treishteil lhiggey daue goll seyr

English: Exactly as we were.
Manx: Myr va shin, kyndagh rish.

English: My notion was that you had been
Manx: Heill mish dy row uss hene dy mooar

English: (Before she had this fit)
Manx: (Roish daink ee dy ve keoi)

English: An obstacle that came between
Manx: Dty lhiettalagh va olk dy liooar,

English: Him, and ourselves, and it.
Manx: Soiet eddyr ain dy creoi.

English: Don’t let him know she liked them best,
Manx: Ny lhig da feddyn magh dy row

English: For this must ever be
Manx: Ee graihagh orroo shen;

English: A secret, kept from all the rest,
Manx: Bee shoh myr folliaght dooint dy braew

English: Between yourself and me.”
Manx: Sy chione ayds as aym pene.”

English: “That’s the most important piece of evidence we’ve heard yet,” said the King, rubbing his hands; “so now let the jury—
Manx: “Shen y feanish smoo scanshoil ta shin er chlashtyn foast,” dooyrt y Ree as eshyn rubbey e laueyn; “nish, lhig da’n ving—”

English: “If any one of them can explain it,” said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn’t a bit afraid of interrupting him,)
Manx: “My oddys fer erbee jeu soilshaghey magh eh,” dooyrt Ealish (v’ee er naase cho mooar er y gherrit as nagh row ee goaill aggle erbee roish brishey stiagh er),

English: “I’ll give him sixpence. I don’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it.”
Manx: “verym shey ping da. Cha nel mish credjal dy vel keeall erbee ayn.”

English: The jury all wrote down on their slates, “She doesn’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it,” but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
Manx: Screeu ooilley fir ny bingey sheese, er nyn sclateyn, “Cha nel ish hene credjal dy vel keeall erbee ayn,” agh cha phrow fer erbee jeu dy hoilshaghey magh y pabyr.

English: “If there’s no meaning in it,” said the King, “that saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn’t try to find any.
Manx: “Mannagh vel keeall erbee ayn,” dooyrt y Ree, “ta shen shaghney boirey erskyn towse, ta fys eu, er y fa nagh lhiass dooin feddyn boirey.

English: And yet I don’t know,” he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; “I seem to see some meaning in them, after all.
Manx: As foast cha nel fys aym,” hie eh er, sheeyney magh ny raneyn er e ghlioon as eshyn jeeaghyn orroo lesh un tooill; “Ta mee sheiltyn dy vel mee feddyn keeall ennagh ayndaue ny yeih shen as ooilliu.

English: ‘— said I could not swim —’ you can’t swim, can you?” he added, turning to the Knave.
Manx: ‘— Agh foast, nagh noddin snaue’ — “cha vod uss snaue, vod?” dooyrt eh, çhyndaa gys y Fieaumanagh.

English: The Knave shook his head sadly. “Do I look like it?” he said.
Manx: Chrie y Fieaumanagh e chione dy trimshagh. “Vel eh jeeaghyn dy voddym?” dooyrt eh.

English: (Which he certainly did not, being made entirely of cardboard.)
Manx: (Son shickyrys, cha row, er y fa dy row eh ooilley jeant ass pabyr creoi.)

English: “All right, so far,” said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself:
Manx: “Mie dy liooar, choud’s shoh,” dooyrt y Ree; as hie eh er as eshyn gra ny raneyn rish hene trooid ny feeacklyn:

English: “‘We know it to be true —’ that’s the jury, of course —
Manx: “‘Shione dooin dy vel shen kiart’ — shen y ving, son shickyrys —

English: [If she would give force to the matter — without doubt, that is the Queen — ‘What fate would befall thee? — What indeed!]
Manx: ‘Dy jinnagh ish cur niart da’n chooish’ — gyn ourys, shen y Venrein — ‘Cre’n erree harragh ort?’ — C’red, dy jarroo! [7]
Notes: [7] There is no equivalent to the contents of this cell in the original English version of 1865, it may be that  they do appear in a later version.

English: ‘I gave her one, they gave him two ’ why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know —”
Manx: ‘Hug mee jee nane, hug ad da piyr’ — gyn ourys, shen ny v’eh jannoo lesh ny sooanyn, ta fys eu —”

English: “But, it goes on ‘they all returned from him to you,’” said Alice.
Manx: “Agh t’eh goll er lesh ‘Haink adsyn hood reesht veihsyn,’” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Why, there they are!” said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table.
Manx: “Dy jarroo, shen eh dhyt!” dooyrt y Ree dy barriaghtagh, cowraghey magh ny sooanyn er y voayrd.

English: “Nothing can be clearer than that. Then again —‘before she had this fit —’ you never had fits, my dear, I think?” he said to the Queen.
Manx: “Cha vod red erbee ve ny smoo cronnal na shen. As red elley — “Roish my daink ee dy ve keoi —’ cha row uss rieau keoi, veen, row?” dooyrt eh rish y Venrein.

English: “Never!” said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke.
Manx: “Cha row rieau!” dooyrt y Venrein dy h-eulyssagh, as ish, ceau tobbyr-doo lesh y Jiolgan Leaghyr myr v’ee loayrt.

English: (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)
Manx: (Va Illiam Beg treih er scuirr jeh screeu er y e sclate lesh un vair, er yn oyr dy dooar eh magh nagh row cowrey erbee jeant myr shen; agh nish ghow eh toshiaght dy siyragh reesht, gymmydey y doo, va sheeley sheese e eddin, choud's va veg faagit.)

English: “Then the words don’t fit you,” said the King, looking round the court with a smile. There was a dead silence.
Manx: “Myr shen, cha nel ny focklyn keoi shoh cooie dhyt,” dooyrt y Ree, jeeaghyn mygeayrt y chooyrt as eh mongey. Va slane tostid ayn.

English: “It’s a pun!” the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed,
Manx: “She raa daa foyragh t’ayn!” dooyrt y Ree dy fergagh, as ren dy chooilley pheiagh gearey.

English: “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.
Manx: “Lhig da’n ving smooinaghtyn er y vriwnys oc,” dooyrt y Ree, son red goll rish y feedoo keayrt y laa shen.

English: “No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first — verdict afterwards.”
Manx: “Cha nee, cha nee!” dooyrt y Venrein. “Deyrey hoshiaght — briwnys ny lurg.”

English: “Stuff and nonsense!” said Alice loudly. “The idea of having the sentence first!”
Manx: “Slane boghtynid!” dooyrt Ealish dy daaney. “Cre’n ommidjys dy gheyrey hoshiaght!”

English: “Hold your tongue!” said the Queen, turning purple.
Manx: “Cum dty hengey!” dooyrt y Venrein as ish cheet dy ve gorrym jiarg.

English: “I won’t!” said Alice.
Manx: “Cha jeanym!” dooyrt Ealish.

English: “Off with her head!” the Queen shouted at the top of her voice.
Manx: “Ersooyl lesh e kione!” dyllee y Venrein magh ec mullagh e coraa.

English: Nobody Moved.
Manx: Cha ghleaysh peiagh erbee.

English: “Who cares for you?” said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.)
Manx: “Quoi ta cur geill diuish?” dooyrt Ealish (v'ee er naase gys e mooadys kiart liorish y traa shoh.

English: “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”
Manx: “Cha nel shiuish agh sthock dy chaartyn!”

English: At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
Manx: Er shoh, dirree y slane sthock seose syn aer as haink getlagh neose urree; lhig ee magh screeagh beg, lieh lesh aggle as lieh lesh ferg, as phrow ee dy scughey ersooyl ad, as hooar ee magh dy row ee ny lhie er y vroogh as e kione ayns glioon e shayrey, va scughey ersooyl dy meeley duillagyn marroo va er vennalt sheese veih ny biljyn er e h-eddin.

English: “Wake up, Alice dear!” said her sister; “Why, what a long sleep you’ve had!”
Manx: “Dooisht, Ealish veen!” dooyrt e shuyr. “Cammah, v’ou dty chadley feer foddey!”

English: “Oh, I’ve had such a curious dream!” said Alice, and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said,
Manx: “Ogh, cre’n ashlish whaagh honnick mee!” dooyrt Ealish. As dinsh ee da'n chuyr eck, chammah as v’ee abyl, ooilley e Contoyrtyssyn quaagh shoh t'ou er lhaih mychione er y gherrit; as tra v’ee jeant, phaag e shuyr ee, as dooyrt ee

English: “It was a curious dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it’s getting late.”
Manx: “She ashlish whaagh v’ayn, son shickyrys; agh roie stiagh son dty hey nish: t’eh cheet dy ve anmagh.”

English: So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.
Manx: Myr shen, hrog Ealish urree as ersooyl lhee as ish smooinaghtyn choud’s v’ee roie, as va shen feer chooie, cre’n ashlish yindyssagh.

English: But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:—
Manx: Agh hannee e shuyr raad v’ee, e kione ny lhie er e laue, as ish jeeaghyn er y ghrian goll dy lhie, as smooinaghtyn er Ealish veg as ooilley e Contoyrtyssyn yindyssagh, gys v'ee hene dreamal neesht er aght ennagh, as er hoh e dreamal:-

English: First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers
Manx: Hoshiaght, ren ee dreamal mychione Ealish veg hene: keayrt elley, va ny laueyn beggey nyn lhie ry cheilley er e glioon, as ny sooillyn gial jeean jeeaghyn stiagh ayns ny sooillyn eck hene

English: — she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that would always get into her eyes
Manx: — v’ee clashtyn y sheean firrinagh jeh’n choraa eck, as v'ee fakin yn aght beg quaagh v’ee ceau e kione dy gheddyn rey rish y folt rouail va kinjagh goll stiagh ayns e sooillyn

English: — and still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister’s dream.
Manx: — as foast, choud’s v’ee geaishtagh, ny sheiltyn y ve geaishtagh, va’n slane boayl mygeayrt y mooee cheet dy ve bio lesh ny cretooryn quaagh ayns ashlish e shayrey beg.

English: The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by—the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool
Manx: Va’n faiyr liauyr ec e cassyn goll er craa tra va’n Chonning Vane siyraghey shaghey — y Lugh agglit skeolley e raad trooid y dubbey va er gerrey

English: — she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution
Manx: — v’ee abyl clashtyn clabberey ny cappanyn myr va’n Mwaagh Vart as e chaarjyn goaill ayrn ayns nyn lhongey dy bragh farraghtyn, as coraa ard y Venrein tra v’ee goardaghey e goaldee treih dy ve currit gy baase

English: — once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess’s knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it
Manx: — keayrt elley va’n oikan-muickey streighyraght er glioon y Vendiuic, choud’s va moggaidyn as jystyn tharmaneaghey mygeayrt

English: — once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.
Manx: — keayrt elley, va screeagh y Ghryphon, y jeest jeh penn leoaie y Jiolgan Leaghyr er y sclate, as toghtey ny muick rangagh plooghit, lhieeney yn aer, mestit lesh sogh y Far-Ligganagh Marrey treih sy foddid.

English: So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality
Manx: Myr shen, hannee ee ny soie, e sooillyn dooint, as ish hene lieh chredjal ayns cheer ny Yindyssyn, ga dy row fys eck nagh row urree agh fosley ad reesht, as veagh dy chooilley nhee caghlaait gys rieughid dree

English: — the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds
Manx: — cha beagh y faiyr agh craa sy gheay, as y dubbey freayney beggan kyndagh rish ny cuirtleeyn

English: — the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen’s shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy
Manx: — veagh clabberey ny cappanyn caghlaa gys claggyraght ny cluig keyrragh, as veagh yllaghyn ard y Venrein caghlaa gys coraa y vochilley

English: — and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard
Manx: — as veagh streighyraght yn oikan, screeagh y Ghryphon, as ooilley ny sheeanyn quaagh elley, caghlaa (va fys eck) gys corvaal mestit y voayl eirinagh

English: — while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle’s heavy sobs.
Manx: — choud’s veagh eamagh yn ollee sy foddid goaill yn ynnyd jeh soghyn sharroo y Far-Ligganagh Marrey.

English: Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make their eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.
Manx: Sy jerrey, heill ee ree hene yn aght veagh y chuyr veg shoh eck cheet dy ve, sy traa ry heet, ny ben aasit ish hene; as yn aght veagh ee freayll, car ny bleeantyn ooilliu, y cree glen as graihagh jeh e lambaanid; as yn aght veagh ee chymsaghey mygeayrt y mooee paitchyn beggey elley, as cur er ny sooillyn ocsyn dy ve gial as jeean lesh skeealyn quaagh dy liooar, foddee lesh ashlish cheer ny Yindyssyn veih foddey er dy henney; as yn aght veagh co-ennaghtyn eck lesh ooilley nyn drimshaghyn neu-ghoillee, as feddyn taitnys ayns ooilley yn boggey neu-ghoillee oc, as cooinaghtyn eck er y lambaanid eck hene as ny laghyn souree maynrey.

English: THE END
Manx: YN JERREY

English: [7] There is no equivalent to the contents of this cell in the original English version of 1865, it may be that  they do appear in a later version.
